story:
Who Are We?

We are Problem Child Productions, and we are raising money to produce our next project, Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead. The production will be staged in a three week run from July 13th-July 30th at an Off-Off Broadway Venue. 

Where Your Contribution Goes

All proceeds raised by this Indiegogo Campaign will be used for royalties, a theater rental with 24/7 access for our three week run, rehearsal space, marketing, and materials for sets, lighting, costumes, and sound.

We appreciate any donation that helps us bring this production to the stage. Check out our amazing perks that you can receive through your generous contributions!

The Impact

Dog Sees God is a story that Problem Child Productions has wanted to tell since before its inception. We are so excited that we finally have the means to tell it. With themes of bullying and tolerance, we feel that Dog Sees God is an especially relevant story to tell during these present events.

Problem Child Productions strives to create work and provide a safe and challenging space for performers to flex their creative muscles and make an impact on the artistic world. We are so proud to continue our work with Dog Sees God.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone has the means to give a monetary donation. If you would still like to help out our campaign, please share this link with others who might be interested.

 

Thank you so much for your time and contribution. We're looking forward to bringing the Blockhead to Off-Off-Broadway!

Amanda Varvar and Courtney Megaro, Co-Producers

story:
Founded in 2016 by Cary Reynolds, Julia Stier, and Rachael McNamara, Unearthed Theatre Company is committed to telling stories in non-traditional ways, whether that is by unearthing newer works, experimenting with the integration of the audience into the world, or by showcasing voices that are traditionally silent in the theatrical world.

On the closing night of their inaugural production, "How Love Lasts," the show's playwrights Daniel Landberg and Brooke Bishop engaged with the cast and audience in a Q&A about love, theatre, and playwriting. 

This season, Unearthed Theatre Company-- under the direction of Hannah Leibson-- will be producing Scott Shallenbarger's play "On Stars Not Falling." 

"'On Stars Not Falling' tells the story of college friends who dropped out of school following a shared traumatic experience. Five months later, they gather for a birthday party on the rooftop of a Chicago three-flat. An unexpected guest who transforms their lives forever interrupts the celebration. This 90-minute, full-length play empowers those who feel small; offers faith to those who feel lost; and ultimately, awakens the courage in us all to stand-up, move forward, and claim our own happiness."

All contriibutions will be used for paying for the theatre space, props, and set pieces.

Contributions to this production are not tax deductible.

story:
Description du projet

 

Depuis trois ans, les productions du Temps qui s'arrête propose au public de Québec, une revue de l'année théâtrale déjantée, le Beu-Bye.

 

Cynique, grinçante et bouffonesque, elle s'éloigne des Byes-Byes ou autre revue de l’année du genre par sa forme éclatée et sa liberté artistique. Construite sous forme de tableaux scéniques théâtralisés, la formule fait ses preuves grâce à une composition dramaturgique où le simple citoyen est aux prises avec des événements qui ont marqué l'actualité. C’est dans cet esprit que le Beu-Bye fait mouche. En s'éloignant de la simple caricature de personnages publics célèbres, l'œuvre se distingue et donne une théâtralité unique au projet.

 

Vos dons serviront à la production du spectacle et la mise en marché de celui-ci.

 

LISTE DES PARTICIPANTS

 

1) Interprètes

 

Joëlle Bourdon

Jean-Philippe Côté

Edwige Morin

Monika Pilon

Lucien Ratio

Nicolas Létourneau

           

2) Équipe artistique

 

Écriture des numéros                              Jean-Philippe Côté

                                                                        Philippe Durocher

                                                                        Lucien Ratio

                                                                        Nicola-Frank Vachon

 

Équipe d’auteurs invités                        Frédéric Blanchette

                                                                        Claude Montminy

                                                                        Pascale Renaud-Hébert

                                                           

Script-édition et mise en scène                     Lucien Ratio

Assistance à la mise en scène                       Philippe Durocher

Conception d’éclairage

et scénographie                                                  Jean-François Labbé

Conception costumes

et accessoires                                                      Marie Mc Nicoll

Conception sonore                                             Mathieu Campagna

 

 

3) Équipe de production

 

Direction artistique                                              Lucien Ratio

Direction administrative                                    Edwige Morin

Directeur de production                                    Jean-Philippe Côté

Direction des communications                       Philippe Durocher

story:
Short Summary

MEET VINCENT DiDONATO (Lou Martini, Jr.) single, lonely and the reluctant new owner of Centennial Casting, a metal shop in lower Manhattan. While cleaning out his late mother's desk, Vincent stumbles across a stack of headshots from eager actors who had mistakenly assumed Centennial was an entertainment casting agency.  Vincent, smitten by one photo in particular – a down-on-her-luck actress, Edie Keaton (Alicia Harding) – is convinced by his best friend and foreman Doo Doo (Anthony Patellis) to pretend to be a theatrical casting director. In a New York minute, the shop becomes a casting office. Edie arrives for an interview and sparks fly as Vincent tries to balance sheet metal and show business… only to realize the ruse jeopardizes any shot he's got at winning Edie’s love. Waist-deep in deception, Vincent tries to find a way to reveal the truth without losing her forever. Centennial Casting is a heart-warming, romantic comedy filled with twists and turns, catharsis and cannoli.

CENTENNIAL CASTING

Written by Gino DiIorio and Nancy Bleemer

Featuring  
Lou Martini, Jr.  •  Alicia Harding  •  Anthony Patellis
Janine Molinari  •  Charles Gould

CENTENNIAL CASTING has had a number of regional productions and most recently a NYC workshop at the Triad. All have been greatly received! We have been highly encouraged to take this play to the next level and produce a top notch quality run in NYC. We've assembled an amazing creative and technical team, along with our talented cast of actors, but we now need the support of all of our family and friends to make this wonderful show a reality. 

With the funds raised here, we will be covering all our production costs, including rehearsal space, theater rental, sound and lighting design, set design, publicity and staffing.  Our passion for this play is undeniable and we are certain you'll love it too! We look forward to sharing this hilarious, heartwarming piece of theater with you all. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $25,000 to stage this show in New York City at the prestigious June Havoc Theatre, August 15 - August 30. We have already raised from our own funds a $10,000 deposit for the theatre. We need:

  • An additional $10,000 for the theatre
  • An additional $6000 for set design and construction
  • An additional $3000 for publicity
  • An additional $2000 for rehearsal space
  • An additional $2000 for lighting design
  • An additional $2000 for costumes, props, programs, stage manager, etc.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends, family, people in the grocery store. 

  • Send an email to five people who love the theatre and love to laugh.
  • Share our site (and plight) on Indiegogo and social media.
  • Add your positive energy to ours! 
  • We appreciate each and every gift!

Lou Martini Jr. and Alicia Harding
MEET THE STARS OF CENTENNIAL CASTING
       

LOU MARTINI, Jr. (Vincent Didonato) was born into a show biz family. His dad was a well-respected character actor and entertainer, Lou's early film credits include The Godfather and What's So Bad About Feeling Good with Mary Tyler Moore. After graduating from the University of Houston, Lou entertained being a sportscaster before landing a lead roll in Tony 'n Tina's Wedding. His TV credits include Vinyl, The Americans, Orange Is the New Black and Law & Order: SVU. He was nominated for a SAG Award for his role as Anthony Infante on The Sopranos. He was host of E's Gasteneau Girls. Lou's film credits include: West End, To Redemption, Alto and the critically acclaimed black comedy, Suicide Notes. Lou star's in his original screenplay, Honor, this Fall.

       

ALICIA HARDING  (Edie Keaton) is best known for Tuesdays with Morrie (1999), Tenderness (2009) and Conventioneers (2005). She's appeared in numerous films (working with Robert DeNiro and Russell Crowe) and in theTV shows Blue Bloods, Without a Trace, Law & Order CI, and The Late Show w/ David Letterman. Alicia's performed in several sketch comedy troupes and you may recognize her from numerous national commercials. She recently played Maggie Bennett in Vincent Pastore’s original play, Wild Children.  Her Off Broadway and regional credits include Cleo in Rocket to the Moon (Soho Rep), Annelle in Steel Magnolias (Sanford Meisner), Miami in Seduced (Kraine), Roxane in Cyrano de Bergerac (Lamb’s), A Chorus Line (Riverside Theater, Fl), and The Engagement (Hudson Theater, LA).

        

ANTHONY PATELLIS (Doo Doo) is an actor, director, writer, and producer, best known for his role as Charles Cirillo, in HBO’s, The Sopranos. Other television and film appearances include, Law & Order(s), New York: Undercover, Crime Story, The Guiding Light, One Last Thing, I Think I Do, Misled, and Miami Or Bust. He created the role of Jimmy Pegorino, in the mega-hit, video game, Grand Theft Auto IV.  Anthony has acted on stage extensively Off-Broadway, in NYC, regionally, including Shear Madness, at The Kennedy Center, and internationally, including the 50th Anniversary International tour of West Side Story, at La Scala Opera, and in 14 countries, on 3 continents. As a director, Anthony has worked in NYC, London, and across the USA, and is a national director of Tony ‘n Tina’s Wedding. His extensive training includes Master Classes, with legendary teachers, Lee Strasberg, and Stella Adler.

         

JANINE MOLINARI (Michele) has performed on stage throughout the USA, Canada and Asia including the Off Broadway, national and Japanese tour of Tony n' Tina's Wedding playing Tina the stripper and a nun! She played Hovel in Fiddler sub-terrain at La Mamma ETC, and the role of “ NYC” in Oren Safdie’s West Bank, UK (West Coast premiere). Janine has performed in multiple musical productions, including; Mary Magdalene in Jesus Christ Superstar, Amnesia in Nunsense, Smitty in How To Succeed...and Sarah in Guys and Dolls. Janine stars in the soon to be released web-series, Tap Out Of It! She is also the resident choreographer/director at the Seven Angels Theater in CT and the owner, and artistic director of DanceMolinari NYC/LA. 

         

CHARLES GOULD (Carmine) is a comedian who lives in the Big Apple. Apparently he's starved for attention. If you recognize him, he hopes it's because he's appeared on MTV (as a nerd), College Humor (as a nerd) and Law and Order (as a nerd blogger) but more likely it's probably because he looks like that kid you went to summer camp with named Ethan. Charles was named a 2015 "Comic to Watch" by Comedy Central and performed as a finalist in the New York's Funniest as part of the New York Comedy Festival. If you're the best looking person in your family or group of friends, then you won't find him funny. His YouTube videos include the hysterical, Puss, about two desperate Millenials who dress like cats to get jobs; Red Flags (why you shouldn’t date him); and East Village Haikus (for all the drunk girls).

story:
InFringe Fest is an independent theatre & performance festival in New Orleans held in our downtown neighborhoods - St Roch, the Faubourg Marigny, Bywater - April 14 to 17, 2016

[ InFringe Fest has no connection to the New Orleans Fringe Festival (or any of its iterations) nor to its successor all-arts festival, Faux/Real. ]

Which is exactly why InFringe Fest is important. A back-to-basics, locally oriented festival is badly needed: for DIY theatermakers and performance artists, for the neighborhood, we think for our audiences. InFringe Fest will be strong, small, tight, and fast on purpose...a limited number of venues (no BYOVs) within a walkable area on a comprehensible calendar grid.

"Strong, small, tight and fast"...and INEXPENSIVE. Not just for our audiences (usually seven bucks per show, $40 for an all-weekend pass) but in its set-up, promotion and production costs. Most all of our labor is volunteer. Our venues are opening their doors for a cut of the door. There are no fees to the performers, at all. InFringe Fest itself, as an entity, keeps only ten percent of the take, in hopes of using that to pay its front-of-house and backstage managers.

The costs that necessitate this campaign are approximate but simple...

$2000 toward calendar/program guide
$500 toward posters & postcards
$500 toward technical equipment for needy venues
$200 toward logo design
$300 toward website
...that's it, folks.

PHOTOS FROM SOME OF THE UPCOMING SHOWS:



(more & larger on the gallery tab)

HERE ARE THE VENUES
(working upriver to downriver):

  • The AllWays Lounge, 2240 St Claude [Ground Zero of New Orleans fringe festivals in their earliest years; now home of the 'InFringe Tent', the opening night party, and three great original variety/burlesque shows]

  • The Mudlark Public Theatre, 1200 Port St [home of the nationally acclaimed Mudlark Giant Puppet Festival, running in conjunction with InFringe Fest]


  • PORT, 2120 Port St [second home of the Giant Puppet Festival, and of cutting-edge experimental performance in general]


  • Art Klub, 1941 Arts St [brand-new venue! Focusing on multi-discipline performance and multi-cultural arts: theatre, dance, video, music and art installation.]


  • Playhouse NOLA, 3214 Burgundy [cozy storefront space; primarily for classes ahd the community, new work, and children's theatre. For InFringe Fest, the home of comedy]


  • Happyland Theatre, 3126 Burgundy [almost brand-new venue! And warehouse big, so the InFringe Fest home of the eye-popping music & performance extravaganzas]


  • United Bakery Gallery, 1337 St Bernard [indescribable and funky Lower 7th storefront gallery-cum-theater; home of photography, music, poetry, performance, everything]


  • The Fortress of Lushington, 2215 Burgundy [mellow open-plan performance space and artist studio. Everything works on this stage]


  • Paradise NOLA, 2360 St Claude [new venue in the old Oya Market! A fully equipped backroom space]


  • The Garret, at the Hatchery, 4210 St Claude, upstairs [an actual garret! Ideal for solo performance, home for InFringe Fest to the smart on-their-own women]


  • Cafe Istanbul, 2372 St Claude [an all-purpose theatre & lounge, for InFringe Fest where nervy cabaret is happening]


  • Bar Redux, 801 Poland Avenue [a genuine neighborhood mainstay, home to any show where the purpose is to have fun]



IF WE DON'T REACH OUR GOAL...
...WE GO AHEAD ANYWAY.


IF YOU JUST CAN'T CONTRIBUTE, WE UNDERSTAND. WE'RE POOR TOO. JUST PLEASE SHARE THIS FAR AND WIDE.

IF YOU CAN CONTRIBUTE, BLESS YOU. ALSO PLEASE SHARE THIS FAR AND WIDE.

The AllWays Lounge, 2240 St Claude [Ground Zero of New Orleans fringe festivals in their earliest years; now home of the 'InFringe Tent', the opening night party, and three great original variety/burlesque shows]

The Mudlark Public Theatre, 1200 Port St [home of the nationally acclaimed Mudlark Giant Puppet Festival, running in conjunction with InFringe Fest]



PORT, 2120 Port St [second home of the Giant Puppet Festival, and of cutting-edge experimental performance in general]



Art Klub, 1941 Arts St [brand-new venue! Focusing on multi-discipline performance and multi-cultural arts: theatre, dance, video, music and art installation.]



Playhouse NOLA, 3214 Burgundy [cozy storefront space; primarily for classes ahd the community, new work, and children's theatre. For InFringe Fest, the home of comedy]



Happyland Theatre, 3126 Burgundy [almost brand-new venue! And warehouse big, so the InFringe Fest home of the eye-popping music & performance extravaganzas]



United Bakery Gallery, 1337 St Bernard [indescribable and funky Lower 7th storefront gallery-cum-theater; home of photography, music, poetry, performance, everything]



The Fortress of Lushington, 2215 Burgundy [mellow open-plan performance space and artist studio. Everything works on this stage]



Paradise NOLA, 2360 St Claude [new venue in the old Oya Market! A fully equipped backroom space]



The Garret, at the Hatchery, 4210 St Claude, upstairs [an actual garret! Ideal for solo performance, home for InFringe Fest to the smart on-their-own women]



Cafe Istanbul, 2372 St Claude [an all-purpose theatre & lounge, for InFringe Fest where nervy cabaret is happening]



Bar Redux, 801 Poland Avenue [a genuine neighborhood mainstay, home to any show where the purpose is to have fun]




IF WE DON'T REACH OUR GOAL......WE GO AHEAD ANYWAY.

IF YOU JUST CAN'T CONTRIBUTE, WE UNDERSTAND. WE'RE POOR TOO. JUST PLEASE SHARE THIS FAR AND WIDE.IF YOU CAN CONTRIBUTE, BLESS YOU. ALSO PLEASE SHARE THIS FAR AND WIDE.

story:
Sara, who am I ? 


 Sara Kozlowska - Graduate of Ballet School of Feliks Parnell in Lodz (Poland), where I started my adventure with dance. During those studies I took part in many performances that were played in Grand Theatre, Musical Theater and in  Philharmonic in Lodz. Later on I began dancing in V6 Theatre in Lodz. I developed  many different dance techniques along with acrobatics. In 2012 I joined KIJO Group, where I constantly improve my skills in contemporary and physical dance, improvisation, contact improvisation and participate in group activities. In dance I am fascinated in physicality, strengh and endurance of the human body. Since 2014 I study choreography and dance techniques on Music Academy of Kiejstut and Grazyna Bacewicz in Lodz.

How I done it?
In October last year I went to Berlin, where was the audition to "Dance Journey" which is organized by the Kibbutz Contemporary Dance Company in Israel. It worked and I received an invitation. So my adventure began! :)  


What is the "Dance Journey"?


The Dance Journey program is a unique  program hosted by Kibbutz Contemporary Dance Company (KCDC), one of the world's leading contemporary dance companies. The program includes repertoire lessons as well as ballet, modern, contemporary and pilates classes. 
Dance Journey dancers also have the opportunity to take part in 'Nitzotzot' where they are given the opportunity, time and space to create an original choreographic work.

The program's faculty is composed of some of the best choreographers and dance teachers in Israel and worldwide. In addition to advancing our career as a dancer, the program's aim is to introduce participants to Israel’s vibrant culture.  The program takes place in the International Dance Village in Kibbutz Ga’aton, Israel where the KCDC dancers and participants of the Dance Journey program study and live together.

A growing number of Dance Journey's past participants are now dancing professionally in KCDC's main company and second company and other Dance Journey program graduates have received contracts with other professional dance companies in Israel and around the world.  The Dance Journey program offers dancers a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for professional development and job networking with other Israeli and international companies.


                      https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gfXaVFQN0y4


 What I need & What You get! :) 

The 5-month program’s cost is $8,500 USD which includes: the Dance Jouney Program, MASA cultural activities, trips throughout Israel, hebrew classes, evening activities, medical insurance, accommodations for the duration of the program. This means that aside from the total program cost, the participant will need roughly $300 per month to cover living expenses along with the cost for the international flight to Israel.

The $8,500 USD in Poland is about 40,000 PLN, so it's a lot. I can't afford it by myself, that's the reason why I decided to collect money. Here I'd like to collect money for first istallment, which is $4,500 and $1,500 for living in Israel. I also have another project on polish website, I hope to collect there the second instalment which is $4,000 USD.


Contributions of any dollar amount will be gratefully received, and I will send you "perks" based on your contribution. 

If I don't  reach my goal in this program, I will still try to collect money on my "Dance Journey". But I hope that with your help I will fly to Israel! :) 


Why the "Journey" is so important for me? 

Participation in this program is very important for me, becouse as a young, maturing dancer I would like to experience, gain knowledge and develop my skills. 

Taking part in the program is an incredible chance to confront my knowledge of dance with what other people know about it. The opportunity to exchange experiences with dancers from all over the world, is the proverbial "encyclopaedia of knowledge" from which I can draw my own coclusions and then implement them to my work. 
I feel honored, becouse I was chosen from hundreds of dancers from around the world. It's a great feeling to be included among the elected and have a chance to aqurie knowledge in the "city of dancers". After five month, there is the opportunity to receive an invitation to the Kibbutz Contemporary Dance Company or to another company from Israel or around the world. 

I believe that participation in the "Dance Journey" can become a very important stage in the development of my career as a dancer and choreographer. I would like to enrich polish dance scene with the knowledge gained during this programe and share the idea how dance looks in KCDC,

I know that my "Dance Journey" dream is possible with your help. 


Other Ways You Can Help Me :) 


 I would be grateful for even $1, because every single step counts!  But I understand that not everyone can support me financialy. You can always help me in other way: 

  • please share my project with your friends around the world
  • let's make some noise about my campaign together!
  • if you have contact with to anyone  who you think can help me, please share it with me. 


Thank you so much, your generosity and support mean more than words can express!
Lots of love!
Sara :)

 I know that my "Dance Journey" dream is possible with your help. 

Other Ways You Can Help Me :) 

  I would be grateful for even $1, because every single step counts!  But I understand that not everyone can support me financialy. You can always help me in other way: 


please share my project with your friends around the world
let's make some noise about my campaign together!
if you have contact with to anyone  who you think can help me, please share it with me. 

Thank you so much, your generosity and support mean more than words can express!
Lots of love!
Sara :)

story:
This Summer, We Need Your Help . . . TO BRING ALCESTIS BACK! 

It's one of our eternally futile longings: to bring the love of your life back from the dead. But what if the impossible were actually possible? What if the ultimate miracle happened? What if, laws of the cosmos be damned, she really came back?

Such is the case in Memoriam, an inventive, multidisciplinary snapshot of the aftermath of a miracle. Inspired by an ancient Greek myth and millennia of wishful thinking, playwright Stephen Kaliski (West Lethargy, Gluten!) reunites a dead queen with her grieving king and then asks, "Is she really back?" What follows is a whirling journey through the looking glass of loss, memory, and the uncertain ownership we have over our own lives.

Memoriam is directed by Elizabeth Ostler and co-produced by Hypnic Theatre Company and Adjusted Realists, recipients of a 2016 Off Broadway Angels grant and creators of Gluten! at 59E59 Theaters and the acclaimed revival of Nicky Silver's Pterodactyls at Teatro Circulo.

Support The Debut! 

Your support will help launch this new play’s participation in the 2016 FringeNYC Festival (www.fringnyc.org), a critical first step in generating interest for regional and Off-Broadway productions. Our goal is to raise $5,000 for this staging. Amongst the many management expenses involved in Memoriam, your donation will help cover:

  • Theater Rental Fees
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Set Construction
  • Artist Salaries

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute at this time, please help by:

  • Posting this campaign to social media
  • Emailing the campaign to your friends

About the Creative Team

Stephen Kaliski (Playwright) is a director, playwright, and educator. Directing credits include Gluten! (59E59 Theaters), Pterodactyls (Teatro Circulo), Deadshot Mary (upcoming: The Bridge), A Midsummer Night’s Dream and In the Next Room or the vibrator play (Yale Dramatic Association), Vinegar Tom (Manhattanville College), The Minervae (On the Square; Backstage “Critic’s Pick”), This (Proprietors Theatre Company) Cardenio, The Violet Hour and The Dumb Waiter (Brooklyn College), West Lethargy (59E59, Edinburgh Fringe, New York Fringe), and His Minute Hand (Hollywood Fringe, 45 Bleecker). Playwriting credits include West Lethargy, which was published in Plays and Playwrights 2011 (ed. Martin Denton), His Minute Hand, Any May Now, Gluten!, and Memoriam. He has worked with such directors as Austin Pendleton (Three Sisters, Assistant Director) and Michael Grandage (Evita on Broadway, SDC Traube Fellow) as well as with The Royal Shakespeare Company, Classic Stage Company, and LAByrinth Theater Company. Stephen received his M.F.A. in directing from Brooklyn College and has taught theater, public speaking, and master classes on leadership and joy at Fordham, Brooklyn College, NYU, LIU Post, Yale, The Professional Performing Arts School, Talent Unlimited High School, and BMCC. stephenkaliski.com. uprightoutloud.com. adjustedrealists.com.

Elizabeth Ostler (Director) is a Brooklyn-based theater-maker, specializing in directing, puppetry and creativity coaching. She is the creator of Communal Theater, an ideological approach to creating theater rooted in the belief that theater should be a communion between the audience and the theater event. She is the founder and CEO of Life’s Echoes Creativity Coaching. Liz is the co-founder of the NYC Artist Group which offers professional development workshops and networking opportunities for NYC theater artists. She has been creating theater for over twenty years with various theaters in New York and Utah. Liz holds a MFA in theater directing from Brooklyn College and a BA in liberal arts from Sarah Lawrence College. www.elizabethostler.com.

CAST:

Alcestis: Ioanna Zafiropoulos 

Admetos: Jeremiah Maestas *

Heracles: Fito Alvarado

Amy: Katie Farrell 

Colin: Matt Mastromatteo

Bertram: Ben Bercot

Skylar: Bryce Crumlish

Death: Lizzie Thompson

God/Servant: Kenny Wang


*Member of Actors' Equity

Production Pending Equity Showcase Approval

story:
Kristiansand Sommerteater presenterer 

Eventyret om Snillanden!

Snillanden sitter på loftet sitt og kikker på alle fuglene som flyr forbi. Hun skulle gjerne ønske hun kunne fly sånn som de, men hun har aldri fått det til. Én dag får hun et flygeblad i fleisen, det er en reklame for flyskole i Florø! Hun legger ut på en reise mot Florø, og på veien møter hun blant annet Henrik Ibsen, Bjørnstjerne og mallen Kalle!


Hjelp oss å lage forestillingen!

VI jobber med å lage fantastisk teater for barn i Kristiansand og for at vi skal få til det trenger vi DIN hjelp!
Vi er allerede godt i gang med å lage forestillingen, og har prøvd ut Snillanden på scenen, i en fortellerforestilling på Barnas Vårslipp på Kjerlingland Gård i Lillesand, lørdag 28.05, og Klimafest på Grønt Senter 05.06.
Du kan gi oss et lite bidrag eller et stort -uansett går gaven uavkortet til materialer for å lage de mest fantastiske dukkene vi kan få til!
Som takk for hjelpen ønsker vi å gi noe tilbake til deg, i tillegg til å lage forestillingen. Sjekk ut alle de morsomme premiene du kan velge mellom og finn din favoritt!

story:
Feed us a story...

Ghost Card is a free outdoor performance event that fuses dance, theater and public art with the connective power of the Internet.  In the show, a voyeuristic gang of hungry ghosts feed on the stories of the living through an audience interactive, card-game-turned-performance. Enslaved to the rules of chance, these eight unruly ghosts and an obsessed card dealer relive true, crowdsourced tales through contemporary dance and a host of irreverent storytelling tactics.

We are collecting these "table stories" from the general public via our online story portal.  The show was inspired by Allen and Ellen Wexler’s public art sculpture Two Too Large Tables at Hudson River Park, upon which we will stage the world premiere of the work in August 2016, followed by a site-adaptive performance at Socrates Sculpture Park in September.  

Our source text is you.

The most important ingredient in Ghost Card is our audience.   You feed us the stories that comprise the text of the show.  Go ahead, click here and feed us a story!   Every time we bring the show to a new public space, we’ll collect new stories from the local community to weave into the production, creating a shape-shifting collage of human identity with each new site.  We map the stories to a 52-card deck of oversized playing cards, which the hungry ghosts use to play an interactive game that unleashes each story through dance, improvisation, spoken word and the laws of chance.  And if the Ghost Card is played... we might just ask you to feed us a story on the spot!

What We Need

This is a free public performance.  We're self-producing in a public park because we believe in creating demand for art through exposure and participation.   But at the same time, we all know that art is never free.  It costs a lot of time, money and creative output to produce this kind of work.  We need your help to make it happen.  Your contribution to our IndieGoGo campaign will fund:

  • Stipends ($3250).  We have hired some highly trained, super-skilled artists for this project, and they've generously agreed to share their talents for modest stipends because they love the work.  Help us pay our 9 luminous performers, 3 incredible designers, and our ridiculously creative production manager.  

  • Costumes ($750).  Our Hungry Ghosts may resort to desperate measures to get at your stories...but they draw the line at performing naked.  Help us put them in conceptually rad, movement-friendly costumes.

  • The Cards ($250). It’s hard to play a card game without cards. We have a gorgeous deck of oversized cards designed by Adam Wile that we need to print and mount.  (P.S. you can get copies of some of these beautiful cards as a perk for supporting this campaign!)

  • Web App ($150).  Ghost Card happens online as much as it does in person.  Our website needs hosting, and our awesome online story-collection gizmo actually comes with a subscription cost.   (Check out the website and feed us a story.  Already done it?  Feed us another!  We're insatiably hungry...)

  • Scenic Design ($300). Ghost Card will premiere at Two Too-Large Tables, but then it's going on the road.  In order to bring the work to public sites across the city and beyond, we need to buy the materials to create an abstracted, elegant, and easily portable scenic design that emulates the concept and quality of the Wexlers' original.

  • Crowd Control Ushers ($300).  We are performing in a nontraditional space at Hudson River Park, filled with passersby, park service vehicles and a busy bike path.   We need to hire crowd-control ushers for each performance to guide the audience toward safe areas.

What You Get

In thanks for your support, we have a fantastic selection of perks.   Shout-outs both virtual and literal, fireworks lit in your honor, a one-page theatrical ode by a FullStop playwright starring YOU,  custom playing cards featuring the designs of the show, dance lessons, a private wine reception with the creative team, a mighty creative services package and a limited-edition artist-signed proof by Allan Wexler...plus special SECRET PERKS that will be revealed throughout the campaign.  (Follow us on Facebook and our blog for the inside scoop on secret perks!)

The Impact

We all know how socially and spiritually isolating life in American society can be sometimes.  And we all know how rich our culture is with artists whose work is rendered invisible to the public because of economic and social barriers.  This project breaks down both of those realities with a free public offering that uses the community’s own stories as the primary narrative substance.  We believe that by reflecting the myriad inner worlds of a neighborhood’s members back to itself through performance, we can begin to dissolve some of the perceived and actual barriers that divide communities of strangers.

The piece is designed to be portable, reproducible, and neighborhood-specific, situated in public parks that are regular visiting points for locals, and comprised of stories supplied by the members of the surrounding community.  We hope to eventually present Ghost Card in public spaces all over New York City, and beyond!

Other Ways You Can Give

If you can't donate, or even if you can, here are some other ways you can show your support:

  • Visit our website and feed us a story!
  • Follow us on Facebook and our blog for updates on the show, as well as the inside scoop on secret IndieGoGo perks to be revealed throughout the campaign.
  • Share our campaign with your people on Facebook, Twitter or via email.
  • Come watch fireworks and drink wine with us at our 4th of July campaign finale celebration, and bring your friends!  Follow us on Facebook for details.
  • Most of all, come see the show!  August 3, 4 and 6 at dusk, Hudson River Park at 29th Street, and September 17 from 2-4PM at Socrates Sculpture Park.

Who we are

We are Megan Weaver and Hassan Christopher, artists, partners, and co-creators of Ghost Card. 

Megan is a director, teacher, and creator of hybrid theater that blends audience interactivity, digital media, mask, puppetry, live music and unconventional spaces.  She is the executive artistic director of FullStop Collective, an NYC performance group in its 9th year.  

Hassan is an award-winning choreographer and experimental performance artist with roots in contemporary dance, house and hip hop.  He is a passionate movement educator with nearly two decades of teaching experience.

Our Ghost Card performers are Alexander Bianchi, Yuki Fukui, Naomi King, Katrina Leung, Lorenzo Sariñana, Alexia Sky, Larissa Skye Van Rensselaer and Adam Wile.

Special thanks to Hudson River Park, Allan and Ellen Wexler, and FullStop Collective for their support of this project.

Ghost Card is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Ghost Card must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

The most important ingredient in Ghost Card is our audience.   You feed us the stories that comprise the text of the show.  Go ahead, click here and feed us a story!   Every time we bring the show to a new public space, we’ll collect new stories from the local community to weave into the production, creating a shape-shifting collage of human identity with each new site.  We map the stories to a 52-card deck of oversized playing cards, which the hungry ghosts use to play an interactive game that unleashes each story through dance, improvisation, spoken word and the laws of chance.  And if the Ghost Card is played... we might just ask you to feed us a story on the spot!

What We Need

This is a free public performance.  We're self-producing in a public park because we believe in creating demand for art through exposure and participation.   But at the same time, we all know that art is never free.  It costs a lot of time, money and creative output to produce this kind of work.  We need your help to make it happen.  Your contribution to our IndieGoGo campaign will fund:


Stipends ($3250).  We have hired some highly trained, super-skilled artists for this project, and they've generously agreed to share their talents for modest stipends because they love the work.  Help us pay our 9 luminous performers, 3 incredible designers, and our ridiculously creative production manager.  
Costumes ($750).  Our Hungry Ghosts may resort to desperate measures to get at your stories...but they draw the line at performing naked.  Help us put them in conceptually rad, movement-friendly costumes.
The Cards ($250). It’s hard to play a card game without cards. We have a gorgeous deck of oversized cards designed by Adam Wile that we need to print and mount.  (P.S. you can get copies of some of these beautiful cards as a perk for supporting this campaign!)
Web App ($150).  Ghost Card happens online as much as it does in person.  Our website needs hosting, and our awesome online story-collection gizmo actually comes with a subscription cost.   (Check out the website and feed us a story.  Already done it?  Feed us another!  We're insatiably hungry...)
Scenic Design ($300). Ghost Card will premiere at Two Too-Large Tables, but then it's going on the road.  In order to bring the work to public sites across the city and beyond, we need to buy the materials to create an abstracted, elegant, and easily portable scenic design that emulates the concept and quality of the Wexlers' original.
Crowd Control Ushers ($300).  We are performing in a nontraditional space at Hudson River Park, filled with passersby, park service vehicles and a busy bike path.   We need to hire crowd-control ushers for each performance to guide the audience toward safe areas.


   
What You Get
In thanks for your support, we have a fantastic selection of perks.   Shout-outs both virtual and literal, fireworks lit in your honor, a one-page theatrical ode by a FullStop playwright starring YOU,  custom playing cards featuring the designs of the show, dance lessons, a private wine reception with the creative team, a mighty creative services package and a limited-edition artist-signed proof by Allan Wexler...plus special SECRET PERKS that will be revealed throughout the campaign.  (Follow us on Facebook and our blog for the inside scoop on secret perks!)
The Impact 
We all know how socially and spiritually isolating life in American society can be sometimes.  And we all know how rich our culture is with artists whose work is rendered invisible to the public because of economic and social barriers.  This project breaks down both of those realities with a free public offering that uses the community’s own stories as the primary narrative substance.  We believe that by reflecting the myriad inner worlds of a neighborhood’s members back to itself through performance, we can begin to dissolve some of the perceived and actual barriers that divide communities of strangers.
The piece is designed to be portable, reproducible, and neighborhood-specific, situated in public parks that are regular visiting points for locals, and comprised of stories supplied by the members of the surrounding community.  We hope to eventually present Ghost Card in public spaces all over New York City, and beyond!

    Other Ways You Can Give If you can't donate, or even if you can, here are some other ways you can show your support:  Visit our website and feed us a story!
Follow us on Facebook and our blog for updates on the show, as well as the inside scoop on secret IndieGoGo perks to be revealed throughout the campaign. Share our campaign with your people on Facebook, Twitter or via email.
Come watch fireworks and drink wine with us at our 4th of July campaign finale celebration, and bring your friends!  Follow us on Facebook for details.

Most of all, come see the show!  August 3, 4 and 6 at dusk, Hudson River Park at 29th Street, and September 17 from 2-4PM at Socrates Sculpture Park.



Who we are
We are Megan Weaver and Hassan Christopher, artists, partners, and co-creators of Ghost Card. 
Megan is a director, teacher, and creator of hybrid theater that blends audience interactivity, digital media, mask, puppetry, live music and unconventional spaces.  She is the executive artistic director of FullStop Collective, an NYC performance group in its 9th year.  
Hassan is an award-winning choreographer and experimental performance artist with roots in contemporary dance, house and hip hop.  He is a passionate movement educator with nearly two decades of teaching experience.
Our Ghost Card performers are Alexander Bianchi, Yuki Fukui, Naomi King, Katrina Leung, Lorenzo Sariñana, Alexia Sky, Larissa Skye Van Rensselaer and Adam Wile.

Special thanks to Hudson River Park, Allan and Ellen Wexler, and FullStop Collective for their support of this project.
Ghost Card is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Ghost Card must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
I am delighted to be developing this new play at The Unicorn later this year with support from Improbable and Arts Council, England.

I needed to raise £550 to secure the Arts Council Funding and I am honoured, surprised and so grateful for the kindness and generosity of those who have donated and helped me reach that target.

The current situation for funding d/Deaf and disabled access is shaky to say the least, and any money over and above the £550 target will be put towards funding rehearsal room Sign Language Interpreter/s on this R&D phase and towards access costs for the full production next year.

'The Girl Who Followed Her Dream' will be a mixed English/ BSL play for hearing and d/Deaf family audiences, children and grown ups and all in between!

story:
Hey There, Hi, and Hello!

Hello, cyberspace! My name is Jacob Clark Boggs and I am one the the founders of Customary Radicals Productions! We are a New York City based production company with a passion for creating art dedicated to disrupting preconceptions and bridging the gaps in human connection. Through collaborative efforts and unorthodox creativity, we aim to present simple and unanimous experiences in the lives of human beings through individually accentuated perspectives- highlighting the experiences shared by fellow man.

WOW! That was formal! 

At our core, we are a group of creative friends that set out on a goal: to produce a unique piece of indie theater all on our own! I am very proud to say that we're well on our way to that goal with our production of Old Haunts, an original play by Emily Simon.  Emily has written a wonderful coming-of-age story about a  college student,  Mark Robbins, who returns back to his hometown of Boulder, Colorado after a semester spent away at Columbia University. Upon his return, Mark finds himself brutally confronted by the relationships he left wearily behind, and haunted by the uncertainty of what his future holds. Told through non-linear plot lines and vivid glimpses into Mark's spiraling imagination, Old Haunts provides an adventurous and unyielding take on what it's like to revisit your old stomping ground. 

While this project was born of sheer optimism and unrivaled passion, there remained a shred of fear that perhaps no one else would be interested in what we had to offer. After all, we were solving tech problems with duct tape and bailing wire. Making costumes out of old socks and tablecloths. Staging rehearsals in our living rooms. Resources were scarce, but our spirits remained high. And we are elated to say that The New York International Fringe Festival believed in our project as much as we do! We have the incredible opportunity to bring Old Haunts to life this August with one of New York's most exciting and prestigious festivals for indie-theater! 

Now it's time to get started! The cast has been chosen, the crew established, and the venue set! All we need now is your help! And LOTS of work!


What We Need & What You Get

With any theater project, there are a lot of expenses. And while scarcity breeds creativity (we hope), certain costs simply cannot be avoided without sacrificing the fidelity of the show or mistreating the wonderful people of the cast and crew.

Rehearsal Space: This is the largest expense we face in doing this project! Old Haunts has a number of complex dance numbers and intricately choreographed scenes that require large studio spaces to create. The cost of studio space in Manhattan for the remainder of our rehearsal period is $2500.00.

Props & Costumes: The name of the game for our Fringe NYC production is simplification!  However, certain major costume pieces need to be designed and created which entails hiring a little help from a friend in the costume design business. In addition, props help us fully enter into the warped world of Mark's imagination, and over time, the cost adds up. 
Furthermore, to be compliant with Fringe NYC requirements, we must make some adjustments to certain props- in particular stage cigarettes and lighters.  We estimate the total cost of the costumes and props to be $1,000.00

Cargo Van: Another expense we will incur for the Fringe NYC production is the rental of a cargo van.  We will be staging a number of performances of 'Old Haunts' throughout the two week festival, and it is a requirement that we strike our set completely after each show.  That means we're carrying the entire set of our show with us. Therefore, we need to rent a cargo van to house these items for the duration of the festival to keep them readily available for each of our performances. The cost of the cargo van rental is $500.00.

Insurance:  We must purchase accident/injury insurance for our cast and crew for our Fringe NYC production.  The cost of this insurance is $300.00.

Compensation:  We estimate the compensation for the cast and crew to be $2,000.00.

Printing:  The estimated cost of printing our Playbills is $100.00

Incidentals:  Every production is met with last minute incidental expenses.  We anticipate our production to be no different.  We're hoping to set aside an additional $400.00 to cover any incidental expenses as they occur.  

Customary Radicals is a fledgling production company with modest means. However, we would like to show our appreciation for any donation you can make. Please check out the 'Perks' section for a list of ways we can give some love back!

In the event we are not able to raise enough funds to fully cover our expenses, any monies raised will go first toward the cost of the insurance for our cast and crew and then toward the rehearsal space as these are our primary concerns.

In the event we surpass our goal, all extra funds will go toward future Customary Radicals productions.


The Impact

Your contribution will allow our production to be manifested at its fullest potential.  Old Haunts is a play with a huge heart and a strong message. With your help, it can be a voice for thousands of people who have experienced similar hardships and heartbreaks. It can be a rally cry for those who could never find the words. It can be a home for those who thought they were alone. 
I can't emphasize enough the amount of love and passion that Customary Radicals has brought to this production. It is because we have a message that we believe in. And we want to share our story with you.  


Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge is actually our biggest achievement.  We are a brand new production company of young artists with vision.  Old Haunts is our very first project and we were immediately recognized by Fringe NYC for our potential.  We are honored and thrilled by this opportunity.  However, because we are just taking our first baby steps as a company, and this is our very first project, we have not had the time to generate the revenue needed to catapult us to the mainstage opportunity Fringe NYC is providing for us.  
We have the play, the cast, the heart, and the motivation.  Fringe NYC is providing the venue.  We simply need the funds to bring our vision to the kind of audience available to us through the New York International Fringe Festival and beyond.


Other Ways You Can Help

We know that for some, a monetary contribution may not be possible.  And yet, there is still a way you can help our efforts.  Simply, tell your friends and family about our play and share our campaign via Facebook, Twitter, email and other social media platforms.  The power of the internet is unstoppable!

story:
The Company

cold.dead.fish is a new independent theatre company comprised of Jessica Peverett and Kyle Lewis. To find out a little bit about us as individuals check out our bios below. Together, we're interested in creating visually stimulating, emotionally challenging, intellectually engaging theatre. Right now we're working on The Miranda Project, a brand new play that will be premiering at the 2011 Edmonton International Fringe Festival. Though we've worked together before, this is the first official project as cold.dead.fish. We can't wait to share it with you. 


Here's a little bit about the show!

Miranda's been locked in the cellar. She finds a light bulb, a bath tub and a stack of books that multiply. Days bleed into weeks and weeks seem like days. She waits patiently. She waits obediently. But when do you give up waiting for love? 


Here's a little bit about us! 


Kyle Lewis: I've been directing for the past 15 years but if I had to label myself I'd be lost. I've got an MFA in directing from Arizona State University and I am a member of Actors' Equity Association, but I've done a little bit of everything including acting, designing and construction. To date I have at least 100 productions under my belt...but none have engaged me like this one. Whether you attend this production or give your online support (maybe even both?) I guarantee that you will be participating in an incredible theatrical event. And my favorite dessert is Guinness. 


Jessica Peverett: I've done all kinds of gigs but primarily I'm an actor, director, playwright and dramaturge based in Edmonton. I just recently graduated from the University of Alberta's Master of Arts program where I spent two years living and breathing theatre. Academia all day and then rehearsals / working at a local theatre at night. This spring, my script Pushed was produced by the Nextfest Arts Company. The production received rave reviews from CBC and Vue Weekly (5 stars) and has been tentatively slated for production again next winter. This will be the first time that I perform something that I've written and I'm so excited to share that with you. And my favorite thing in the world is an iced coffee beverage. 



CHECK OUT THE UPDATES SECTION FOR COOL TIDBITS LIKE where did you get the idea for the show? can I watch a rehearsal? when and where does the play happen? where's the best place to get a beer at fringe? who makes the best deep fried chocolate bar on site? what's with that weird clown guy near second cup who won't leave me alone?


Why is the Edmonton Fringe Festival so amazing?

The Edmonton Fringe is the second largest Fringe festival in the world where 41 venues house over 1500 performances. Last year over 192,000 tickets were sold and they estimate that nearly half a million people came out to visit the Fringe site. 

The Edmonton Fringe is unique because it runs on a lottery system. So that means, in October of 2010, we submitted an application for a spot in one of those 41 venues and then names were picked from a jar. Literally! A Jar! We were lucky enough to be selected and we've been working on the piece ever since.


How can you help out The Miranda Project?

The Edmonton Fringe is a fabulous tool for independent artists to get out and produce new works. But with a great opportunity comes some financial snags. We're responsible for paying all the bills. To apply for the festival, companies are required to pay $635.00 CAD. This gets us a venue, a professional technician, ticket services and very limited promotion. From there, we have to pay for our set, our costumes, our props, our rehearsal space and the rest of our marketing materials (posters, handbills, etc). All this has to be paid off before we can think about paying our actors. 


It's really important to us that we be able to compensate the people who throw themselves into this project and there are no guarantees at Fringe!


So here's what we're trying to subsidize before we get to the festival:


1. The $635.00 application fee

2. $100 for promotional materials (if no one knows about our shows, then we certainly won't make any money through ticket sales!)


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're in the Edmonton area during the Fringe (August 11-21) come check out the show! 

TICKETS ARE $10 and can be purchased through the Fringe Box Office or at the door (Walterdale Playhouse 10322 83 Avenue)

SHOW TIMES:

August 12 10:00 pm – 10:55 pm
August 14 6:15 pm – 7:10 pm
August 15 12:30 pm – 1:25 pm
August 17 2:30 pm – 3:25 pm
August 18 4:30 pm – 5:25 pm
August 20 8:15 pm – 9:10 pm


Check out our Facebook Event (The Miranda Project - Edmonton Fringe 2011) for more details. 


We'd love it if you could pass on this awesome site to anyone and everyone who might be interested! 


Every dollar counts and we're so grateful for your support.

story:
From the creative minds that brought you End of Line Club:
The Merchants of Deva are proud to present Milk+Bar at Norwescon 35.
This year we are bringing you our steamworks take on Stanley Kubrick's classic "A Clockwork Orange".
Enter into the Deva Milk+Bar and enjoy our classic drinks as well as the new Moloko Deva.
Fall further into the Ludovico Dance Chamber for some sensory overload courtesy of dj.spacemonkey--aversion to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony is optional.

In order to create this one-of-a-kind experience, we will need your help.
Your tax-deductible contribution will enable us to rent the suite, pay for food and beverages, and set up the space to impress all of our guests as we've never done before.

If you love the Merchants parties at Norwescon -- or even if you've never heard of us before, but are just interested in having a good time -- then help make this happen. The biggest thrill for us in doing these parties all these years has been getting to watch all of you have a great time, and knowing that we made that happen for you. We want to share that feeling with you -- watching a few hundred of your fellow geeks having a night they'll never forget because of you feels amazing, and we can't wait to show you what that's like.

So put on your bowler hat, gather up your droogs, and together we'll make it a night you'll never forget.

story:
Village Playwrights Story

The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS was founded out of the need of Lesbian and Gay writers to have a venue in which they could present their works without fear of being harshly criticized or dismissed because of their sexual orientation or gender identification.   The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS meet at the LGBT Center in New York on the 2nd and 4th Wednesdays of each month and welcome all Playwrights, Screenwriters, Directors and Actors to participate in their programs.  The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS take pride in critiquing works solely on their merit and not on their sometimes sensitive subject matter. This allows each writer to find his or her voice as a creative individual.  To speak freely is to be empowered.

What We Do

Twice a month we hold readings of plays. We help with the casting of plays and the readings are followed by a critique of the works by the  writers’ peers which is an invaluable aid for the writer. We encourage writers to take their scripts off the shelves and out of the drawers and allow them the opportunity to hear their works performed by trained actors. Some writers choose to have their works read as they are working on them, scene by scene; others prefer to hear their works read when they are completed.

 

Three times a year we sponsor An Evening of Short Plays in a theater that we rent in order to give the writers the further opportunity of participating in the production of their plays that have been workshopped at our meetings.   Putting a play before an audience is the best method for learning how to write well.

 

Many of our writers have gone on to have had their works presented by many local organizations such as the FRESH FRUIT FESTIVAL, the SAMUEL FRENCH OFF-OFF BROADWAY FESTIVAL and THE THEATRE FOR THE NEW CITY.

What We Need

We are seeking $2000--$1000 to apply for non profit status and $1000 to subsidize the expense of renting rehearsal space.   


Producing a play can be a thrilling experience as well as a very costly one.  In New York,  rehearsal space for a 90 minute show costs a minimum of $1500.  This is always a huge problem for our writers.  Often a fine work by a talented writer can not be presented for want of money.  We would like to offer financial help to deserving writers who are unable to finance their own productions.

 

We need seed money to establish non profit status for the VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS so that we would be able to approach Corporations, Foundations and Individuals for funding for our activities.   As a non profit organization we would be able to approach owners of space who would benefit from our status.

 

Since 1985, The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS have been actively involved in helping writers in their endeavors and we are deeply committed to continuing this valuable enterprise. We would gratefully appreciate your support. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Donate your loft space or unused space for rehearsals.
story_txt:
Village Playwrights Story

The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS was founded out of the need of Lesbian and Gay writers to have a venue in which they could present their works without fear of being harshly criticized or dismissed because of their sexual orientation or gender identification.   The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS meet at the LGBT Center in New York on the 2nd and 4th Wednesdays of each month and welcome all Playwrights, Screenwriters, Directors and Actors to participate in their programs.  The VILLAGE PLAYWRIGHTS take pride in critiquing works solely on their merit and not on their sometimes sensitive subject matter. This allows each writer to find his or her voice as a creative individual.  To speak freely is to be empowered. 
What We Do

Twice a month we hold readings of plays. We help with the casting of plays and the readings are followed by a critique of the works by the  writers’ peers which is an invaluable aid for the writer. Many of our writers have gone on to have had their works presented by many local organizations such as the FRESH FRUIT FESTIVAL, the SAMUEL FRENCH OFF-OFF BROADWAY FESTIVAL and THE THEATRE FOR THE NEW CITY.

story:
Back in 2015 I started this company in the hopes of bringing something a little different to city. That December we did our first show Eve of St George, and that is what we are Remounting in January. 

 

Eve of St George is a voyeuristic and immersive recreation of one of our most chilling tales. The Audience is greeted, masked and set free to roam four levels of the historic great hall. Its a choose your own adventure kind of show where each guests experience is different from the next.  

 

The plan for this show was to approach it in stages. 2015 was our trial run and luckily proved to be extremely successful. With incredible feedback and audience loving their experience it really pushed me to continue as planned and bring this show back, this time for a little bit longer, and on a slightly larger scale.

 

To do a show of this magnitude and complexity involves a large team, and a large team requires a large budget.

Main budget costs are:

16 dancers pay

Building rental for rehearsals, tech runs, show days

Set and Lighting designers

Props/ Set

PR team/ Marketing

Costumes

These are only the main costs!!! This funding goal only covers about 15% of our full production.

 

Needless to say this is a daunting task to take on financially and this is where we ask for your help. I now know this show is something this city craves and i’m really interested in creating experiences that everyone even you non arts goer can enjoy. Any donation is a help, We thank you for all your support and we hope to see you in January! 

TICKETS AVAILABLE AT:

https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/eve-of-st-george-ti...

story:
Engel the Elder's BARD, BEAT$, & BURLESQUE!!! at Santa Cruz Fringe Festival (presented by The Sixty Grit Theater Co)
Reviewed by Paula Love
July 18, 2013

"...I was rewarded with a fresh, whimsical take on ... Shakespeare."

I am a huge fan of the Santa Cruz Fringe festival. What I love most about it is the wide spectrum of performance one can sample in a short period of time.In my search for the offbeat and unique, I found myself attending Bard, Beat$ and Burlesque at the Tannery World Dance and Cultural Center.

I came into this show not knowing what to expect and for my intrepid curiosity I was rewarded with a fresh, whimsical take on the poetry and prose of the man we know as William Shakespeare .

We are introduced to Engel the elder who is reportedly 10,000 years old as he is interviewed by radio personality Buck Wild. Engel, played to delightful comic effect by actor Greg Paroff, knew Shakespeare as a boy and mentored him. He claims Shakespeare did not write any of his plays, but that they were written by a Big White Bunny Rabbit.

He tells us many fanciful tales from his long and illustrious life and we are treated to some of Shakespeare's sonnets. At some point we are introduced to the delightful Valentina the Ballerina as Engel reads to her Romeo & Juliet, and we learn the true meaning of the story of the lovers is to learn to count (you have to see this part to understand). Also, what must be seen - as it is a true delight - is a charming burlesque performance performed, en pointe, by Valentina.

I don't want to give the whole show away, but I will say Shakespeare is given a modern twist. Paroff wins the audience over with a Hip Hop/Rap rendition of the Bards' work.

So, do yourself a favor. Catch this show at the tannery! 

Engel the Elder's BARD, BEAT$ & BURLESQUE premiers at the 2013 Santa Cruz Fringe Festival on Saturday, July 13 (3:30 p.m.); Thursday, July 18 (7:30 p.m.); Friday, July 19 (10:00 p.m.) and Saturday, July 20 (2:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m.) at the Tannery Dance and World Culture Center. For more info, go to: http://santacruzfringefestival.com/index.php/ti... 

Engel the Elder is my alter ego--and we two have been building up to this show/performance-piece for several years. Engel means "angel" in German, and his development began when I lived in New York and met an elderly and wise character actor who mentored me and became my angel.

Since 2009, I've appeared as Engel annually at The Carolina Renaissance Festival where I've performed magic, swallowed fire, and recited from Shakespeare, often with Bathos the Muse (the stage name of guitarist Eddie Jeff Cahill), for the thousands of people visiting Fairhaven Village each October & November. I've been nominated twice by the Metrolina Theater Association (Charlotte Metro Area) for appearing as Engel in the part of "Henry, The Old Actor" in two separate productions of The Fantasticks and, in the same role, I won Best Character Actor from the Uwharrie Players for their 2012 production of The Fantasticks.

I've written and had published award-winning stories, poems and plays; recorded spoken and musical CDs; appeared in films and on radio and tv--all as Engel the Elder (aka Engel Meister). I've also created signature images of Shakespeare using the name Shaxpere. Last year, on a shoestring budget, I brought my first Engel the Elder show, Engel the Elder's SHAXPERE AFTER MIDNIGHT, to the 2012 Santa Cruz Fringe.

To improve and professionally produce the Santa Cruz show, I humbly ask for your participation in funding this production.  Of course, as my "angels," you will not only be contributing to this production, but to the continued development and success of Engel, and what I hope will become a well-loved and well-known character. And, of course, you will receive the really cool perks described to the right.

What We Need & What You Get

The goal is to raise at least $600--which is only 40% of the production costs for the 2013 Santa Cruz Fringe. The show is a 50-minute salute to everything Shakespeare. The main challenge of putting up this show is raising the money for things like transportation, advertising, props and crew. The next biggest challenge is getting the word out so that people buy tickets and come to the show. Your support of this project will help make this and future show possible!

I thank you for taking your time to consider this project. Any level of help is greatly appreciated. If you can be in Santa Cruz on the performance dates, I hope I'll see you there.  And if you can't be at these performances, I look forward to performing for you soon.

As Shakespeare wrote: "The play's the thing....."

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you contribute to the production costs (and receive a perk(s) and my eternal thanks), you can also help by copying and sharing https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/engel-the-elder-s-bard-beat-burlesque-at-santa-cruz-fringe--2/set_up on your Facebook page or any other social media you use. You can also go to Engel's or Greg's Facebook page and share from there or send your own e-mail to your friends with a link to this page.

Thanks for anything you do to help and get the word out.  And if you're in Santa Cruz, July 11-20, be sure to enjoy the 2013 Santa Cruz Fringe and all it has to offer.

story:
Half Straddle is proud to present In the Pony Palace / FOOTBALL in co-production with The Bushwick Starr, February 10 - 26, 2011. PONY UP for Half Straddle and help lead the team to victory!


About our upcoming show In the Pony Palace / FOOTBALL

The show takes the language, aesthetics, and dynamics of high school football and frame it within a musically-enhanced performance where girls play football in full pads, cheerleaders still might rule and being on the bus after the game feels like the most amazing moment ever.

Written + Directed by Tina Satter. Music arranged by Chris Giarmo + Bobby McElver.

In the Pony Palace / FOOTBALL features:

- Real football plays onstage !

- Lady Gaga &  Rolling Stones mash-up played live by the Pony Palace marching band led by Bobby McElver !

- Moe Angelos, Jess Barbagallo, Eliza Bent, Nikki Calonge, Emily Davis, Erin Markey, Glennis McMurray, Kourtney Rutherford & Julia Sirna-Frest as your players, cheerleaders and coaches !

Why You Should Pony Up

This marks Half Straddle’s first official attempt to fundraise in a sane and organized manner. After three years of making shows on shoe-string budgets stained with blood, sweat and tears, we can’t do it alone—and hope you’ll help us continue to make transcendent amazingness. We promise your soul will sparkle when you pony up.

About Half Straddle

HALF STRADDLE makes plays, performances, music and videos under the artistic direction of Tina Satter and the musical direction of Chris Giarmo.

Since 2008, the ensemble has presented three full-length shows in New York City: Nurses in New England (Ice Factory, 2010), FAMILY (Ontological-Hysteric, 2009, Top Ten of Time Out New York’s 2009), and The Knockout Blow (HERE Arts Center, Ontological-Hysteric, 2008/2009)—as well as a number of smaller works such as Sliding Whores (a episodic live British dramedy) and Girl Detective Agency (with real 9-year old girls!).

The ensemble includes Jess Barbagallo, Eliza Bent, Emily Davis, Julia Sirna-Frest, lighting designer Zack Tinkelman and production manager Nathan Lemoine. Awesome performers such as Erin Markey, Annie McNamara, Joseph Keckler, Lena Moy-Borgen, Katherine Scharhon, Greg Zuccolo and others have joined Half Straddle in making their work.

Our Work

Half Straddle creates what a very smart person once said was what “David Lynch would make if he was a 12-year old girl.”  That’s pretty correct—and speaks to our interest in performatively exploring the unexpected edges, a total embrace of entertainment value, and creating roles and shows that consider the weirdness, disappointments, and amazingness of dynamics that don’t revolve around standard narrative set-ups. With original text and music.

Here's what people are saying ...

“Satter re-imagines experimental theater with a post-postmodern/girl-group/punk aesthetic. She adds feminist perspective, gay pride, biting commentary… and lots of sequins and sass.” –nytheatre.com

Nurses in New England
“I saw this show last week and it was so great - and I don't know if you saw it? Nurses of New England? It was by that Half Straddle company. It was WONDERFUL. Totally, geniusly ridiculous, with song numbers and a live band and an amazing but simple set. … It was perfectly executed and ultra precise, and the perfs were so good – it was one of those shows where you can just relax because you know no one's trying to pull anything over on you. None of them gives a flying f, yet they've worked really hard and have still managed to not give a flying f.” – Sibyl Kempson

FAMILY
• Named a Top 10 Show of 2009 by Time Out New York
• “Ridiculous and enchanting musical Family... full to the brim with killer talent.”—Helen Shaw, TIME OUT NEW YORK
• “Family re-invents downtown experimental theater for the new millennium—and has a
tremendous lot of fun doing it.”—Heather J. Violanti, NYTHEATRE.COM

The Knockout Blow
• “Satter pair babes in off-the-shoulder lamé with winky, wistful dialogue and sets it all to Chris Giarmo’s synthesizer-mad, '80s-esque avant-ballads. A well-put-together production, I almost felt, would have ruined the girls-playing-dress-up vibe.”—Helen Shaw, TIME OUT NEW YORK
• “That Eskimo, werewolf and backup dancer know how to knock those songs out of the park”—George Hunka, SUPERFLUITIES REDUX

story: After seeing much of the world, I would like to share what I've learned through dance with an emphasis on what unites us as a people.
story_txt: After seeing much of the world, I would like to share what I've learned through dance with an emphasis on what unites us as a people.

story:
You've found us!

We are Tremor Theatre Collective. We are a group of performing artists with the common belief in theatre as a space apart, a sublime meeting place where we can all break with reality, and become aware of the simplest iterations of humanity. By extracting those essential moments, those actions and behaviors that reveal us to be human, we weave together new stories, new rules, new realities. We want to take on the challenge it is to create a truly transcendent theatrical experience. Check us out in more detail here: tremorcollective.tumblr.com


Something's afoot...

A play! An experience! An adventure! Our inaugural production as a collective will be THE RUB, a site-specific original work, conceived and directed by Nessa Norich, an alumna of Barnard College's theatre program and Jacques Lecoq International School of Theatre. Using Shakespeare's Hamlet as a point of departure, THE RUB is a surreal and playful investigation of the frustration, anxiety, passion, complacency, self-doubt, delusion, isolation and desire that come with being heirs to a state rotting from the inside out. Hamlet's in the thick of it, we're in the thick of it, you're in the thick of it--we're all freaking out about it, so let's do it together!

THE RUB will take place in the sprawling Magic Future Box, a warehouse off the beaten path, in Brooklyn, NY. We promise you this will be a unique diversion!


SAVE THE DATE:

FEBRUARY 10-12th @ 8PM

MAGIC FUTUREBOX

55 33RD STREET

4 FL

BROOKLYN, NY

N,R,D TRAIN TO 36TH STREET


ATTENTION DONORS!

IF YOU MAKE A DONATION ABOVE $10 AND PLAN ON SEEING THE SHOW, PLEASE EMAIL tremorcollective@gmail.com to CLAIM YOUR TICKETS!! No need to claim the perk. Thank you! ***************


But there are some things we need...

Like props and costumes, insurance, lights and sounds, and space! With your help to get these things, we can offer in return: our warmest gratitude, some sweet sweet perks (check out that sidebar), and most importantly, a show that we will present with the utmost generosity and pleasure-- which we hope will be experienced by you with as much satisfaction.


So spread the word!

We appreciate any and all support, and a huge way you can help us is by getting the word out about this project. So, use IndieGoGo's awesome share buttons, tweet about us, talk about us at parties, shout about us from the rooftops. Follow us at tremorcollective.tumblr.com for updates about the project and the collective, and look out for news of our upcoming launch party (for those of you in NYC)! 


Tremor maintains that making theatre and making communities go hand in hand, and we want you to know that you are an integral part of our family. Thank you!

Like props and costumes, insurance, lights and sounds, and space! With your help to get these things, we can offer in return: our warmest gratitude, some sweet sweet perks (check out that sidebar), and most importantly, a show that we will present with the utmost generosity and pleasure-- which we hope will be experienced by you with as much satisfaction.


So spread the word!
We appreciate any and all support, and a huge way you can help us is by getting the word out about this project. So, use IndieGoGo's awesome share buttons, tweet about us, talk about us at parties, shout about us from the rooftops. Follow us at tremorcollective.tumblr.com for updates about the project and the collective, and look out for news of our upcoming launch party (for those of you in NYC)! 

Tremor maintains that making theatre and making communities go hand in hand, and we want you to know that you are an integral part of our family. Thank you!

story:
Dear Friends and Family of Pirate Sugar,

Ahoy! We have had a fantastic start to 2012! We have been working hard at putting on multiple shows a month, and we are thrilled to let you all know we've been accepted to a number of Sketch festivals! We are going to Montreal Sketch Festival at the end of May, and we were also invited to the Chicago Women's Funny Festival to perform in June!

Getting a large group of hilarious women all over North America is hard work, and we are throwing a benefit show next week in Brooklyn to help us pay for our travel expenses. We're inviting lots of other women to join us doing stand up, improv, and even silly music! It will be a blast and we'll use the donations to help us in our travels.

If you can't make it to our Brooklyn show, fear not! You can still help us reach our comedic travel goals! If you would like to donate anything at all to help us, please do so here! If you know anyone else who would like to help us reach our destinations, please forward this message on!

Thanks for all your love and support! Aaaaaarrrrrr!
The Pirates 
- - Ann Marie, Cat, Delilah, Janet, Jess Ann, Katie, Lauren, and Sam - -

 

Pirate Sugar is 8 feisty fearless ladies that constantly wreak havoc in NYC with their sharp-edged swash-buckling sketch comedy.  Pirate Sugar wildly comments on everything from relationships to politics to flatulence.  Men, women, and everyone in between will agree that Pirate Sugar is a raucous good time!

Pirate Sugar formed in February 2011 and has been performing a veritable potpourri of musical, character, topical, and observation sketches ever since.  Pirate Sugar booked a regular monthly slot at the Tank (http://www.thetanknyc.org/) in November of 2011.  They have also performed at NYC venues: The Producer's Club, Under St. Marks, The Magnet Theater, The PIT, UCBeast, Theater 54, and The Nuyorican.  

Pirate Sugar has been selected to perform at the Montreal Sketch Festival this May and the Chicago Women's Funny Festival in June.

story:
Our Story

American fairy tales and rural paganism, witches and big foot, aerialists and giant puppets, not to mention an on-stage country rock band...  We knew from the start that we wanted to take these elements and create a spectacle that would enchant kids and adults alike.  Inspired by the massive beauty of the Alps and an international community of kids,  we began writing Devil in the Hole while teaching Shakespeare at a summer camp in Lugano, Switzerland.  We fell in love with our lead character, Copperhead Jabe, a wandering musician who battles demons, schemers, witches and curses with the magic of his hawthorn wood guitar.  Arriving back in NYC, we quickly teamed up with director, Jen Wineman, dramaturg, Krista Williams and producer, Nick Micozzi in order to make this dream of a show into a reality.    Now, our first performance experiment with this brand new musical in development is nearing.  Devil in the Hole is being hosted at Dixon Place on December 17th for a special one night workshop presentation. 


The Impact

Through the exchange of personal stories across generations, cultures and artistic vocabularies, Devil in the Hole can foster a new understanding of our American mythology.   We hope to open conversations about why we tell stories and how, like Copperhead Jabe, we can fight the ï¿½forces of evilï¿½ in our lives when we believe in the power of our shared histories. 


What We Need & What You Get

Devil in the Hole needs to be shown to kids and adults alike throughout its development.  We need feedback to imagine richer stories, create a more engaging soundscape and stretch towards greater physical and visual wonders.   Your contribution towards our $2000 goal will make it possible for us to continue working on this powerful piece and find new opportunities to share it with a larger community.   We need funding to rent aerial friendly rehearsal space, develop non-traditional riggings and aerial apparatuses, and purchase materials to create costumes, hand made instruments and puppets in order to make the most powerful magic for our audience.  

Other Ways to Help

Like us on Facebook.  Follow us on Twitter. Join us on December 17th at Dixon Place!
