story:
Short Summary

Just turning 50, Marie-France Levesque returns to the stage and on pointe after a serious car accident stopped her dance career 14 years ago. This inspiring and motivational ballet, contemporary & music performance is sure to surprise, delight, and empower people of all ages to believe they can reinvent their lives and careers, overcome adversity and pursue their dreams and passions even after 50 and keep everyone "on pointe" with themselves in their lives. 

It will be an inspiring evening of stunning world-class dance and music. From sensual pas-de-deux, tango and salsa to neo-classical and contemporary pieces, experience dance that will move you! Featuring grammy-nominated composer and latin piano virtuoso, Freddie Ravel and Opera Singer and "Ms. Senior America & California 2012", Elisabeth Howard and the exciting dancers of THE LOS ANGELES DANCE COMPANY.

The performance will premiere at the Scherr Forum Theatre at the Thousand Oaks Civic Arts Plaza in Los Angeles, CA at 7:30 pm on November 2, 2013. We plan on a Southern California tour for the 2014 season. Please visit  our website for more info: www.TheLADC.com

What We Need & What You Get

Althought it is an ambitious production involving the hard work of a team of 25 people, we have managed to set a budget of $70,000. This has been possible thanks to the selfless generosity of our team. Our ticket prices are very reasonable (only $35 and $47), and our audience size is 400 seats.

For this performance ”On Pointe at 50, and beyond!..., we've already raised a part of the funds. We need your help and your support to cover the rest of the production expenses, including scenery, wardrobe, props, studio & theater rentals and performers & choreographer's fees.

With deep gratitude, we thank you in advance for your kind generosity!

Los Angeles Choreographers & Dancers 

is our Fiscal Sponsor

Your donation is tax–deductible through L.A. Choreographers & Dancer’s non-profit  501 (c)(3) status Federal Tax Identification #95-3509028. Please contact your professional tax advisor regarding the percentage of tax deduction applicable which you are entitled with your donation.

PERKS:

Gift: $15-$49

·      Mention on donor page in performance program

·      Personal thank you mention on our Face book page

Benefactor: $50-$150

·      Mention on donor page in performance program & on the website

·      Personal thank you mention on our Face book page

·      One autographed picture

Supporter: $150-$500

·      Mention on donor page in performance program & on the website

·      Personal thank you mention on our Face book page

·      1  ticket to the performance

Friend: $500-$1,000

·      Mention on donor page in performance program & on the website

·      2  tickets to the performance

·      Meet the artists and get one autographed picture

    Emerald Sponsor: $1,500

·      Mention on donor page in performance program & on the website

·      2 VIP tickets to the performance

·      2 VIP post-performance champagne reception tickets

·      Greet the artists and get one autographed picture

   Bronze Sponsor: $2,500

·      One quarter-page in the program book

·      Mention on donor page in performance program & on the website

·      4 VIP tickets to the performance

·      4 VIP post-performance champagne reception tickets

·      Greet the artists and get one autographed picture

Special Angel: $2,501-$4,999

Support your favorite artist by donating his full performance fee. Inquire with us for all details. Minimum donation: $2,500

·      Mention on donor page in performance program & on the website

·      4 VIP tickets to the performance

·      4 VIP post-performance champagne reception tickets

·      Greet the artists and get one autographed picture   

   Silver Sponsor: $5,000

·      One half-page in the program book

·      Mention on donor page in performance program & on the website

·      6 VIP tickets to the performance

·      6 VIP post-performance champagne reception tickets

·      Greet the artists and get one autographed picture

   Gold Sponsor: $10,000

·      Name and Logo mentions on all printed materials

o   poster, brochures, advertisements

·      Logo and hyperlike on The Los Angeles Dance Company website

·      Mention on all The Los Angeles Dance Company’s social media pages

o   Facebook, Twitter, Linkedin, Utube, Pinterest and Google Book

·      Special mention in all press materials

·      Logo presence on performance dvd

·      Special pre-performance acknowledgement from the stage

·      Mention on donor page in performance program & on the website

·      8 VIP tickets to the performance

·      8 VIP post-performance champagne reception tickets

·      Special VIP Backstage tour, meet & greet the artists

·      Special private viewing of three rehearsals

·      Autograph pictures of all participating performers

The Impact

At a time when millions of Americans are seeking to reinvent and recover from one of the worst economic times in our country's history, this production will bring the fervently needed desire to inspire, uplift and motivate our audiences to renew, revive, and rebuild themselves with passion once again. Mrs. Levesque hopes to share this very significant moment in her career, when she feels restored, revitalized, and has developed a new sense of self-respect, with audiences young and old.

Other Ways You Can Help

- You can also help by Sponsoring in kind by offering products or food or wines for our post-performance reception if you own a shop or a restaurant. You need to call the office for product approval first at 310-308-2471.

- You can also help by purchasing advertising online on our website or in our program book. Visit:  http://theladc.com/advertise/

story:
Spartan Theatre Company regretfully announces it is no longer involved in our previously announced production of "Gunpowder". We wish nothing but the best for the production and those involved. As a result, we advise that no one donate to this current IndieGoGo fundraiser as any funds received will not go towards the production of "Gunpowder" and will instead be refunded to the contributor upon the completion of this campaign as according to IndieGoGo rules and guidelines.

If you wish to donate to this production please follow the link: http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/gunpowder--12...

story:
We love Shakespeare!

At Fourth Room Theatre in Iowa City, we have all been in love with Shakespeare for a long time. Many of us were inspired to love theater, in part, because of community groups or production companies who put massive time and effort into free productions of the Bard for their communities. 

And we love FREE things!

The Public Theatre's Shakespeare in the Park, NYC; Shakespeare on the Green in Omaha, NE; The People's Shakespeare Project in southeastern Pennsylvania - only a few examples of excellent Shakespeare productions offered free to the public that have personally inspired us.

We feel it's time to bring this powerful approach to theater to Eastern Iowa, and we need your help!

Ticket sales are important, don't get us wrong...

Theater can't always be free and we are well aware that ticket sales and subscriber bases are extremely important. Space, lights, sound equipment, costumes, weapons rental, royalties, choreography and a dozen other necessities vie for hard-earned dollars and time in any theatrical production.

But a free production every year...imagine

A free production can help bring new audiences to theater - and that means new audiences to ALL theater in the area.

We are a community based, non-paying theater company and we want to make a difference in our community. One of the ways we want to do that is by providing a production of Cymbeline (and future annual Shakespearean productions) totally FREE to our community.

Please help us make this dream a reality!

Thank you,

Fourth Room Theatre

Kevin, Angie, Kehry, Rachel, Matthew, and Ottavia

(and our remarkable and dedicated cast and crew thanks you too!)

story:
Short Summary

William Shakespeare once wrote  "All the World's a Stage" and no other passage can better describe the history and philosophy of the Hudson Shakespeare Company. Since 1992, the company has produced a wide range of titles from the Bard to Modern theater (now over 100 productions and counting) in a variety of outdoor and indoor venues.  From city parks to courtrooms, our mission has always been a simple one - to give our audience the best theatrical experience possible. For 22 years HSC has been serving the public arts community by providing free productions in various venues throughout Northern New Jersey, New York, and Connecticut.  We love performing for these communities and plan to continue to do so.  This fall, we are planning to go beyond our normal summer season and produce TWO shows - one for our annual school tour, an all-female AS YOU LIKE IT and Shakespeare's great slasher play, TITUS ANDRONICUS.  Normally, our funds can take care of us, but this time we are seeking for a bit of help.  Our normal rehearsal space is not available to us, and we would prefer to keep to our actors healthy and happy for our performances by not asking them to rehearse outside in the park as the weather gets cooler. Rehearsal space is expensive, and we need some help in acquiring these spaces for the remainder of the rehearsal period which runs through the end of October.  We can't express hiow much just a little extra cash would help us out.  It will keep everyone safe, happy, and healthy for the rigors the performing requires.  We want to provide an inviting atmosphere for our actors to work in. 

What We Need & What You Get

Rehearsal space!  We are seeking some extra funds to help us out with this.  Each room in Manhattan costs at minimum 20$ an hour (so minimum 60$ a night) so anything you can give will help. 

In return we have some awesome offerings - everything from a signed program from the cast, a reserved front row seat at one of our shows,  or a personal monologue audition session! 

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • As part of this production, we are performing in the Harismus Cemetary in Jersey City.  This historic site is run by valueable volunteers who are trying to perserve the city's history.  It's such a fantastic site for this great play.  By helping us, you will be helping them.  If we are able to bring this awesome show to them, we can bring money to their site to keep it preserved.  Your donating is seriously appreciated. 
  • We are one of the few non-union theatre companies still in exsistence.  Started in 1992 by our founder, L. Robert Johnson (effectionately known as "Luther") who's goal it was to bring outdoor theatre across the Hudson, we strive on to continue to bring these works of the Bard with very little, yet still bring New Jersey and the tri-state area the best talent and productions we can.  It all comes from a love of what we do, and of a love of the work.  We want to continue to grow as artists, as people, and as contributors to the community. 
  • Please help us help our community and to keep the work of our business partner alive.  Luther started this and has touched many people and while we are aware that a lot of those who participate don't know who he is, or his impact on our lives, to those he did work with, he will never be forgotten and we will continue to forge on in this wonderful company he set up. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Please share this campaign with others!
  • Have a car?  You can also help us out by becoming a driver and helping our actors get from one venue to the next!
  • Have props?  Costumes?  You can donate them to us.
  • A special skill?  Do you stage manage or love to do sound design?  We'd love to have you.  We're getting more inventive, so please, if you have skills and tricks and tools of the trade to share, let us know!

We are one of the few non-union theatre companies still in exsistence.  Started in 1992 by our founder, L. Robert Johnson (effectionately known as "Luther") who's goal it was to bring outdoor theatre across the Hudson, we strive on to continue to bring these works of the Bard with very little, yet still bring New Jersey and the tri-state area the best talent and productions we can.  It all comes from a love of what we do, and of a love of the work.  We want to continue to grow as artists, as people, and as contributors to the community.  
Please help us help our community and to keep the work of our business partner alive.  Luther started this and has touched many people and while we are aware that a lot of those who participate don't know who he is, or his impact on our lives, to those he did work with, he will never be forgotten and we will continue to forge on in this wonderful company he set up.  

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Please share this campaign with others!
Have a car?  You can also help us out by becoming a driver and helping our actors get from one venue to the next!
Have props?  Costumes?  You can donate them to us.
A special skill?  Do you stage manage or love to do sound design?  We'd love to have you.  We're getting more inventive, so please, if you have skills and tricks and tools of the trade to share, let us know!

story:
Miami Acting Company seeks to promote awareness and appreciation of the performing arts in Miami-Dade County and its surrounding communities through the presentation of live theatrical performances.  We are also dedicated to the support of philanthropic causes that would benefit from utilizing our programs for fund raising purposes.  We strive to provide a theatrical experience to all of Miami-Dade County including the elderly, residents of low-economic means and students who would not normally be able to attend a live theater experience.

We are a theater company without a theater and current venue expenses have made us investigate the possibility of creating our own theater.  This will allow us to produce more performances and allow us to provide the community with services such as theater classes for kids and adults, and work as a community enrichment center offering other opportunities to enhance the cultural experience in our region.  Funding will be helping us invest towards our future theater and theater equipment such as lighting and microphones. 

As a community theater it is our mission to introduce our audiences to live theater.  This
is why we work closely with schools to inspire young theater goers both as
spectators and participants.  After over 6 years, we have been able to produce professional quality shows the whole family can enjoy at a fraction of the cost. 
We also work together with other community organizations to help them achieve their fundraising goals.  We are a community theater built by the community to serve the community.   Our Board of Directors, actors, and crew are made up of professionals from all walks of life who volunteer countless hours to bring live theater to the community.

story:
See Our Past Work:


Who We Are:

Visit www.TheKandake.com to see more of our work.

Formed in March 2011, The Kandake is a dance-theatre collective that combines social activism and philanthropy with folkloric, contemporary, theatrical and experimental movement.

The collective embraces talented performers of various ethnicities, religious (or non-religious) backgrounds and gender identities though the original Kandake were the queens of ancient Ethiopia, Sudan, Somalia and parts of Egypt who were the political, military and spiritual leaders of their societies.

The members of The Kandake aim to continue the legacy of their predecessors--with modern relevancy--by generating active community leaders and joining the frontlines of diverse humanitarian efforts as part of their collective higher purpose. A percentage of proceeds from every Kandake-run production supports a grassroots, not-for-profit or charitable project. The Kandake also stays active in the community by hosting free shows, street art and workshops. 

Storytelling and interaction with the audience is integral to our theatre. While some presentations may be disturbing, absurdist, graphic or "dark" the purpose of our work is to rupture comfort zones, wake the unconscious and inspire critical thinking. Just don't fall into the habit of trying to find "meaning" in every show--sometimes we just want to dance! 

What We Wanna Do Next:

1001 Nights: A Rock Opera (Love Stories on Death Row) --like all our work-- is a modern take on ancient art with social change and giving back to communities in need as our ultimate goal.

It rebirths the mystical world of the original 1001 Nights-- using classic stories from the Middle East, North Africa, India, China and Greece-- within a frame story that has modern, political significance. Scheherazade is no longer a Queen staving off the wrath of her cruel husband but a woman condemned by the criminal justice system.

The show is a literal feast for all five senses that explores what it means to be the "minority" in terms of ethnicity, religion, sex and sexual orientation within society particularly as it relates to the American prison-industry complex. 

What Inspired This?

The numbers speak for themselves. Just a few of the facts:

- The United States holds about 25% of the prisoners in the world, but only 5% of the world population

- What happens when women (especially women of color) defend themselves: http://4strugglemag.org/2013/05/02/no-justice-when-women-fight-back/

- 75% of those incarcerated are imprisoned for non-violent crimes

- The majority of the illegal drug users "white", most people incarcerated for illegal drug use are "of color"

- It costs thousands more to execute a prisoner than to imprison them for life

What We Need

Creating a Rock Opera is A LOT of work. We need to pay for the actors, dancers, rehearsal space, band, writer, producer, director, musical composer, costuming and so much more. Every Kandake-run production has the goal of giving a portion of ticket sales back to marginalized communities in need-- a very hard task to accomplish if you're just trying to break even all the time. 

Help us exceed our fund-raising goal by donating NOW! Every penny counts!


Email kandakedance@gmail.com to Ask About Other Ways You Can Help!!!

story:
Hey there!

How’s it goin’? We’re Elizabeth and Taylor (yes, just like the actress!) and we’re producing a new play, (un)real, with Reckless Theatre Group.


What’s (un)real about?

Family. Fiction. Freefall. 

Desperately alone after her mother’s untimely death, Catherine is forced to navigate her fractured family history and discover how to claim her own future. Is Catherine toeing the edge of reality’s cliff or has she already plunged into the crisp waters of a narrative that is (un)real?  

(un)real began development in fall of 2012 at NYU. After a successful thesis reading earlier this year at Theatre for the New City, the play will premiere December 4th - 8th, 2013.


Who are you anyway?

Reckless was started in 2009 by Producing Artistic Director Taylor Haven Holt, and we have produced three successful mainstage productions - Stupid Kids (UNDER St. Marks), A Midsummer Night’s Dream (Kraine Theatre) and Dog Sees God (UNDER St. Marks), as well as numerous readings and cabarets. We’re proud to have used the talents of over 33 actors in the last 4 years, as well as many designers, stage managers, and videographers.

The motivation of Reckless Theatre Group is to develop theatrical projects utilizing and engaging an emerging generation of artists. In doing so we hope to provide a voice for a present and future generation of issue-oriented introspective theatre-goers. 

In 2013, Reckless produced Shel’s Shorts - a weekend of short pieces by the brilliant Shel Silverstein - at Jimmy’s No. 43, as well as two developmental readings of (un)real.


Brilliant. Who’s working on (un)real?

We’ve put together a crazy amazing team of artists!


the CAST.

Andrea Lynn Green* as Catherine

Matthew McShane as Phillip

Charlie Gorrilla as Gabe

and

Emily Mikesell* as Moira 

*denotes member of Actor’s Equity Assoc.


the CREATIVES. 

playwright. Elizabeth Lee

director. Taylor Haven Holt

assistant director. Whitney Urish

dramaturg. John O’Connor

stage manager. Katie Medved

set designer. Rebecca Phillips

set designer and scenic painter. Brandon Hardy

costume designer. Stephanie Levin

lighting designer. Timothy Cook

sound designer. Emily Auciello

photographer. Benjamin Stelly

videographer. Meredith Ganzman


So, what’s up?

Producing in NYC is not an easy feat. We are thrilled to have booked an amazing and historic theater in the East Village - the Gene Frankel Theater. But it takes a lot of resources to make this production come to life.

That’s where you come in!


How can I get involved?

We are ecstatic to be presenting the premiere of (un)real, and showcasing the talents of our team of artists. In order to make this production a reality we must raise $5,000. The money all goes toward:

- rental of the Gene Frankel Theatre

- actor and designer stipends

- set materials (to transport you to a genuine Greenpoint studio apartment)

- props

- lighting equipment rentals

- transportation of materials and equipment

- marketing and printing costs (postcards, posters, playbills)


That sounds great! But... what do I get in return?

For your generous contributions, you become a member of the Reckless community, and receive a number of different benefits, depending on your level of support. Donors will receive perks such as online (and playbill) shout outs, cast-signed Brooklyn postcards, free beer and wine, and even above-the-title Producing credit.


I’m completely in! Anything else I can do?

If you are not able to support us financially, but are interested in offering goods or services (marketing, Opening Night party space or consumables, costume or set support, etc), we’d love to hear from you!

AND

Please share our campaign on social media to help us get the word out!

LIKE us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/recklesstheatregroup

CHECK OUT our website at www.recklesstheatregroup.com

AND

Most importantly, come see the show! You can buy TICKETS at unrealplay.brownpapertickets.com


THANK YOU!

story:
Somos IMAGINARIO COLECTIVO, una compañía artística multidisciplinaria e independiente, dedicada a la gestión cultural de proyectos innovadores, interdisciplinarios y de investigación. A través del riesgo, la pasión y la calidad de nuestras propuestas, buscamos incidir en la transformación de nuestra realidad socio-política y cultural mediante el contacto con el público y nuestro medio artístico.

Teniendo en cuenta las acciones que ha tomado el estado en los últimos años y la coyuntura social actual, hemos decidido sumar esfuerzos para mostrar una historia que nos permita ver de cerca lo que está en juego cada vez que ignoramos los derechos básicos de las personas trans que viven en nuestra sociedad. Esta pieza busca ayudarnos a medir la distancia que hay entre nuestro punto de partida como profesionales y ciudadanos y el de las mujeres y hombres trans que también llaman a esta ciudad su hogar. 

Creemos y apostamos en que el teatro es una plataforma idónea para mostrar otras realidades y el impacto que tienen nuestras acciones sobre las vidas de los demás.  Somos conscientes de la necesidad de visibilizar a aquellxs personas que no están siendo tomadas en cuenta por la sociedad y el Estado; lo que no se ve se le teme, se le aleja, se le rechaza... Cada unx puede apoyar desde su trinchera, desde aquel lugar que se desarrolla mejor, y en nuestro caso es en el teatro: en puestas en escenas de calidad, con contenido sincero y real.

¡Es por eso que necesitamos de aliadxs! Personas con un interés en generar conciencia a través del arte. Ser unx aliadx en el hermoso proceso de montar esta obra con mensaje y que ya ha cautivado a algunas personas personas y queremos que llegue a muchas más. Su apoyo nos ayudará a generar un producto de calidad, con la ayuda y esfuerzo de actores de renombre en el medio nacional, así como también en una locación privilegiada en el corazón de Miraflores y con diseñadores y creativos que apunten a nuestro mismo horizonte, con el fin de darle calidad a una obra que se está haciendo con el corazón y con mucha alegría.

El aporte a la comunidad, al desarrollo de la sociedad y apoyarel activismo en pro de los derechos de todxs puede venir de todos lados y en diferentes magnitudes. Desde nuestra pequeña plataforma queremos generar espacios de escucha y de conversación, dónde el público charle con actores y activistas trans que ya se han sumado a este proyecto. La cercanía y atmósfera que el teatro genera da pie a discusiones sinceras, de entendimiento y con respeto. 

SE UN ALIADX

Realizar teatro en nuestra realidad es sumamente complejo. Sacar adelante un proyecto artístico y conseguir su financiamiento en nuestro medio es complicado, y si a esto le sumamos el hecho de ser trans y LGTBIQ+ entonces nuestras trabas aumentan. ¡Esto nos motiva a seguir adelante!

Para la realización de nuestra obra necesitamos 5000 DOLARES y con esto poder cubrir gastos necesarios de una obra, como escenografía, luces, vestuario, etc.; así como también cubrir los ensayos de nuestros actores y también retribuir el trabajo a todxs lxs diseñadores que nos apoyan con su talento y experiencia. Sacar una obra adelante es un esfuerzo en común de un gran equipo de personas, y ¡tú puedes ser un aliadx nuestrx!

EL IMPACTO

Apostamos por conversar, discutir y educar. Creemos que generar espacios donde se discuta situaciones delicadas es un deber social con el fin de vivir en comunidad de manera más justa para todxs. Poner en escena a un personaje trans VISIBILIZA a una población que normalmente no tiene un espacio en las tablas. Lo que invita a la conversación a toda aquella persona que sea parte del público, ya sea con un conversatorio con personas cercanas al temas o a la salida del teatro con su acompañante, el impacto esta ahí: en romper el tabú.

Es justamente esa acción de romper el tabú la que, poco a poco, va acabando con los prejuicios y discriminación... Si nos empezamos a ver de verdad, reconociendo nuestras semajanzas por sobre nuestras diferencias es cuando vamos a crear una sociedad más justa para todxs. 

OTRAS FORMAS DE AYUDAR

En caso se te hace imposible contribuir por el momento, ¡te invitamos a que compartas nuestro video! ¡Es muy importante que este video le llegue a la mayor cantidad de personas dentro del periodo de la campaña!

No te va a tomar mucho tiempo, ¡HAGAMOS QUE EL ARCOIRIS LLEGUE A MUCHA GENTE!

Si en caso no puedes apoyarnos en dólares y prefieras hacerlo en soles, puedes escribir al correo: elarcoirisenlasmanos2017@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

We are In Lak’ech Dance Academy, the only queer, trans and allied salsa and bachata dance company in the U.S., directed by Jahaira Fajardo and Angelica Medina. 

We are proud to produce the first Queer Latin Dance Festival in Oakland, California June 8th – 9th, 2018.

The money that we raise in this campaign will help us to produce this festival and will also support scholarships for queer and trans dancers who would otherwise not be able to afford to attend.  

Our dance company is committed to creating a dance community that affirms all genders and sexualities. We do this because leading and following have nothing to do with gender. We also believe that dance can help us heal from the many traumas that we experience in our lives as queer and trans people.

The Queer Latin Dance Festival will be an embodiment of our values as a company and will reflect the diversity of our communities.  

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $6000 to produce this festival and to provide scholarships to queer and trans people of color. We’re doing everything we can to keep registration costs down because we want this to be as accessible as possible. But we aren’t skimping on the talent! We are hosting professional and award winning instructors, as well as musical guest Andre Veloz, an amazing female bachata singer, and her band.

By supporting this campaign, you are supporting the mission of In Lak’ech Dance Academy and you are supporting the *first* Queer Latin Dance Festival. Plus you get some really cute perks that you won’t be able to get anywhere else! We will be printing hand fans and t-shirts with “salserx” and “bachaterx” to help you look hot and stay cool on the dance floor. We’re also making ridiculously cute buttons and stickers with phrases like, “#SheLeads” and “Dance With Your Corazon.”

The Impact

We were recently featured in a short doc from DanceOn that went viral with 297,000 views in two weeks. We’re overwhelmed with the support that we’ve received and we know that what we are doing is deeply needed in the Latin dance community.

 

The Queer Latin Dance Festival is unique because we are creating a festival where queer, trans and allied dancers feel affirmed in our genders and sexualities while we learn to dance.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign on your social media sites! Every share helps us get closer to our goal! Be sure to also like and follow our social media pages: 

  • Queer Latin Dance Festival on Facebook
  • In Lak'ech Dance Academy on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube

 

Make history with us by helping us create the first Queer Latin Dance Festival!
story_txt:
Short Summary
We are In Lak’ech Dance Academy, the only queer, trans and allied salsa and bachata dance company in the U.S., directed by Jahaira Fajardo and Angelica Medina. 
We are proud to produce the first Queer Latin Dance Festival in Oakland, California June 8th – 9th, 2018.
The money that we raise in this campaign will help us to produce this festival and will also support scholarships for queer and trans dancers who would otherwise not be able to afford to attend.  
Our dance company is committed to creating a dance community that affirms all genders and sexualities. We do this because leading and following have nothing to do with gender. We also believe that dance can help us heal from the many traumas that we experience in our lives as queer and trans people.
The Queer Latin Dance Festival will be an embodiment of our values as a company and will reflect the diversity of our communities.  

What We Need & What You Get
We need to raise $6000 to produce this festival and to provide scholarships to queer and trans people of color. We’re doing everything we can to keep registration costs down because we want this to be as accessible as possible. But we aren’t skimping on the talent! We are hosting professional and award winning instructors, as well as musical guest Andre Veloz, an amazing female bachata singer, and her band.
By supporting this campaign, you are supporting the mission of In Lak’ech Dance Academy and you are supporting the *first* Queer Latin Dance Festival. Plus you get some really cute perks that you won’t be able to get anywhere else! We will be printing hand fans and t-shirts with “salserx” and “bachaterx” to help you look hot and stay cool on the dance floor. We’re also making ridiculously cute buttons and stickers with phrases like, “#SheLeads” and “Dance With Your Corazon.”

The Impact
We were recently featured in a short doc from DanceOn that went viral with 297,000 views in two weeks. We’re overwhelmed with the support that we’ve received and we know that what we are doing is deeply needed in the Latin dance community.
 
The Queer Latin Dance Festival is unique because we are creating a festival where queer, trans and allied dancers feel affirmed in our genders and sexualities while we learn to dance.

Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this campaign on your social media sites! Every share helps us get closer to our goal! Be sure to also like and follow our social media pages: 


Queer Latin Dance Festival on Facebook

In Lak'ech Dance Academy on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube


 
Make history with us by helping us create the first Queer Latin Dance Festival!

story:
Help Bring Once Upon A Zombie Apocalypse to life ... or perhaps an undead life!

  • Ever wanted to remix your favorite fairytale? 
  • Ever wondered if you would survive a zombie apocalypse?  
  • Ever wondered just how versatile duct tape can really be?  
If you said 'yes' to any of the above, you're in luck. And if you said 'no', prepare to have your mind blown right open and possibly eaten by zombies because it's clear that you are grossly unprepared for a zombie apocalypse.  

Once Upon a Zombie Apocalypse is filled with fun and adventure that everyone can enjoy whether they're a kid themselves or just a kid at heart.  It will be produced in this year's first inaugural Chicago Kid's Fringe Festival.  And in order for it to be the best possible show Fringe goers can hope to see, we need your help! By contributing to our production efforts you are helping us to offset the costs for:

  • Set and Prop Pieces
  • Costumes
  • Marketing Materials
  • Ad Space
  • Performer and Crew Stipends

Become a contributor and you will be recognized in our program for helping to bring to life our little play full of big ideas.

This sounds AMAZING, what else can I do to support?

Glad you asked!  Buy a ticket to come see Once Upon A Zombie Apocalypse and spread the word to help us reach our goal!
Tickets - $10 for Adults plus a one time $5 button purchase/$5 for Kids

https://www.vendini.com/ticket-software.html?t=tix&e=3c4a7e263d8ab7df50c0dd5de077e759

All performances at Jefferson Playhouse - 4766 N. Milwaukee - first floor
  • Sept 6th @ 1pm
  • Sept 12th @ 1pm
  • Sept 13th @ 2:30pm

story:
What We're All About

We met in training at the Upright Citizens Brigade. We're NYC-based comedians looking to showcase our voices. Our team worked together in December 2016. We were ecstatic when our sketch show, "Life of Pinata" sold out 

 https://vimeo.com/channels/1174802  

Our campaign is important to us because we care about telling original comedic stories. 

Meet the Team

Patrick Keene, Director

Patrick is an improviser/actor based in Brooklyn, NY. You can see him on the road with UCB's TourCo, on Lloyd Night with Judy Big Mouth, or around NYC with his indie groups Owl Theory, Together We Chill, and PLUR. He is also a Pisces and co-hosts a monthly improv show based on astrology called A Taste of the Peculiar. He's on Twitter (@doo_kee) and Instagram (@pad00d2.0). Can you believe?

Emily Menez, Writer/"Margene"

Emily Menez is a comedy writer and improviser at the Upright Citizens Brigade. She's written for IFC, Funny or Die, and SNL's "Weekend Update." Emily hails from Overland Park, Kansas but her heart belongs to New York City. You can follow her @emenez2. She also owns @emenez1 but forgot her password.

Jon Hudson, "Berty"

Jon Hudson performs and writes for his sketch comedy team, Big Britches, and recently co-wrote and starred in Glen Garry Glen Escalator - a comedy play that is exactly what it sounds like it is. After a tumultuous period as a notorious soccer internet celebrity called Stat Geek, he is delighted to be in a show as fun, funny, and funky as Margene Salt. Please accept his warmest regards and find him @JonHudson on Twitter.

Erin Harland, "Fran"

Originally from "The Sunshine State", Florida native Erin Maloney moved to New York at just 17 years old to pursue her love for acting, studying with the New York Conservatory for Dramatic Arts and training with the Upright Citizens Brigade school for improv. In the meantime, she loves to write, film, and edit for personal projects with friends. She also writes and sings original music, as well as Standup Comedy, and performs at Open Mic nights around New York City.

Amanda Poryes, "Caroline"

Amanda Likes Plays. She also likes sketch comedy (they're like five page plays) and improvised comedy (it's like made-up plays with no rehearsals or memorization).

web.amandaporyes.com  

Joe Taylor, "One Dimensional Joe"

Joe has trained in Sketch Comedy and Improv at the Upright Citzens Brigade since 2013. He currently freelances for Funny or Die. His name is very common so good luck finding him on the internet.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our goal is to raise $1,000
  • This will cover rehearsal space, festival submission fees, props, dance training, make-up/costumes, director's fee, and most importantly, renting the performance venue. 
  • We appreciate you taking a chance on us, and offer unique thank yous, described in detail on the right under "perks"

Timeline

  • June & July: Read-throughs
    • Launch Indiegogo campaign
    • Book theater space
  • August & September: Rehearsals, Gather Props/set pieces
    • Submit for Upright Citizen Brigade SPANK consideration
    • Submit for various one act festivals
  • October & November: Performances Start 

Risks & Challenges

  • We're balancing out our day jobs and other comedy gigs to make this play a priority
  • Although it's a lot of effort, it's also an honor to tell this story. We will push through to make this thing happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about "Margene Salt"
  • Our Twitter handle is @MargeneSaltPlay, shout us out!
  • Most importantly, please come and see us when we're up. We couldn't do this without you!

June & July: Read-throughs
Launch Indiegogo campaign
Book theater space



August & September: Rehearsals, Gather Props/set pieces
Submit for Upright Citizen Brigade SPANK consideration
Submit for various one act festivals



October & November: Performances Start 

Risks & Challenges

We're balancing out our day jobs and other comedy gigs to make this play a priority
Although it's a lot of effort, it's also an honor to tell this story. We will push through to make this thing happen!

Please get the word out and make some noise about "Margene Salt"
Our Twitter handle is @MargeneSaltPlay, shout us out!
Most importantly, please come and see us when we're up. We couldn't do this without you!

story:
MElder Movement Art is in its infancy (conceptualized earlier this year) and needs your help! Though we are a baby company, we have already been asked to participate in so many great opportunities!

We are presenting our first work, A Study of Occupied Spaces, THREE TIMES in the coming months: HERE Summer Sublet Series, Take Root at Greenspace, and Triskelion Split Bill. As well, the company will be touring to D.C., Maryland, and Iowa to teach masterclasses and create. As a newly founded dance collective, so many opportunities so quickly is rare, and we want to commit to all of them. Sadly, that requires a little bit of money...

As you may already know, art making and producing is expensive, especially in the United States. It is very difficult to receive funds at a state/federal level, so most art initiatives stay afloat through individual patronage from people like you. 

We are trying to raise $1,250. This is the absolute minimum needed to fulfill the requirements of our future engagements. This cost covers dancer fees, travel expenses, lighting design, stage management, marketing, rehearsal space, costuming, and all the other miscellaneous expenses that accompany a season of art making/producing. Below are a few incentives to give:

Donators up to $50: Social media mention

Donators of $50-75: Mention in program and website

Donators of $75-100: Mention in program and website and a personalized letter from the company

Donators of $100-150: Mention in program and website, personalized letter from the company, and a progressional photo of the company 

Donators of $150+: Mention in program and website, personalized letter from the company, professional photo of the company, and a two free tickets to any of our upcoming shows

No donation is too small, but I do understand if donating is not a possibility. If it is not, please share with others you feel may have an interest in contributing to our 2017-18 season. Thank you for reading, and we hope to see you at our shows!

For more details, feel free to contact us at: contact@meldermovementart.com.

story:
How can I aMUSE you?

             Hey there everybody! My name is Cody Martinez. I am 19 years old and born and raised in Durango, Colorado. I began teaching myself to dance when I was about 11 years old. Hip hop and breakdance were my first areas of interest in this art form. The first success I had was when I was 15. My mom pushed me to enter a local talent contest called Spotlight to stardom. I won first place in my age group and was awarded 500 dollars, I was stoked! About a year ago I was introduced to a company called "The Muse" directed by Jessica Starr. I was incredibly inspired by her and her dancers. I only spent a few days taking class from them but in that time, I saw inspiration, passion, and an expansion of dance that I had never felt before. Their goal each time they dance is to incorporate inspiration, intention and intelligence. Not only did they achieve that very clearly but they also shared a bond for fellow dancers that was nothing short of awesome! After talking with Jessica, she told me that I should audition for her summer program called "The Muse Experience". It is a program that shows you the ins and outs of being a professional dancer in L.A.  and a year later, I did just that! The audition required a video of me answering questions and performing a solo. I got my video in just in time and was accepted to be a part of The Muse Experience 2014!! (The video of my audition is on my page) That was the first step toward the opportunity of a lifetime! The next step, raising 3200 dollars to take a life changing adventure to Los Angeles, California! The money would cover funds to pay for the experience, plane expenses, and food. Whatever money I raise will go towards my fees even if I do not reach my goal. The list of new experiences this provides for me outside of dance includes, first time going to California, first time traveling by plane, and possibly going to a beach for the first time! Not only will this be outrageously beneficial to me, it will also help me bring something back to the children I teach and work with.  Overall this would be the most impacting journey of my 19 year old life.
         Throughout high school I participated in local shows put on by Fort Lewis College and fundraisers at The Durango Arts Center, as well as performing for Terpis Contemporary Dance company and competing for the Dance in the Rockies Competition Team on a full scholarship. Woooo! I competed the past 2 years with DITR and had the privilege of choreographing and teaching some recreational hip-hop classes. My interest in dance has also brought me to becoming a gymnastics coach. I have been coaching gymnastics classes as a part of The Durango Gymnastics Academy for a year now and the love I have for the kids and the sport is right up there with the love I have for dance and the family that it has brought me. The impact on the children that I have the honor of teaching, has already been a huge step in making my dreams come true.
         By the end of my dance career, if there were a few things I could have people say about me, they would be that I entertained them, that I helped them achieve something they never thought possible or that I inspired them to be above and beyond the hardships of life. There are no words to truly describe what this means to me or how much I would appreciate any help possible. I have already received so much love from my community and this opportunity gives me a tremendous chance to bring something truly special back to everyone who has supported me. Thank you all for taking the time to read this!!

story:
My name is Allison Plamondon and I am a NY-based choreographer, actress and teacher originally from Edmonton, Canada. As a choreographer, I have presented work throughout North America, including the New York Musical Theatre Festival, the NY Fringe (Award for Excellence in Choreography), the Princess of Wales Theatre (Toronto) and Canada's prestigious Charlottetown Festival. I have also choreographed for film/tv, most notably for the 2013 Oscar-winning short film, Curfew.  

I have been creating movement to Tchaikovsky since early 2014. I have always appreciated his music popularly used for ballet but only recently fell in love with his full, epic body of work. I find it incredibly inspiring to choreograph to music of such emotional scale and it has challenged me to expand my movement vocabulary and make bold concept choices.

I have assembled an extremely talented, versatile cast of 12(!) who are as passionate about the project as I am and are generously donating their time and talents. Your contribution will go directly to giving each performer a modest stipend as well as paying the stage manager and assistant choreographer. Your support will also help with the rental costs for dance studio space before we are in residency at HB Studio. The average hourly rate for rehearsal space in nyc is $25/h, adding up to nearly $800 in pre-residency costs. Other expenses include minimal set and costume (budgeted at $200).  I also plan on hiring a videographer to record the showings, as having dance footage is an essential tool for the next stage of the work. 

One of the most important ways to give is by attending our showings. In the meantime, please spread the word and we'll see you Sat, Nov 19th and Sun, 20th at HB Studio.

Thanks again for your support!

story:
Help us save the GameVerse!

The DC Stunt Coalition (DCSC) has performed the live stunt show at MAGFest for the past 2 years and we are now far into our prep for year three! This year's chapter: "Guardians of the Grimdark" - an action packed adventure starring are stunt performers as creatively costumed video game heroes, anti-heroes, and villains from across your favorite gaming fandoms!

 

Since August 2016, we have been hard at work writing another fully original parody show. We are well on our way in producing another exciting and hilarious adventure for our audience to enjoy. With our creative team developing the script and the cast perfecting their fights and learning lines, we  believe you are all in for another extraordinary show.

It is our hope to not only create a fun show for us, but a memorable one for you!

We need your help to show appreciation to this marvelous collection of talented stunt performers and action actors as they fight one another to determine the fate of the GameVerse. With your contributions, we can make the production value of this show; costumes, props, and effects, much greater than years before.

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign is being produced in an effort to support our cast. As parodies, these shows can't yield a profit, so we use them as educational exercises to give our performers a chance to create an amazing show and put it on MAGFest's incredible primetime stage. With that opportunity though, comes a huge investment on the part of the cast and crew in costumes and props.

So we need your help! We would like to give you, the audience, a chance to help us create this amazing hour of entertainment, all to insure our excitement and inspiration when producing future shows. Your contributions are a direct investment into our ability to create entertaining art!

This year, we'll be pulling out all the stops, as our costumes and props inspired by games and characters such as: Fallout’s Vault Dweller, Mass Effect’s Commander Shepard, Protoman, Bowser, LoL's Katarina, Kirby, Overwatch's Mercy, the Prince of Persia, Kingdom Hearts’ Sora and Heartless, and more characters soon to be announced!

It's a huge show, but we've learned how to crunch our numbers, and create a sustainable budget - so we don't need much! We are aiming to raise just $500 in order to help our performers make exciting costumes, our prop masters to make spectacular props, and also to help us afford provisions for our cast such as extra food, water, and print supplies.

Perks include: Recognition in after-show credits, a month membership to DCSC, private training with a DCSC instructor, and even last year’s star prop the Giant Video Game Controller, signed by last year’s cast!

The Impact

DCSC has joined MAGFest for the past 2 years in the celebration of music and gaming. The live stunt show has brought laughter and excitement to hundreds of our fellow fans. This is a production by fans for fans to be enjoyed with fans of video games.

Risks & Challenges

DCSC’s "Gamers Against the Grimdark" shows at MAGFest are fully volunteer productions. All costumes and props are assembled, created, or modified by the performers at their own personal cost in order to capture the spirit of their characters and the wonderment we all feel from videogaming to the best of their ability. Our performers pay out of their own pockets for the love of our fans, the love of performing, and most importantly, the love of video games. Your support will go a long way in alleviating the costs to our performers, as well as covering the cost of materials and props used in the show.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come support DCSC at our live stunt show! If you like what we do, tell others about us and share us on social media. And tell MAGFest how much you love us so we can keep coming back year after year.

With our creative team developing the script and the cast perfecting their fights and learning lines, we  believe you are all in for another extraordinary show.

It is our hope to not only create a fun show for us, but a memorable one for you!
We need your help to show appreciation to this marvelous collection of talented stunt performers and action actors as they fight one another to determine the fate of the GameVerse. With your contributions, we can make the production value of this show; costumes, props, and effects, much greater than years before.

What We Need & What You Get
This campaign is being produced in an effort to support our cast. As parodies, these shows can't yield a profit, so we use them as educational exercises to give our performers a chance to create an amazing show and put it on MAGFest's incredible primetime stage. With that opportunity though, comes a huge investment on the part of the cast and crew in costumes and props.
So we need your help! We would like to give you, the audience, a chance to help us create this amazing hour of entertainment, all to insure our excitement and inspiration when producing future shows. Your contributions are a direct investment into our ability to create entertaining art!
This year, we'll be pulling out all the stops, as our costumes and props inspired by games and characters such as: Fallout’s Vault Dweller, Mass Effect’s Commander Shepard, Protoman, Bowser, LoL's Katarina, Kirby, Overwatch's Mercy, the Prince of Persia, Kingdom Hearts’ Sora and Heartless, and more characters soon to be announced!
It's a huge show, but we've learned how to crunch our numbers, and create a sustainable budget - so we don't need much! We are aiming to raise just $500 in order to help our performers make exciting costumes, our prop masters to make spectacular props, and also to help us afford provisions for our cast such as extra food, water, and print supplies.
Perks include: Recognition in after-show credits, a month membership to DCSC, private training with a DCSC instructor, and even last year’s star prop the Giant Video Game Controller, signed by last year’s cast!


The Impact
DCSC has joined MAGFest for the past 2 years in the celebration of music and gaming. The live stunt show has brought laughter and excitement to hundreds of our fellow fans. This is a production by fans for fans to be enjoyed with fans of video games.

Risks & Challenges
DCSC’s "Gamers Against the Grimdark" shows at MAGFest are fully volunteer productions. All costumes and props are assembled, created, or modified by the performers at their own personal cost in order to capture the spirit of their characters and the wonderment we all feel from videogaming to the best of their ability. Our performers pay out of their own pockets for the love of our fans, the love of performing, and most importantly, the love of video games. Your support will go a long way in alleviating the costs to our performers, as well as covering the cost of materials and props used in the show.


Other Ways You Can Help
Come support DCSC at our live stunt show! If you like what we do, tell others about us and share us on social media. And tell MAGFest how much you love us so we can keep coming back year after year.

story:
About Beatrice

Beatrice is a wordless steam-punk puppet show, that deals with our human fascination and sometimes symbiotic relationship with machines.

The performance is based on 'Beatrice', a short story by Karin Tidbeck. The surreal and tragi-comic universe created by the author constitutes an ideal setting to explore with puppetry.

It's a unique story about all-consuming passion and its costs, set in a universe, where man and machine live together, fall in love, procreate and hate in a way that is both bizarre and organic. The main characters are:  Franz Hiller, a doctor who falls deeply in love with the airship Beatrice. And Anna Goldberg, a printer's daughter, who has a hot romance with a steam engine called Hercules.

This extraordinary and imaginative love-story is told in a steam-punk setting of puppets, shadows, rotating mechanics, original sounds and music, and lots of dark humor.

We are 5 theater professionals from Denmark and UK, working together for the first time creating 'Beatrice': 1 director, 2 puppeteers, 1 composer,  and 1 puppet maker / set designer. 

'Beatrice' will be premiered at Svanekegaarden in Denmark on the 6th of June 2014. We will take the production on a premiere tour on Bornholm. We are also planning a Nordic tour in September 2014. Following that we will start working on a world tour.

For further information and production peeks, please visit Beatrice on Facebook

Who we are:

Tidsrum is a non-profit company based in Copenhagen, Denmark. Tidsrum makes art experiences focusing on sensory, poetical and interactive expressions. 'Beatrice' is our first puppet production.

The dream team making the production 'Beatrice' come true is:

Director: Steve Tiplady

Puppeteers: Ida Marie Tjalve and Karina Nielsen

Puppets and Set design: Sarah Piyannah Cederstrand

Instrument creator and composer: Andreas Busk

Author: Karin Tidbeck

The Music:

We tell the story with out words, which is why the music is very important. Andreas Busk has not only composed a whole soundtrack for the show, but also invented 2 instruments.

The Bornholmer Violin is played live in the show. It is mainly used as the voice of Beatrice the airship. Watch here to hear Andreas test its sound:

The Step Sequencer - made out of two turntables, is built into the set and is part of the universe the puppets live in. It will add sounds to the soundtrack according to the way the puppets operate it, and with a random factor that gives every show its own sound.

What we need the money for:

We have been working on 'Beatrice' since 2012. We've already invested lots of time, energy - and love - to get where we are now: The puppets are almost finished, the set is working, the music is ready for the final adjustments and the rehearsals are running.

Now we need YOUR help. We hope to raise $15,000 on indiegogo. The raised money will go to:

- One last rehearsal period

- Costumes

- Lighting equipment

- Transport costs

- Materials and workspace (to get the set really gorgeously steam-punked)

- A short presentation movie about the show

We already have some funding for PR, posters and marketing. Any funds above our goal will go to make international touring of 'Beatrice' possible, thus giving more people a chance to experience this fantastic tale...

ANY donation will help!  - and all will go into making the show. 


What you get:

First of all you get to be part of making this great show real. You will have our sincerest gratitude and to show our appreciation of your generosity, we will be offering some great perks, including: show tickets, invites to opening night, mention in our programs and on our website, and even some original art pieces.

- If you do NOT want your name on web, Facebook or program just send us a message.


Other Ways You Can Help:

No amount is too small (or too big!), but we understand that making a donation is not possible for everyone. You can still be a huge help to us by simply spreading the word about our campaign and sharing our video on Facebook and Twitter.
And check us out on Facebook ( in English) to learn more about the process of making 'Beatrice', or Tidsrum's website (in Danish) to learn about our company, workshops and productions.

Thanks!

story:
Operating Theater is a collective of Theater teaching artists dedicated to creative exploration and presentation of theater, both scripted and self-generated, in an open studio environment. 

            The brand-new Operating Theatre Company is proud to present our inaugural production of

The Memory of Water

By Shelagh Stephenson

January 16th-19th, 2014

“Nothing has a stronger influence psychologically on their environment and especially on their children than the unlived life of the parent”- Carl Jung

Three adult sisters to pick through the past but  are unconsciously bound by their memories of their mother, who watches over their struggle. How does the lived and unlived life of their mother shape the life of her daughters?

Complicating their interactions is the fragile nature of memory. Their mother has died of Alzheimer’s disease. Each sister has her version of her own childhood.  No two sisters remember their childhood experiences in the same way or have the same emotional coloration to those memories.  Even their mother doesn’t recognize the harsh judgmental creatures who are her daughters. Yet, they are sisters and must find a way to come together.  Unable to connect with each other, they find dangerous, hilarious and endearing ways to break through.

**************************************************************************

“God gave us memory so that we might have roses in December.” 

Cast: 

  • Catherine: Ellen Boyle
  • Mary: Kate Myre
  • Theresa: Lisa Norman
  • Frank: Timothy Piggee                
  • Mike: Kerry Skalsky
  • Violet: Rhonda Soikowsk

Director:  Makaela Pollock  

Design/Tech Director: Rick MacKenzie  

Stage Manager:  Anna Gustafson 

Assistant Stage Manager: Victoria McNaughton

Dialect Coach:  Kayla Walker 

Music: Andre Couture 

Produced by Operating Theatre Company

The show will run January 16th through 19th at the Cornish Playhouse Studio Located at 201 Mercer Street Seattle, WA 98109.

****************************************************************************

“There are some things one remembers even though they may never have happened.” - Harold Pinter

We all have felt the need to question and investigate what is needed for 21st century actor training.  Operating Theater can provide a forum for refining what we are teaching in our classrooms.  We are modeling professional conduct, ethics, problem-solving, communication and or course. We have a true common experience to share with our students, and they are invited to watch as we struggle to render truthful and powerful performances on stage. We have also been invited to participate in Our Creative Society, wherein several members of Operating Theater will host a workshop for our greater community.

*********************************************************************************************

In order to make this production as good as we know it can be, we ask for your support. We have already raised some funds and incurred some costs on our own, but in order to reach our goal we need YOUR HELP.

Where Does This Money Go?

This is a self-produced piece. Many of our recent alumni are finding it both necessary and desirable to produce their own work. They are proactively taking charge of their artistic output by finding pieces that interest them and finding other artists with whom they want to work.  Our journey in creating Operating Theater and in producing this piece gives us first-hand experience with the challenges and rewards in self-producing. 

We are working towards the costs of  building physical production, paying the director, the stage manager as well as additional costs that come with putting on a production. But contributions of any and all sizes are deeply appreciated. We can't do this without the support of our friends and families.

story:
PHAEDA AT TCG'S NATIONAL CONFERENCE!

Phaeda Wins Award is a meta-theatrical political comedy by Danny Mitarotondo, directed by Leslie Ishii. Beginning as a light-hearted post-show talkback between artistic director Martin Miller and Asian American theatre director Phaeda Thai about Phaeda's directorial choices in her all Asian rendition of Neil Simon's Laughter on the 23rd Floor, the play takes a turn into a serious and complicated conversation about race and money. Plunging head-on into the present-day reality of Asian American invisibility in American theatre, Phaeda Wins Award aims to inspire radical change in our business.  

After a successful workshop in New York in January and a reading of the play in Los Angeles in February - both funded by your generous support here on Indiegogo - we are honored to present a short excerpt of the play at Theatre Communications Group's National Conference in San Diego on June 20th! 

We are asking for your support: to bring our playwright to San Diego from New York, to cover gas money from Los Angeles (where we are rehearsing) to San Diego, and the money to house our artists at the conference from June 19th through June 21st. 

We still have $250 saved from our original campaign in January and received a massive anonymous donation of $1440 to cover our conference registration costs! The total amount we have to raise is exactly $1344.  

TCG's National Conference is the foremost meeting place of our nation's theatrical leaders and innovators. With your support, we will not only present Phaeda to the key artists who can help bring it to full future life, but you will help us initiate serious dialogue about the lack of Asian American artists working in American theatre directly with the people who must make these changes. 

With your support, we can make a dramatic impact at the conference with our colleagues and across the nation. 


THE BUDGET AND HOW YOU CAN HELP

All we need to get FOUR artists to the TCG National Conference is $1344! Here is our total, transparent budget:  

Airfare from New York to LA for playwright Danny Mitarotondo: $392.20

Gas Money for the entire creative team to drive from LA to San Diego:  $100 

Lodging for three of our artists at the conference for three nights:  $851.80 

Meals for all artists (rehearsals and conference): $250 (saved from last campaign!)

Conference Registrations for all participants ($285 per person): $1140 (covered by an anonymous donor!!)

TOTAL: $1344!!

This conference is mostly attended by theatre administrators with steady employment. For working freelance artists like us, $1344 is a lot of money. With your support, we can cover these basic, bare-bones expenses and participate in this tremendous opportunity. 


THE CONFERENCE

Phaeda will kick off what is bound to be a watershed breakout session at TCG's National Conference, created by our fearless leader Leslie Ishii. Entitled "Establishing Asian Pacific Islander Visibility in American Theatre," the breakout session will begin with an excerpt from Phaeda Wins Award, performed by actors Wesley Mann and Julia Cho. The excerpt will seamlessly transition into a serious conversation between the TCG audience and representatives of our nation's leading API artists and allies. 

These artists include:

Seema Sueko (Panel Moderator): Associate Artistic Director, The Pasadena Playhouse, Co-Founder & Former Executive Artistic Director, Mo`olelo Performing Arts Company; Pasadena, CA

Tim Dang (Panelist): Producing Artistic Director, EWP (East West Players Asian American Theatre); Board Member, CAATA (Consortium of Asian American Theatres and Artists); Los Angeles, CA

Mia Katigbak (Panelist):  Artistic Producing Director, NAATCO (National Asian American Theatre Co.); Founding Director; CAATA (Consortium of Asian American Theaters & Artists); New York, NY

Randy Reyes (Panelist):  Artistic Director, Mu Performing Arts; Board Member, CAATA (Consortium of Asian American Theatres and Artists); Twin Cities, MN

Marc Oka (Panelist):  Western Region Equal Employment Opportunity Committee, Actors Equity Association; Los Angeles, CA 

Sharifa Johka (Panelist):  Program Manager, FAIR (Fellowships, Assistantships, Internships, Residencies); Oregon Shakespeare Festival, Ashland, OR

Our actors Julia Cho and Wesley Mann will join playwright Danny Mitarotondo and director Leslie Ishii two days before the conference in LA to rehearse the play. The actors and playwright will then attend the conference, unite with our esteemed panelists, and knock it out of the park on Friday June 20th. 


To read an essay by playwright Danny Mitarotondo written for TCG's Conference 2.0 website about Phaeda and his role as a playwright ally, please click here: http://www.tcgcircle.org/2014/05/write-what-you-dont-know/


JOIN OUR SUPPORT NETWORK!

In our last campaign, we began creating a network of support toward our play and cause. To date, our donors are:

Will Arbery, Marcus Chong, Stacey Cole, Janice Coll, Daniel Darwin, Dennis DiOrio, Shannon Fillion, Susannah Frith, Patricia Garza, Jonas Goslow, Beth Gudenrath, Jennifer Hill, Addie Ishii, Raymon Ishii, Sarah Jessop, Hana Kadoyama, Sarah Kauffman, Peter Kuo, Sunshine Lampitoc, Blaze Mancillas, Felicia Meyer, Erica Mitchell, Charmain Page-Walthrus, Pamela Nobuto, Michael Pantozzi, Jeanne Patterson, Patricia Peterson, Christine Phillips, Debra Rocco, Karin Saari, Becca Schneider, Leslie Scigliano, Andrew Trent, Mark Watford, Craig Young, Sarah Zapiler, Mo Zhou, and Judith Zuckerman

With their tremendous support, we were able to get our play off the ground ... and now that play is going to San Diego! Join this wonderful group. Help us reach this next crucial stage. Every little bit helps! 


THE FUTURE ... IS NOW

In our last campaign (view here: ), we wrote:

"It is here and now that we meet, more impassioned than ever, to support the theatre industry to move diversity and inclusion forward for all peoples who have historically been marginalized. We hope you will join us at this crucial step in both the journey of our play and its message."

This is happening now. Because of your support in January, we took a giant step forward. We now take another one, a larger one. We ask, from the bottom of our hearts, that you join us. That you help us. That you bring us closer to establishing the Asian Pacific Islander on the American Stage.

story:
We thank you all for your contributions to the Ivy Crest Theatre Co. Our campaign is over, but if you didn't get the opportunity to donate you can still do so here!

About Us:

The Ivy Crest Theatre Co. is a newly formed theatre ensemble with an exciting mix of established, professional and emerging theatre artists. Our ensemble includes an Oscar winning producer, teachers from two of the most reputable acting schools in the world, award winning directors and designers, and well trained actors at various points in their careers. The one thing that unifies us all is a dedication, passion and an unending study of our crafts. The Ivy Crest Theatre Co. is our way of creating a platform to get to work, creating compelling theatre on our own terms.

www.ivycrestnyc.com

Our Mission:

The Ivy Crest Theatre Co., founded in 2015, was developed with the initiative to provide professional quality theatre at an affordable price to the NY audience in intimate black box settings. Our core imperative is that the plays we produce resonate with both our artists and audience. It is our commitment to achieve this mission through underproduced forms of theatre, such as one acts or short plays, new works and revivals of Off-Broadway plays. As an NYC theatre company, it is also our deeply held belief that our work should be as diverse as the city itself- providing a platform for women and minority writers but also to focus on works that range from blue to white collar struggles. As to the type of stories we want to tell, Faulkner said it best "the problems of the human heart, in conflict with itself."

Company Board

Executive Director: James McCloskey

Artistic Director: David Newer

General Manager: Yulianna Garrido

Development Director/Producer: Lauren Duffy

Staff

Resident Director/Artistic Associate: Erica Silberman

Consultant/Director: Milton Justice * Academy Award Winner

Tech Director: Matthew Leddin 

Lighting Designer: Scott Kuker

Videographer: John Noel


About the Plays:

Our first production will feature two one act plays by Edward Allan Baker.

Location: Davenport Theatre, Black Box 45th St, btw 8th & 9th Ave

Up, Down, Strange, Charmed, Beauty, and Truth

A beaten-down, 18 year old girl needs to convince her uncle to free her and her sister from their crazy, violent and drug addicted mother. But salvation, if it is to be achieved, comes at a terrible price and may not be attainable to all. Baker tells a wrenching tale of loves found and lost, of broken hearts and betrayal.

North of Providence

On the last day of their father's life, Carol must convince her despondent, drunk of a brother to come to the hospital and say goodbye. Through tears, violence and confrontations the secret that has been eating away at Bobbie, leaving him in ruin for years, comes out. It's a play about the buried past and how it can keep on burning us for years, but also holds the possibility of redemption....forgiveness.

About the Playwright:

Edward Allan Baker is a New York City playwright. His One Act Plays have been produced all over the U.S., Canada, and Europe, most notable, among others include, North Of Providence, Dolores, Rosemary With Ginger, Face Divided, A Dead Man’s Apartment, Up, Down, Strange, Charmed, Beauty and Truth, Mafia On Prozac, and Lila On The Wall. Off-Broadway successes include full-length plays, Prairie Avenue, American Storage, and The Framer. Baker is a screenwriter, as well as being a faculty member at Pace University/Actors Studio Drama School, and a recipient of "The 25th Anniversary Award For Theatrical Excellence," by The Ensemble Studio Theatre Of New York. He is a member of The Dramatists Guild.

Creative Team

Up, Down, Strange, Charmed, Beauty, and Truth

Erica Silberman, Director

Erica directed David Newer's award winning solo show LA Unified at United Solo Theatre Festival and other solo shows at Dixon Place and Manhattan Theatre Source. Co-founder and writer/director for Eating Theatre. Sixteen time writer for theAtrainplays. Associate produced Michael Mejias’s award winning play Ghetto Babylon at 59E59 Theaters. Erica's plays have been developed or produced at EST, HERE, Playwrights Horizon, The Metropolitan Playhouse, New Perspectives, and The Stonington Opera House. Member DG, LPTW and WAM.

Kelly Kozakevich, Marley

Kelly is thrilled to be a part of this incredible show and cast! Kelly was born and raised in Canada and currently resides in NYC. Credits include: Be A Man (FGR & MRT), Toad of Toad Hall (Red Deer Theatre), The Agreement (Love and Time Machines Theatre), and The Ghost Sonata (Studio A). Film: Getting Creative (Web Series), At The Range, Tumaini. Kelly is a graduate of the William Esper Studio (NYC). Matthew 7:7-8 www.kellykozakevich.com

Lacy Marie Meyer, Steph

A NYC based Award Winning Film, Television, and Theatre Actor; who has been performing on stage since the age of five. Lacy moved to NYC to study with the acclaimed Bill Esper after finishing her first lead role in a feature film -- SUCK IT UP BUTTERCUP -- for which she won BEST LEAD ACTRESS four times with other awards at various film festivals throughout the nation. Upon graduation from The William Esper Studio's Two Year Meisner Based Training Program, Lacy has completed two more feature films as the lead: SECOND CHANCE (2x4 Productions, 2015) and JOKERS WILD (JFA Productions, 2015). She has a Recurring Role on Comedy Central's INSIDE AMY SCHUMER. Further, Lacy is now a lifetime Permanent Ensemble Member of The Collective, a NYC based Theatre and Film Production Company.


David Newer (AEA /SAG-AFTRA), Danny 

THEATER: L.A. Unified*, Time Stands Still, Dinner with Friends, Rounding Third, Magnetic North, Split Second, Gun Club, Parker Family Circus, Texas Homos, Noon Day Sun, Clean Living, Cold Flesh, Carry the Tiger to the Mountain

*Best Educational Play Award, United Solo Festival 2014, written and performed by David Newer

FILM & TELEVISION:  Performance Anxiety*, Thinking with Richard, Preying For Mercy, directed by Bill Duke (Deep Cover, Predator), Law & Order, Law & Order SVU

*Prix De La Critique (Critic’s Choice, Best Short Film), Cannes Film Festival-1994

North of Providence

David Newer, Director

DIRECTING: Eden End, The Blue Room, The Last Supper, Exit Neon, Tape, Orphans, Danny and the Deep Blue Sea, The Dumb Waiter, Mary MacGregor, Red Light Winter, This is our Youth, Home Free

TEACHING: 2015 marks David’s eleventh year teaching first and second year acting at the William Esper Studio in NYC. He won Backstage's Readers' Choice Award for Best Monologue Coach 2014.

Lauren Duffy, Carol

Lauren is a recent graduate of the William Esper Studio. With a strong background in musical theatre, she has performed in many productions in and out of New York City. Previous credits include: Down the Road (Blue Box Productions), Waist Watchers the Musical (Broadhollow Theatre Productions), and Stage Mothers (Manhattan Theatre Rep). University credits include: Five Women Wearing the Same Dress, Cabaret, and Spring Awakening. She has also been involved in numerous short films, staged readings, as well as singing at restaurants and bars all across Long Island. 

James McCloskey, Bobbie

James is a recent alumni and an ongoing student at the William Esper Studio. NYC Theatre Credits: The Turn of the Screw & The Dead for Breakfast. Rutgers University (NJ) credits include: The Lieutenant of Inishmore, The House of Yes, The Goat or Who Is Sylvia?, Six Degrees of Separation, Coax. Jesus Hopped the A Train, Parade, & A Midnight Clear. James is a founding member and the Executive Director of The Ivy Crest Theatre Co.

What We Need

There is no easy way to say this, so it's best to be direct. We need money. The actors and staff are volunteering on this project. With that said, we still need funds to secure a theatre and rehearsal space in midtown, pay a professional director, build a set and publicize the event. As of right now, we have put in as much money as we can on our own. To continue in finalizing this project and building a foundation for the theatre company- we need your help.

Your Impact

This project, and more specifically, this theatre company is about creating an opportunity. It’s about supporting a group of passionate artists, both new and professional, looking to take on works that strike a chord in them.  

Your impact, is the chance to give us the power to build a foundation so we can bring these works to life. Instead of searching for the right auditions, waiting by the phone for a call back or performing in unfulfilling projects, we want to get to work. It goes beyond just throwing a few extra bucks towards a project a friend is involved in. It’s the opportunity to give us a sustainable platform to continually create theatre on our own terms. You are crucial to our success. There is so much we want to say to you, but we’ll say the only thing worth saying...Thank you.

The Ivy Crest Acting Ensemble

Josh Atkinson


Daniel Deutsch


Camber Donahoe


Katherine Gage


Yulianna Garrido


Colleen Hart Huley


Emily Kaplan


Matt Magnusson


Jesse Pimentel

Nathan Shapiro


Alex Underwood


Other Ways You Can Help

We know that we are not all wealthy people and that's why we are here in the first place, but $5.00 or even just sharing this campaign with your network could go a long way. You’d be surprised at how far word of mouth advertising could get us. Whether it’s sharing our IndieGoGo campaign posts on social media or even just talking us up to your friends and family - we could use all the help we can get! Whatever you can give is immensely appreciated. To contribute by VENMO or personal check, please email IvyCrestTheatreCo@gmail.com


The Ivy Crest Theatre Co. Presents

Up, Down, Strange, Charmed, Beauty and Truth and North of Providence

By Edward Allan Baker

March 16-20th, 2016

Wednesday through Friday at 8:00

Saturday at 2:00 and 8:00

Sunday at 3:00

The Davenport Theatre

354 West 45th Street (Btw. 8th and 9th)

New York, NY 10036

Purchase Tickets Here
www.ivycrestnyc.com
story_txt:
We thank you all for your contributions to the Ivy Crest Theatre Co. Our campaign is over, but if you didn't get the opportunity to donate you can still do so here!

About Us:
The Ivy Crest Theatre Co. is a newly formed theatre ensemble with an exciting mix of established, professional and emerging theatre artists. Our ensemble includes an Oscar winning producer, teachers from two of the most reputable acting schools in the world, award winning directors and designers, and well trained actors at various points in their careers. The one thing that unifies us all is a dedication, passion and an unending study of our crafts. The Ivy Crest Theatre Co. is our way of creating a platform to get to work, creating compelling theatre on our own terms.
www.ivycrestnyc.com


Our Mission:

The Ivy Crest Theatre Co., founded in 2015, was developed with the initiative to provide professional quality theatre at an affordable price to the NY audience in intimate black box settings. Our core imperative is that the plays we produce resonate with both our artists and audience. It is our commitment to achieve this mission through underproduced forms of theatre, such as one acts or short plays, new works and revivals of Off-Broadway plays. As an NYC theatre company, it is also our deeply held belief that our work should be as diverse as the city itself- providing a platform for women and minority writers but also to focus on works that range from blue to white collar struggles. As to the type of stories we want to tell, Faulkner said it best "the problems of the human heart, in conflict with itself."
