story:
The Necessity of Atheism by Sean Lang @ Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2016

What it's all about

Hello and thank you for taking a look at this project. 

You're probably wondering why there's a French flag on an apple. 

The Necessity of Atheism by Sean Lang is a farce about the young poet Percy Shelley. Set during the height of the Napoleonic Wars (hence the flag), it sees Shelley distributing his new and rather controversial pamphlet asking for proof of God around the University of Oxford, attracting the attention of the less than sympathetic Lord Eldon. This is a boisterous comedy inspired by the exuberant cartoonists of the time. 

But what about the apple I hear you ask? Well we don't want to give the game away but the apple is a key part of the hilarity of this play. 

            

At the helm of this project is myself, the director, Sabrina Poole. I began directing in my first year of university with a 1920's adaptation of Oscar Wilde's 'The Importance of Being Earnest. Since then I have gone on to direct a variety of plays from Restoration Drama to new modern writing. 'The Necessity of Atheism' is a play very close to my heart. I played Shelley in the original all-female 2013 production which received a very positive response in Cambridge and Oxford, including multiple nominations in the Cambridge Drama Festival. This play was one of the best I have ever been part of and I am thrilled to have the opportunity to present it again. I have on board a team of enthusiastic and dedicated actors and a talented technician. For both them and myself this is a fantastic opportunity and we want to be able to make the most of it. Which is where you come in. 

 

                             

Your Support

We are incredibly grateful for any kind of support but taking the show up to the Fringe is an expensive venture. We're looking to raise around £2000 to cover the venue hire costs and to subsidise the actors' accommodation so that they can fully enjoy all that the Fringe has to offer. 

In return for your support we can offer perks for each amount, from personalised thank you cards to boxes of handmade apple themed sweet treats which will include; apple cookies, apple flapjacks, and marzipan apples. (Please do let us know if you have any dietary requirements). 

* Please note due to an editorial error for the £50 donation perk you are unable to enter your address for delivery. We will contact you on the supplied email when you place the order to get the delivery address. Apologies for the inconvenience. 

We'll also be running a raffle at our Norwich preview on July 17th at the Maddermarket Theatre.

                 

About the author

Sean Lang is a Cambridge based playwright and author, and a senior lecturer in History at Anglia Ruskin University. His plays are often produced through his theatre company Anglia Ruskin Creative, with whom I have had the honour of working with since 2012.
With Anglia Ruskin Creative, Sean's plays have received multiple wins and nominations at the Sawston, Cambridge, and Haverhill drama festivals, particularly in the Best New Play category. 
More information about Sean and his plays can be found on his website - http://seanlangtheatre.com

Other Ways You Can Help

As well as monetary support, there are more ways to help us:

You can like us on Facebook and follow us on twitter (links below) - the bigger our profiles the more people we can engage with.

You can come and see the show. As well as our stint in Edinburgh, we'll be performing in Norwich in July. More details can be found on our social media pages. 

If you think you may have something else that may help us in terms of rehearsal spaces in Norwich, materials/props, or perhaps something that will help us promote the show then please do get in touch.

story:
Bref résumé

Starshit est une pièce de théâtre co-écrite par Jonathan Caron et Julie Renault, deux comédiens et auteurs de la relève, qui sera présentée du 5 au 23 avril 2016 à la salle Jean-Claude Germain du Centre du Théâtre d’Aujourd’hui à Montréal MAIS AUSSI à l’automne 2017 à l’Agora des arts de Rouyn-Noranda et au Théâtre du Rift de Ville-Marie, en Abitibi-Témiscamingue.


SYNOPSIS

Bienvenue chez Starshit ! Une usine à café où l’on rencontre une faune d’employés – disciples et porte-étendards de l’entreprise – dont le seul fait de travailler pour cette corporation est en soi un privilège : une adhésion quasi totale, une famille reconstituée, un mode de vie, un amour du café exponentiel !

Texte fantaisiste où l’on fait la satire d’un dévouement corporatif total, Starshit est une critique de la société performante à travers des personnages qui ne sont pas de méchants financiers, mais de jeunes employés payés 10 $ l’heure.


ENTRE LES RÉGIONS ET LES GRANDS CENTRES

Starshit est une co-production du Théâtre du Tandem, établi depuis une vingtaine d’années e  Abitibi-Témiscamingue, et du Théâtre en Quec’Part qui vient tout juste de naître. C’est aussi un projet d’entraide où le relais se fait entre l’expérience et l’apprentissage du milieu artistique professionnel.

Le Théâtre du Tandem veut le porte-voix de l’imaginaire des artistes de l’Abitibi-Témiscamingue, ainsi qu’un espace de rencontre entre le milieu artistique régional et d’autres créateurs du Québec et du Canada.

Le Théâtre en Quec’Part s’assure de garder la relève vivante en région, et de la nomadiser afin qu’elle ne se rouille jamais dans l’acquis, tout en s’assurant de faire le même travail dans les grands centres. Elle axe ainsi la création vers la coopération et l’enrichissement mutuel.


 Ce dont nous avons besoin 

Nous avons l’appui du Tandem, du programme Jeunes Volontaires et de quelques autres partenaires financiers ainsi que trois soirées bénéfices derrière la cravate, mais il nous manque un dernier coup de pouce pour produire un spectacle de cette envergure. Chaque geste compte. Un 25$, un 50$ ou un 100$ contribue à payer:

-La salle du Centre du Théâtre d’aujourd’hui (15 soirs + entrée en salle)

-Les techniciens

-Le matériel de décor

-Les costumes

-Les éclairages

-Les artistes (Concepteurs, comédiens, metteur en scène, conseiller dramaturgique, …)

-Le matériel promotionnel (affiches, flyers, captations vidéos, … )

-Les frais de tournée et de ses préparatifs

-Ect!

Il ne manque que la dernière petite gorgée de café pour bien attaquer la première série de représentations et vous donner le meilleur des spectacles qui soit! Objectif de 7 000$ atteint ou pas, ces fonds seront judicieusement investis dans le projet.


Ce que vous obtenez

Donner à Starshit vous permet d'intégrer l'entreprise petit à petit pour peut-être devenir un célèbre barista habitant Starshit City! Pour vous remercier, la maison mère vous a préparer des petits cadeaux comme: 

  • 10$ La reconnaissance éternelle de la compagnie et de son équipe
  • 25$ Une photo personnalisé de l'équipe qui te remercie et la chanson thème de l'entreprise à mettre comme sonnerie ou réveil-matin
  • 50$ Un ensemble de café gourmets à déguster afin de développer tes goûts
  • 100$ Un tablier rouge à l'effigie de Starshit, pareil à un vrai barista de chez Starshit
  • 300$ Une paire de billets pour aller voir le spectacle, accompagnée d'une visite VIP des coulisses du spectacle en compagnie de l'équipe Starshit
  • 500$Une toile à thématique Café réalisé par nul autre que Jonathan Caron


L'impact

Contribuer au succès de Starshit, c’est permettre à de jeunes artistes de s’accomplir et de produire leur première création dans un théâtre institutionnel, entourés par des gens qui ont de l'expertise dans le domaine. Contribuer à la réussite de Starshit, c’est participer à un acte de rassemblement entre les régions du Québec et ses grands centres. Contribuer à Starshit, c’est aussi permettre la création d’un excellent spectacle auquel vous pourrez assister qui changera peut-être votre perception des choses.


Notre équipe

Les artistes:

Texte - Jonathan Caron et Julie Renault

Interprétation - Jonathan Caron, Julie Renault, Martine Pype-Rondeau et Karine Berthelot

Mise en scène - Luc Bourgeois

Conseiller Dramaturgique - Simon Boudreault

Assistance à la mise en scène et direction de production - Andrée-Anne Garneau

Direction technique Montréal - Charles-Antoine Bertrand-Fontaine

Éclairages et direction technique Abitibi-Témiscamingue - Lyne Rioux

Conception sonore - Habib Zekri

Scénographie et conception de costumes - Noemi Paquette

Régie et aide à la direction de production - Caroline Daigle


Les producteurs:

Théâtre du Tandem - Hélène Bacquet

Théâtre en Quec'Part -  Mélissa Delage, Hugo Boutillette, Julie Renault


 D'autres façons d'aider

- Venez voir le show, parlez-en, partagez l’information, amenez vos amis et votre famille au théâtre!

- Partagez la campagne Indiegogo sur votre page facebook!



Le théâtre en Quec’Part et le théâtre du Tandem, ainsi que toute l’équipe de Starshit vous remercie.
story_txt:
Bref résumé

Starshit est une pièce de théâtre co-écrite par Jonathan Caron et Julie Renault, deux comédiens et auteurs de la relève, qui sera présentée du 5 au 23 avril 2016 à la salle Jean-Claude Germain du Centre du Théâtre d’Aujourd’hui à Montréal MAIS AUSSI à l’automne 2017 à l’Agora des arts de Rouyn-Noranda et au Théâtre du Rift de Ville-Marie, en Abitibi-Témiscamingue.





SYNOPSIS


Bienvenue chez Starshit ! Une usine à café où l’on rencontre une faune d’employés – disciples et porte-étendards de l’entreprise – dont le seul fait de travailler pour cette corporation est en soi un privilège : une adhésion quasi totale, une famille reconstituée, un mode de vie, un amour du café exponentiel !


Texte fantaisiste où l’on fait la satire d’un dévouement corporatif total, Starshit est une critique de la société performante à travers des personnages qui ne sont pas de méchants financiers, mais de jeunes employés payés 10 $ l’heure.



ENTRE LES RÉGIONS ET LES GRANDS CENTRES


Starshit est une co-production du Théâtre du Tandem, établi depuis une vingtaine d’années e  Abitibi-Témiscamingue, et du Théâtre en Quec’Part qui vient tout juste de naître. C’est aussi un projet d’entraide où le relais se fait entre l’expérience et l’apprentissage du milieu artistique professionnel.


Le Théâtre du Tandem veut le porte-voix de l’imaginaire des artistes de l’Abitibi-Témiscamingue, ainsi qu’un espace de rencontre entre le milieu artistique régional et d’autres créateurs du Québec et du Canada.


Le Théâtre en Quec’Part s’assure de garder la relève vivante en région, et de la nomadiser afin qu’elle ne se rouille jamais dans l’acquis, tout en s’assurant de faire le même travail dans les grands centres. Elle axe ainsi la création vers la coopération et l’enrichissement mutuel.


 Ce dont nous avons besoin 

Nous avons l’appui du Tandem, du programme Jeunes Volontaires et de quelques autres partenaires financiers ainsi que trois soirées bénéfices derrière la cravate, mais il nous manque un dernier coup de pouce pour produire un spectacle de cette envergure. Chaque geste compte. Un 25$, un 50$ ou un 100$ contribue à payer:


-La salle du Centre du Théâtre d’aujourd’hui (15 soirs + entrée en salle)
-Les techniciens
-Le matériel de décor
-Les costumes
-Les éclairages
-Les artistes (Concepteurs, comédiens, metteur en scène, conseiller dramaturgique, …)
-Le matériel promotionnel (affiches, flyers, captations vidéos, … )
-Les frais de tournée et de ses préparatifs
-Ect!


Il ne manque que la dernière petite gorgée de café pour bien attaquer la première série de représentations et vous donner le meilleur des spectacles qui soit! Objectif de 7 000$ atteint ou pas, ces fonds seront judicieusement investis dans le projet.


Ce que vous obtenez
Donner à Starshit vous permet d'intégrer l'entreprise petit à petit pour peut-être devenir un célèbre barista habitant Starshit City! Pour vous remercier, la maison mère vous a préparer des petits cadeaux comme: 

10$ La reconnaissance éternelle de la compagnie et de son équipe
25$ Une photo personnalisé de l'équipe qui te remercie et la chanson thème de l'entreprise à mettre comme sonnerie ou réveil-matin

50$ Un ensemble de café gourmets à déguster afin de développer tes goûts
100$ Un tablier rouge à l'effigie de Starshit, pareil à un vrai barista de chez Starshit
300$ Une paire de billets pour aller voir le spectacle, accompagnée d'une visite VIP des coulisses du spectacle en compagnie de l'équipe Starshit
500$Une toile à thématique Café réalisé par nul autre que Jonathan Caron



L'impact

Contribuer au succès de Starshit, c’est permettre à de jeunes artistes de s’accomplir et de produire leur première création dans un théâtre institutionnel, entourés par des gens qui ont de l'expertise dans le domaine. Contribuer à la réussite de Starshit, c’est participer à un acte de rassemblement entre les régions du Québec et ses grands centres. Contribuer à Starshit, c’est aussi permettre la création d’un excellent spectacle auquel vous pourrez assister qui changera peut-être votre perception des choses.


Notre équipe

Les artistes:


Texte - Jonathan Caron et Julie Renault


Interprétation - Jonathan Caron, Julie Renault, Martine Pype-Rondeau et Karine Berthelot


Mise en scène - Luc Bourgeois


Conseiller Dramaturgique - Simon Boudreault


Assistance à la mise en scène et direction de production - Andrée-Anne Garneau




Direction technique Montréal - Charles-Antoine Bertrand-Fontaine


Éclairages et direction technique Abitibi-Témiscamingue - Lyne Rioux


Conception sonore - Habib Zekri


Scénographie et conception de costumes - Noemi Paquette


Régie et aide à la direction de production - Caroline Daigle

Les producteurs:
Théâtre du Tandem - Hélène Bacquet
Théâtre en Quec'Part -  Mélissa Delage, Hugo Boutillette, Julie Renault






 D'autres façons d'aider


- Venez voir le show, parlez-en, partagez l’information, amenez vos amis et votre famille au théâtre!
- Partagez la campagne Indiegogo sur votre page facebook!






Le théâtre en Quec’Part et le théâtre du Tandem, ainsi que toute l’équipe de Starshit vous remercie.

story:
"Music-Hall" follows the story of a small troupe in one of the oldest professions in the world -- the theatre.  In this beautiful play by Jean-Luc Lagarce, the audience is invited into the innermost thoughts, triumphs and tragedies of La Fille, Boy 1 and Boy 2 in their vagabond, theatrical life.  American actress, Jackie Sanders, French Actor François Baron and Italian actor Jacoppo Rampini will perform this play in French as Lagarce wrote it with English supertitles, making it as easy to follow as a French film with subtitles.  

Director Roxane Revon and several members of the Diffractions team will be translating this Lagarce favorite into English for the first time to provide the supertitles with the permission of Lagarce's estate.  We are honored to be the first company to bring this beautiful work to New York City.  

A French director at the helm of an international cast performing in French with English supertitles in New York City promises to be a truly innovative and exciting theatrical eventfor New York City.  Diffractions hopes that the excitement and support that follows the many successful "French films with English subtitles" festivals in NYC every year will translate to excitement for live French theatre as well.  

Please consider supporting this endeavor -- Diffractions is really looking forward to bringing this international cast and crew together for Jean-Luc Lagarce's "Music-Hall" - in French with English supertitles in New York City.  

This project is very ambitious and more than ever we need your help to make it a success. To support us, make a spontaneous tax-deductible donation.

We seek your generous support to help with the following:

  • Cost of renting rehearsal space
  • Covering the theater rental plus insurance costs
  • Covering equipment insurance premiums and rental of technical equipment
  • Publicity and expanding outreach to the global community
  • Materials to realize ambitious costumes, lighting, and video design
  • Creating live-able stipends for our creative artists

MUSIC-HALL will be presented in May 2014 (shows in French with English supertitles). 

Every donator will be mentionned in our programme and will be able to follow our rehearsal process (with singing, tap dancing and acting tips).

Thank you very much for your generous support !

story:
About the performance

‘But the city was there, close to me, looking over my shoulder, holding up the prism through which I understood the world…’ (Ahdaf Soueif)

My City… My Revolution… explores a woman’s fractured journey where the act of walking triggers the multiple narratives engrained in the fabric of a city… where a city becomes the site of displacement and alternative revolutions.

In a multilayered form of storytelling that synthesizes physical performance, visuals, text and video, My City… My Revolution… weaves autobiographical and historical narratives that stem from the experience of an Egyptian woman living a revolution that redefines her relationship to two cities: London and Cairo. Parallel stories then unfold and contrast, hers and others’, speaking of home, the city, longing and belonging, and the melancholic tension of a dual existence, where urban, psychological and cultural geographies are doubled and juxtaposed.

Based on the text “Cairo: My City, My Revolution” by Nesreen Hussein, published in Performance and the Global City. Eds. Kim Solga and D.J. Hopkins (Palgrave 2013). This is the performance’s first stage of development, conceived by Nesreen Hussein in collaboration with performer Vanio Papadelli and filmmaker Mohamed Goely.

The performance opens at Rich Mix in London on 23rd January 2015. 

After this first performance, we aim to develop the piece into a wider collaborative project that forms a platform to engage with the broad questions of 'home', belonging and displacement and how we relate to the city. 

We also aim to present the work in Cairo during 2015.

(You can follow the project's updates via its Facebook page, or this related Twitter account).

What We Need

We are currently raising funds to cover the production costs of the first phase of the project leading to the performance at Rich Mix on January 23rd. 
In addition, we also wish to cover the basic fees for the artists participating in this project and who are contributing with their time, expertise, creative input and labour.


Why You Should Support My City... My Revolution... 

- It's a new work in development that uses a personal story as a vehicle to carry forward broader narratives around issues of wider significance.
- It's an on going project with aims and potentials that go beyond the immediate demands of a one-off performance, such as establishing a network of participants who are interested in exploring the themes raised by using a variety of mediums.
- It's the starting point of an extended collaboration between young artists who are redefining their artistic practice and opening up their cultural and artistic frames of reference.


What You Will Get

In addition to the joy of supporting an up and coming group of young artists to realise their ambitious project, for any amount of donation you make, you will receive a "thank you" note in addition to being acknowledged in the event's publicity for your generous support. 
The more you donate, the bigger the rewards! Check the "Perks" section on the right side of this page for more details on what each donation category entails, which includes signed copies of the performance's official poster, tickets to the performance in London, and more! The amount of donation is open for you to decide, nothing is too small!


Creative Team

Nesreen Hussein (UK / Egypt): A theatre artist and scholar focusing on exploring the intersection between visual arts and theatre. She has worked internationally with a number practitioners, including Improbable theatre (London and New York), Nagy Shaker (Cairo), Richard Gough (Aberystwyth and Chichester), Opera East Productions (touring production) and Vanio Papadelli (London and Alexandria). She studied Fine Arts and Scenography at the Faculty of Fine Arts in Cairo, and obtained a PhD in Drama and Theatre from Royal Holloway, University of London. She is currently a Lecturer in Contemporary Theatre at Middlesex University in London. In 2011, Nesreen received two awards for emerging scholars from the International Federation for Theatre Research.
Vanio Papadelli (UK / Greece): A movement/physical theatre performer, maker and teacher (Goldsmiths and Rose Bruford College). Through professional experience and a Practice-based PhD she has been developing a practice called Attunement that draws mainly on Contact Improvisation, release-based techniques, and Eastern European Laboratory theatre. Vanio has led and participated in performances and residencies in Greece, UK, Italy, Poland, Germany, Egypt and Lebanon.

story:
'The Butterfly Project'

Nana Woo comes from Korea. When she was 21 years old, she started 'The Butterfly Project'out of her passionate belief that human beings can transform themselves."Inside the cocoon of ourselves we have to dream of what we might one day become.The butterflies that I create have become for people a picture of this unfolding. If you do not follow your dreams what will happen to you?  Keep your dream in your heart!" To see more 'The Butterfly Project'

'Eurythmy'

After a long journey, she met Eurythmy and knew at once that this was what she was meant to do in this world. 

Eurythmy is a Movement art which helps people to reconnect with themselves, others and Nature. Eurythmy helps people to overcome their separateness and to sense the space around them. It helps people unfold the potential inside themselves. Eurythmy works with live music and poetry. Eurythmists are dancers who make the sounds of music or poetry appear before your eyes through the movement of their bodies. They work as performing artists, as movement therapists, as teachers in schools and socially in many contexts. Eurythmy performance "Die vier Jahreszeiten" Sommer 3

'Social Eurythmy'

Nana’s dream is to work with Social Eurythmy which explores the relationship between individuals and community, through moving together. This gives them a living experience of what is happening between them. Social Eurythmy Flashmob

Nana has been studying Eurythmy at Peredur Arts Centre (Peredur Eurythmy) in West Sussex, UK for three years. She has one more year to complete her training which will give her a BA in Performing Arts and a Certificate to teach Eurythmy in schools. In order to complete this last year she needs your help. Coming from outside of Europe, she is prevented from working and creating an income to pay for her tuition and accommodation fees. Your support to be able to finish this training and to keep her dream of bringing her skills where they are needed in the world, especially to her home land, will be greatly appreciated. Please give what you can to help her pass on these gifts of transformation to others.

Budget for 2014 to 2015

- School Fees :   £1300 per term for 3 terms = £ 3900

(for Eurythmy training at Peredur Arts Centre)

Monday to Friday,  start 8:45am till 4:30, 5:30pm. Full time course

                         Autumn Term 2014       22 Sep - 18 Dec

                         Spring Term 2015          12 Jan -  26 Mar

                         Summer Term 2015      20 Apr - 9 Jul

- Accommodation Fees:   £90 per week for 43weeks = £ 3870  

- Eurythmy training plus accommodation = £ 7770


An African Elegy

We are the miracles that God made
To taste the bitter fruit of Time.
We are precious.
And one day our suffering
Will turn into the wonders of the earth.

There are things that burn me now
Which turn golden when I am happy.
Do you see the mystery of our pain?
That we bear poverty
And are able to sing and dream sweet things

And that we never curse the air when it is warm
Or the fruit when it tastes so good
Or the lights that bounce gently on the waters?
We bless things even in our pain.
We bless them in silence.

That is why our music is so sweet.
It makes the air remember.
There are secret miracles at work
That only Time will bring forth.
I too have heard the dead singing.

And they tell me that
This life is good
They tell me to live it gently
With fire, and always with hope.
There is wonder here

And there is surprise
In everything the unseen moves.
The ocean is full of songs.
The sky is not an enemy.
Destiny is our friend.

 -- Ben Okri

story:
Seguici anche su: http://www.macaomilano.org/workcenter/

English version

LA RESIDENZA DI WORKCENTER A MACAO

Il primo incontro tra Macao e Workcenter risale allo scorso maggio durante il Festival Folle Agire Urbano a Macao. Il Workcenter, con la sezione guidata da Mario Biagini - l'Open Program, porta per la prima volta a Milano un suo spettacolo. La musica, i movimenti, le voci del Workcenter ci contaminano; il clima di quella serata, l’energia, la vitalità e la delicatezza ci incantano. In luglio, dopo averci invitato a Pontedera per vedere il loro lavoro, arriva a Macao anche il team guidato da Thomas Richards. Nasce così, attraverso reciproche ospitalità, un progetto comune: una residenza del Workcenter a Macao, dal 3 al 12 ottobre 2014, con tre spettacoli (I Am America, Electric Party Songs, The Hydden Sayings), un workshop (Azione intenzionale e comportamento organico), la proiezione di alcuni documentari (Action in Aya Irini, Dies Iraæ: the Preposterous Theatrum Interioris Show) e una tavola rotonda sul tema dell'incontro tra ricerca teatrale e politica.

Durante la residenza abbiamo raccolto immagini, note, frammenti di lavoro e di vita. Vogliamo infatti che questa esperienza possa confluire nella produzione di un libro con testi originali di Ginsberg, interviste, appunti di lavoro, note, foto e video scaricabili tramite QR-code. Un racconto corale per dare voce a un’esperienza realmente condivisa, che non termina con la fine dello spettacolo. E’ un progetto ambizioso. Macao non ha finanziatori né produttori, e abbiamo bisogno del tuo aiuto per realizzarlo.

WORKCENTER ATTRAVERSA GINSBERG

Il Workcenter risiede dal 1986 in Toscana, a Pontedera. Vi si stabilisce per volontà di Jerzy Grotowski, regista che ha tracciato linee fondamentali nella ricerca teatrale del secondo novecento. Da uno dei suoi storici spettacoli, “Apocalypsis cum figuris”, Ermanno Olmi realizza nel 1979 un celebre documentario. Articolato in due team di lavoro, il Focused Research Team in Art as Vehicle guidato da Thomas Richards e l’Open Program guidato da Mario Biagini, il Workcenter porta ancora oggi la propria ricerca artistica in tutto il mondo. Nel 2001 ritira al Piccolo Teatro di Milano il prestigioso Premio Ubu per lo spettacolo “One Breath Left”.

«Siamo un gruppo di artisti provenienti da molti paesi diversi. Dal Nord America, il Sudamerica, l’Europa; abbiamo radici europee e africane. La ricerca del Workcenter, sin dagli inizi, è stata un’indagine su questioni di confini e barriere. Cos’è mio? Cos’è nostro? Esiste qualcosa che appartiene a tutti noi? I nostri desideri hanno qualcosa in comune?  Hanno a che vedere con la libertà? (...) Abbiamo portato avanti per oltre 25 anni un lavoro approfondito sui canti dell’Africa e della sua diaspora (...). Oggi la nostra ricerca ci ha portato allo stesso tempo come un ritorno e un movimento in avanti in America (...). Salutiamo con gratitudine i nostri antenati e, come Ginsberg, traiamo ispirazione dalle radici del jazz, blues, rock e punk”                                                             Mario Biagini, attore e regista di OpenProgram/Workcenter

STARE A MACAO

A Milano, in viale Molise 68, c’è lo spazio dismesso dell’ex-Borsa del Macello, edificio esemplare in stile Liberty. In questi spazi sono attivi da oltre due anni tavoli di studio, lavoro, progettazione e sperimentazione sui diversi linguaggi della cultura e delle arti contemporanee, che costituiscono anche un laboratorio di partecipazione e di cittadinanza attiva. La produzione indipendente e in Creatives Commons, lo studio e la sperimentazione di nuove economie, la condivisione del proprio tempo e dei propri saperi, sono alcuni dei rami della ricerca sviluppata a Macao.

La residenza di Workcenter è parte di questo continuo lavoro di sperimentazione relativo a modelli e forme di produzione e distribuzione culturale, generati dall'incontro di cittadini che mettono in comune tempo e competenze.

“Quando siamo arrivati a Macao abbiamo capito che lo spazio è molto flessibile e che vi si potrebbero fare tutti i nostri spettacoli. Questo è interessante, perché non accade spesso che un solo posto sia così mobile e accogliente. (…) Al Workcenter cerchiamo una certa qualità in tutto quello che facciamo. Questi è legato al fare dell’attore, ma non solo; è anche parte della vita.(…) Dico questo perché a Macao mi è sembrato di percepire qualcosa di simile; il modo in cui eravate disponibili durante tutti i giorni… non stavate facendo finta di essere disponibili ed attenti.Lo eravate davvero. Questa è la stessa differenza tra un attore che recita e un attore che fa: al primo non credi, al secondo sì.”                                                                                                Alejandro Tomàs Rodriguez, attore di OpenProgram/Workcenter

NowHere. RESIDENZE ATTIVE

Sulla facciata di Macao c'è una scritta: NOWHERE. Puoi leggerla come “da nessuna parte”, ma anche come “qui adesso”.

NOWHERE è un progetto aperto di residenze artistiche, di cui l'Open Program costituisce la prima tappa. E’ prima di tutto un incontro tra persone che condividono il desiderio di un luogo dedicato alla produzione culturale, alla convergenza tra storie, in uno spazio che si concede a diversi linguaggi e forme artistiche.

COSA VOGLIAMO FARE

La produzione di un libro e di alcuni video sull’esperienza di questo incontro nasce dal desiderio di diffondere un’opera collettiva, rendendola tangibile, dando voce alle persone che l’hanno vissuta, per condividerla oltre il tempo della residenza. Questo lavoro si sviluppa in diverse fasi, a partire dalla residenza di Open Program a Macao, filmata integralmente e documentata con appunti, interviste e fotografie. Questi materiali, una volta elaborati e post prodotti, verranno inseriti in un libro, che conterrà un QR-code tramite il quale accedere ai video.

Poter raccontare efficacemente tutto questo è importante, non solo per la qualità del lavoro portato dagli artisti di Open Program, ma anche per diffondere il più possibile e con mezzi adeguati il progetto delle residenze artistiche di cui questa esperienza costituisce il primo passaggio. Desideriamo infatti che a questa seguano altre residenze, con attori, musicisti e artisti che vorranno avvicinarsi ad una forma sperimentale di produzione culturale, aprendosi ad una dimensione di apertura e confronto.

Ringraziamenti

Ringraziamo per il sostegno alla campagna: Stefano Bollani | Federico Fiumani Tiziana Ghiglioni | Têtes de Bois | Andrea Marinelli

Ringraziamo per i consigli ed il supporto: Renata M. Molinari | Marco Liberatore

Partner: Cinema Beltrade | IlSaggiatore

Con il patrocinio di: ZKM, Center for Art and Media, Karlsruhe | DAMS di Torino | Progetto S.A.B. Students Arts Box del Dipartimento di Studi Umanistici dell’Università di Pavia | CIT, Centro di cultura e iniziativa teatrale “Mario Apollonio” | Master Azioni e Interazioni Pedagogiche attraverso la Narrazione e l’Educazione alla Teatralità, Facoltà di Scienze della Formazione dell’Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore di Milano| CRT Teatro-Educazione

************************************

WORKCENTER’S RESIDENCY IN MACAO

The first meeting between Macao and Workcenter dates back to last May during the Festival “Folle – Agire Urbano” (Crowds – Urban Action) organized by Macao.

Workcenter, and in particular the section led by Mario Biagini, brought one of its shows to Macao for the first time. The Music, movements and voices of Workcenter were infectious; the atmosphere of that evening, its energy, vitality and delicacy enchanted us. In July, after the invitation to discover their work in Pontedera, the team led by Thomas Richards also visits Macao. Through reciprocal hospitality, a common project was born: Workcenter’s residency in Macao, from the 3rd to the 12th October 2014, inculding: three shows (I Am America | Electric Party Songs  | The Hydden Sayings), a workshop (Intentional action and organic behavior), documentaries screening (Action in Aya Irini, Dies Iraæ: the Preposterous Theatrum Interioris Show), a round table about the relationship between theater and politics.

During the residency, you will happen to meet the promoters of the project, photo cameras, video cameras, microphones and notebooks, hunting for images, notes, fragments of work and life. In fact, we want this experience to lead to the publication of a book containing original texts by Ginsberg, interviews, working notes, images and downloadable video clips through a QR-code. A choral tale to give voice to a truly shared experience that does not end when the show is over. It is an ambitious project, Macao has no donors or producers, and we need your help to make it real.

WORKCENTER TRAVERSES GINSBERG

Workcenter has resided since 1986 in Pontedera, Tuscany. Here it was established by Jerzy Grotowski, a director who deeply influenced theatrical research in the second half of the twentieth century. Based on one of his most important shows, “Apocalypsis cum figuris”, Ermanno Olmi produced a famous documentary in 1979. Structured in two different working teams, the Focused Research Team in Art as Vehicle led by Thomas Richards and the Open Program led by Mario Biagini, the Workcenter is still bringing his artistic research around the world.

In 2001, at Piccolo Teatro di Milano, received the prestigious Ubu award for the show “One Breath Left”.

"We are a group of artists coming from many different countries. From North America, South America and Europe, with European and African roots.
The Workcenter research, from its beginnings, has been an inquiry into questions of boundaries and borders. What is mine? What is ours? Does anything exist that belongs to all of us? Can our desires have something in common? Do they relate to freedom? At the Workcenter for more than 25 years we have carried out an in-depth work on songs from Africa and its diaspora. Today our research has led us – simultaneously as a return and a move forward – to America. It is with gratitude that we salute our ancestors and, like Ginsberg, draw inspiration from the roots of jazz, blues, rock and punk”                                                                      Mario Biagini, actor and director of OpenProgram/Workcenter

STAYING IN MACAO

In viale Molise 68, Milan, there is the disused space of the ex-slaughterhouse’s Exchange, a perfect example of Art Nouveau in Milan. In these spaces working groups have been operating for two years. They research, design and experiment on the different languages of culture and of contemporary arts and constitute a laboratory for participation and active citizenship. Independent production (and) in Creative Commons, the study and the experimentation of new economies, the sharing of one’s own time and knowledge, are just some of the lines of research that Macao has developed.

Workcenter’s residency is part of this ongoing experimentation focused on the models of cultural production and distribution, generated through the coming together of citizens who share their time and competences.

“When we arrived at Macao we realized that the space was extremely versatile and that it could host all of our shows. This is interesting, because it is not common that one single space is so mobile and hospitable (…) In the Workcenter we seek a certain level of quality in everything we do. Concerning our job, this means that we must be credible in what we do (…) These are specific elements linked to an actor’s work, but not only; they also are part of life (…) I say this because in Macao I have perceived something similar; the way in which you were helpful each day… you were not pretending to be helpful and careful. You really were. This is the same difference between an actor who recites and an actor who acts: you don’t believe the first, the second you do."
Alejandro Tomàs Rodriguez, actor of OpenProgram/Workcenter

NowHere. ACTIVE RESIDENCIES

On Macao’s facade there is a word: NOWHERE. You can read it as “in no place”, but also as “now here”.

NOWHERE is an open project of artistic residencies, of which Open Program constitutes the first stage. It is, first of all, an encounter among people who desire a space devoted to cultural production, to the convergence among stories, a space open to different languages and artistic forms.

WHAT WE WANT TO DO

The production of a book and the videos about the experience of this meeting stems from the desire to disseminate a collective work, making it tangible, giving voice to the people who have lived it, to share it beyond the limited time of the residency. This work is developed in different phases, starting from Open Program’s residency in Macao, integrally video recorded and documented with notes, interviews and photographs. Once processed and post-produced, these materials will be collected in a book with a QR-code for accessing the video clips.

To be able to narrate all of this effectively is fundamental: not only for the quality of the artists of Open Program, but also to spread as much as possible and by appropriate means the active residencies’ program, of which this experience is the first stage. In fact, our desire is that more residencies will follow, with actors, musicians and artists willing to approach an experimental form of cultural production based on openness and dialogue.

Supporters

Thank you for supporting our self-funding campaign: Stefano Bollani | Federico Fiumani Tiziana Ghiglioni | Têtes de Bois | Andrea Marinelli

With thanks for the advice given during the project's development: Renata M. Molinari | Marco Liberatore

Partners: Cinema Beltrade | IlSaggiatore

Supported by: ZKM, Center for Art and Media, Karlsruhe | DAMS di Torino | Progetto S.A.B. Students Arts Box del Dipartimento di Studi Umanistici dell’Università di Pavia | CIT, Centro di cultura e iniziativa teatrale "Mario Apollonio" | Master Azioni e Interazioni Pedagogiche attraverso la Narrazione e l’Educazione alla Teatralità, Facoltà di Scienze della Formazione dell’Università Cattolica 


P.S. There is a little mistake in 50€'s perk. The book you get with this contribution is digital version, not printed one. We are sorry!

story:
Quick and Dirty Show Info!

When: Wednesday, May 24 and Thursday, May 25, 8pm
Where: The Lilypad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge, MA
Tickets: Donate $20 on THIS INDIEGOGO PAGE (check out the $20 donation levels to your right), or buy with CASH at the door. Those are your only options!

IMPORTANT: Seating is limited, so if you want a chair, come early!  Doors will open around 7:30. 

Why are we doing this?

When The Orange Menace was elected in November, we (Katie, Kathleen, and Anna) were disappointed in our country. And we knew it would be an attack on marginalized people: immigrants, people of color, disabled people, and women - and there are plenty of people who fall into more than one of those categories who would be scared. We knew we needed to do something, but what? Well, what we can do is sing. (We're not going to be much use in the post-apocalypse.) So we're organizing an evening of songs about women, sung by us (who are also women). And we're giving all the proceeds to All-Options Pregnancy Resource Center in Indiana. The ONLY WAY to get your tickets to the show is at the door or here on this page (see the $20 perks to your right), so donate today to secure your ticket for the show on Wednesday, May 24 or Thursday, May 25 at The Lilypad, 1353 Cambridge St. in Inman Square. 

What's this money for??

We want as much money as possible to go to the clinic, but there are costs involved in mounting even a small cabaret like this one. Expenses include:

  • $390 space rental
  • $150 musician payments
  • $100 printing costs
  • TBD: perks (the perks cost money to create, so this one depends on how many you want!)
  • All the rest: that's what we can give to the clinic!

Why All-Options Pregnancy Resource Center?

Well, part of the reason we chose this organization was that we are petty as hell, and since Mike Pence is from Indiana, we wanted to really get him where he literally lived. Additionally, the women of Indiana, frankly, need our help more than the gals here in Massachusetts, overall. All-Options Pregnancy Resource Center provides "support for unplanned pregnancy, miscarriage, infertility, abortion, adoption, or parenting," which really runs the gamut of women's health care. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not in the Boston area, you can still donate!

  • There are a few perk levels that don't include a ticket to the show - but DO include perks, in case you'd like a little thank-you for supporting us and All-Options Pregnancy Center. 
  • You can only buy tickets through this campaign - the Lilypad doesn't sell advance tickets. If you want a ticket to the show, donate at the $20 level (or buy at the door...if you want to risk it). 
  • And don't forget to share this campaign! 

Perks

If you want to help out, but can't come to the show, you can still donate - and get these fun gifts as a thank-you! (And if you can come to the show...you can still get the perks. Just donate again!)

Nasty Woman Pin

Show the world just how nasty you are with this sophisticated, devilish pin from nastywomanpins on Etsy.

Elizabeth Warren Candle

Candles are handmade, so variations may occur

Show your love for Massachusetts' senior senator with this classy candle.

Nevertheless, She Persisted Cross Stitch

Celebrate traditional women's work AND our hardworking women in the government with this cross stitch from House of Miranda.

Pussy Hat

Yes, I will literally make you a pussy hat in any color you choose. (Pink, though, right?

Awesome graphics generously donated by Kara Ebrahim.
story_txt:
Quick and Dirty Show Info!
When: Wednesday, May 24 and Thursday, May 25, 8pmWhere: The Lilypad, 1353 Cambridge St, Cambridge, MATickets: Donate $20 on THIS INDIEGOGO PAGE (check out the $20 donation levels to your right), or buy with CASH at the door. Those are your only options!
IMPORTANT: Seating is limited, so if you want a chair, come early!  Doors will open around 7:30. 
Why are we doing this?
When The Orange Menace was elected in November, we (Katie, Kathleen, and Anna) were disappointed in our country. And we knew it would be an attack on marginalized people: immigrants, people of color, disabled people, and women - and there are plenty of people who fall into more than one of those categories who would be scared. We knew we needed to do something, but what? Well, what we can do is sing. (We're not going to be much use in the post-apocalypse.) So we're organizing an evening of songs about women, sung by us (who are also women). And we're giving all the proceeds to All-Options Pregnancy Resource Center in Indiana. The ONLY WAY to get your tickets to the show is at the door or here on this page (see the $20 perks to your right), so donate today to secure your ticket for the show on Wednesday, May 24 or Thursday, May 25 at The Lilypad, 1353 Cambridge St. in Inman Square. 

What's this money for??
We want as much money as possible to go to the clinic, but there are costs involved in mounting even a small cabaret like this one. Expenses include:

$390 space rental
$150 musician payments
$100 printing costs
TBD: perks (the perks cost money to create, so this one depends on how many you want!)
All the rest: that's what we can give to the clinic!


Why All-Options Pregnancy Resource Center?
Well, part of the reason we chose this organization was that we are petty as hell, and since Mike Pence is from Indiana, we wanted to really get him where he literally lived. Additionally, the women of Indiana, frankly, need our help more than the gals here in Massachusetts, overall. All-Options Pregnancy Resource Center provides "support for unplanned pregnancy, miscarriage, infertility, abortion, adoption, or parenting," which really runs the gamut of women's health care.

story:
Short Summary

Pulp Productions: we are a small group of students and professionals, troubadours and tragedians, brought together by our shared vision of what theatre—in its organization and its presentation—ought to be. We are committed to an open, collaborative creative process, in which all are encouraged to share their ideas and listen earnestly to others in the building of character, craft, and authentic connection. We strive, above all, for truth. 

Our upcoming project is The Language Archive by Julia Cho, a contemporary play about the fallible nature of language. The story begins with a linguist named George who amidst his desire to archive dying languages becomes blind to what language is actually for. The play is a poetic, mythic and dreamlike unfolding of how language, at its essence, exists to say ‘I love you’; a heart breaking and life affirming play about the wounds created by trying to hold on to that which is fleeting.

This play illustrates the bravery needed to speak a language and the courage it takes to be truly understood. Language, in this play is said to be an act of faith. And what is theatre, if not also, a great act of faith.

Pulp Productions is currently unsponsored and unfunded, and depends entirely on the contributions of its members, as well as the generosity of people just like you. No theatre or performing arts company is able to survive off ticket sales alone. This is even more true for a budding ensemble like ours which strives to create exciting, fresh productions that are accessible to a wide range of audience. Our shows are either free or on a sliding scale with no one turned away due to lack of funds. This current production will be free and open to public.

The performance dates for The Language Archive are May 1, 2, 3rd, and 15, 16, 17th at The Evergreen State College Communications Building 332.

What We Need:

The break down of $1,000:

  • $480 for royalties: this covers royalties for 6 performances.
  • $445 for us to put toward building our set, purchasing props, and printing posters
  • $75 to cover Indiegogo's percentage of the funds raised

Stretch goals:

$1500:

  • the above plus:
  • stipends for the production team to cover the costs of travel, food donated for work days, etc.

$1700 +

  • the above plus:
  • support for future productions

Why should you support this production?

Pulp productions strives to offer creative, heartfelt performances to our community. We want to ensure that anyone who wishes to attend the performance can.

Whatever funds remain after the expenses of this show are saved to support future Pulp projects and performances. Production costs accrue before opening night, before tickets go "on sale," before this campaign ends. This production is possible due to the generosity of patrons of one of our previous productions. We hope to continue this pattern of one show supporting the creation of the next. Sustainability rather than profit.

We are not your average community theater. We do not have a theater and often bring you interesting performances in sometimes unexpected places. Our goal with each show is to tell a story, it may be a familiar one, with honesty and care and often a little bit of humor. 

* Photos are from past productions of Much Ado About Nothing and The Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? That's okay, you can still help!

  • Let others know about the campaign and the production.
  • If in the area, come see our show!

story:
Mavrik is an Israeli dance troupe for young adults in the Washington, D.C. area. Established in 2013, Mavrik performs classical Israeli dance pieces, as well as modern pieces to popular Israeli songs. 

We all love to dance and share our fun spirit, dance skills and high energy with others, but that comes at a price. We have each dedicated our own time, money and resources to Mavrik, including paying our own way to Boston for an annual Israeli Folkdance festival and buying our costumes.

We did some math and it looks like this year, each of us will need to spend at least $250. It would be great to not only decrease the amount each of us has to pay, but to set up a foundation for next year and the years to come. Our goal is to raise $3,000.  

Help donate today to set the foundation of Mavrik and help us spread our love of Israeli dance and culture. We couldn't do it without your support, so please donate today.

We couldn't do it without your support, so please donate today.

story:
There was a joke at Architecture School about resorting to 'interpretive dance' in design juries to disguise or distract from woefully inadequate work. The joke underscored the apparent futility of dance: dancing, as the Elvis Costello quote implies, could tell us nothing about architecture. Yet perhaps, unconsciously, we wanted to be wrong and yearned to fold like the facade, twist like the staircase and be still like the column. Deep down, we knew how wonderful it would be to dance about architecture and that if it were possible surely our buildings and places would be made better, more potent. All we needed was someone to guide us, someone to show us the way...

The 2014 National Architecture Conference Fringe Event Committee is proud to present:

'Dancing About Architecture'

- a dance performance commissioned especially for the 'Making: Fun - Public Forum' by the award winning Unkempt Dance.'Dancing About Architecture' is one component of the 'Making: Fun - Public Forum', a free and public event featuring a range of artforms and dialogue about how architecture and art come together.  

All of the funds raised in this campaign will go directly to Unkempt Dance members - Amy Wiseman, Carly Armstrong and Jess Lewis - for their time to choreograph, rehearse and perform 'Dancing About Architecture'. The performance will be  approximately 10 minutes in length promises to be creative, engaging and fun.

The best part of this campaign is that through your generous support you'll be creating a unique event for yourself and the public of Perth to experience when 'Dancing About Architecture'  is performed Friday 9 May from 7:00pm in the State Theatre Centre Courtyard.

Using crowd funding as the platform for 'Dancing About Architecture' is an exciting way to engage with the 'Making' theme of the National Architecture Conference. It provides a unique opportunity to the public - Perth locals and conference delegates alike - to be direct and indispensable participants in the 'Making' of this event. Through your generosity not only will you be supporting a fantastic Western Australian dance group and the 'Making Fun: Public Forum', you will be a 'Maker' and custodian of this event too.

We invite you to take a look through the 'perks' that are being offered.There are a range of possibilities for different people and interests including: T-shirts, dance classes and a chance to win National Conference Opening Party tickets. You could even take part in  extending the Dancing About Architecture project across the city by commissioning for yourself a personalised photo of Unkempt Dance interacting with your favourite public place in Perth.  

If you can't contribute any money - no worries! There are still ways you can help. Feel free to spread the word to people who you think would like to contribute to the campaign and of course you are always welcome to come see the performance and other events as part the 'Making:Fun - Public Forum'.

Images courtesy of Emma Fishwick

story:
The Play

It's Christmas Eve at Melanka's house, but the Revolution is in full swing on the streets of Kyiv.

This is the story of riot cop-­turned-­protester Vasyl and caroller-­turned-­activist Melanka. It unfolds through traditional Central and Eastern Ukrainian carols, ballads, and psalms, in a fully interactive setting that places the audience in the centre of the action as they enjoy a traditional Ukrainian Christmas dinner.

The Backstory

Counting Sheep is based on the first­hand experiences of playwrights Mark Marczyk and Marichka Kudriavtseva, who were on the Maidan and the Anti­Terrorist Operation (ATO) front in Ukraine in 2014. It stars members of local Juno­-nominated guerrilla-­folk party-­punks The Lemon Bucket Orkestra (runner-­up for Best Band in NOW Magazine's "Best of Toronto" poll).

The Music

Over the past 16 years, singer and ethnomusicologist Marichka Kudriavtseva has been traveling across Ukraine with the renowned folk ensemble Bozhychi, collecting centuries-old songs from the aging carriers of the world-famous Ukrainian vocal tradition. Now, she has come to Canada to teach the Lemon Bucket Orkestra this dying repertoire to help tell the story of the Revolution in her country. These are songs rarely heard even in contemporary Ukraine that will transport you to the plains villages of a country currently under siege.

The Videos

Thanks to camera phones and Youtube, this is the most documented revolution we have ever seen in the history of our planet. Marczyk and Kudriavtseva have spent the greater part of the last month collecting and editing these exact videos-- not high definition journalistic shots, but the stories of civilians shot from a wide variety of perspectives. We're going to blow up these gripping images onto three walls of St. Vladimir Institute, creating a fully immersive visual background that will help the audience see the Maidan Square through the eyes of the people.

The Dinner

With the help of local gourmet Shamez Amlani of La Palette, chef Dan Ihnatowycz has created a menu that will give our audience both a taste of a traditional Ukrainian Christmas Eve dinner-- Svjata Vecherja-- and a glimpse into the culinary experience of the revolution. Following the philosophy that the way we feed ourselves is directly related to our paths in life, Ihnatowycz's unique take on Ukrainian cuisine will help complete the journey for the intimate 30-person audience.

WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT!

To be able to give the audience the intimate immersive experience required to bring Marczyk and Kudriavtseva's script to life, we need a lot of community support. Just as in the Maidan Revolution, we are calling on people both within the Ukrainian community and outside it to help us tell the story. We've already gotten people to donate rehearsal space, projectors, and some costume elements, but we need a lot more if we're going to reach our goal of transforming the space.

Some of the things we need to cover:

  • tires
  • paper for masks (designed by Oksana Hawrylak of Kosa Kolektiv)
  • wood and metal for the table and benches (designed by Matt Cherkas)
  • plates and cutlery; pots and pans to cook in bulk
  • dinner ingredients in bulk
  • military fatigues
  • theatre lighting
  • lighting, sound technicians, stage manager
  • professional PR representative
  • airfare and lodging for Kudriavtseva
  • artist fees

IF you can help by donating/lending us any of these materials, we would be very grateful and will of course acknowledge your support in our program. Otherwise, you can support the project by pre-buying a ticket for the show, hiring us to come singing carols from the show AT YOUR HOUSE on December 24 or 25, or buying memorabilia from the show (beautiful art pieces).

Patriot Defence (patriotdefence.org)

It is important to us not only to tell the story of the Revolution and War in Ukraine, but to practically help organizations working full time to save lives. Patriot Defense is a Kyiv-based group that provides high quality first aid kits to medics and soldiers on the front lines of the Ukraine-Russia conflict as well as the necessary training in how to properly use them.

By supporting Counting Sheep, you will also be helping to save lives; a percentage of each dollar you give will go to this incredible organization.

Slava Ukraini!

story:
This year the New Orleans Fringe is highlighting Circus Arts, Paper Doll Militia, referred to as “The Sophisticated Circus of Now”, is one of the few companies selected out of the 136 who applied.  Now we need your help to get there.  Please join our community and support us bringing our show to New Orleans!



About Paper Doll Militia

Paper Doll Militia’s innovative approach to choreography and poignant use of theatricality have gained the company the reputation of being pioneers in original aerial theatre.  Their pieces seamlessly weave dynamic physicality, aerial arts, and visual theatre.  They emphasize the mixture of modern and vintage mediums as well as invented aerial apparatus to create their signature aesthetic; dreamy, whimsical, and dark.

Learn more about the company at paperdollmilitia.com


About LoopsEnd

The performers envelop you into their otherworldly environment where gravity is more a suggestion than a law. LoopsEnd features Paper Doll Militia’s most edgy and dynamic works to date, retaining the dark and magical quality the company is most known for. Appealing to audiences of all ages and languages, the show has it’s foundations in universal human concepts, told with enticing visuals and non-verbal unfolding narrative. With a diverse use of mediums and aerial apparatus, the stage is continuously transformed.  A true journey of the human spirit, highlighting the crossroads we face and the cyclical nature of oppression. LoopsEnd shows us a mirror of our own experiences reminding us of our collective grit and strength.


LoopsEnd features aerial theatre short stories Unchained and Crossroads, both of which had their world debut this summer at 7 Stages (Atlanta, GA) in the overwhelmingly successful run of Exposed: Humanity in Motion.  Unchained, with performers and creators Rain Anya and Sarah Bebe Holmes, was developed under the year long residency at Summerhall in. Edinburgh Scotland. Crossroads, directed by Rain Anya, members from the original cast from Liquid Sky ensemble in Atlanta GA. Liquid Sky is a thriving cirque arts entertainment company out of Atlanta GA. Learn more about the company at liquidskyent.com

Please help us take these pieces forwards!


Support Circus Arts in the US

Currently in the United States there is no public funding for the Circus Sector.  Many people are trying to change this through building awareness of circus.  A major contributor to this movement is the organization Circus Now.  Paper Doll Militia were one of the first companies in the United States to become members of this organization.  We are grateful for the work they are doing and thrilled that New Orleans Fringe is highlighting Circus Arts this year.  This will certainly add to the awareness of the incredible work being made in the United States right now.  By supporting Paper Doll Militia in going to New Orleans you are supporting Circus in the US and hopefully someday the next generation will benefit as well.  


If you want to help but don’t have the cash, don’t worry.  The stage is held together by nuts and bolts, but also hands and man hours.  An hour of your time can help us!


• Online Marketing with Social Media

• Helping us reach our audiences/research New Orleans Press

• Provide a place to stay for our cast in New Orleans

• Costume Mending

• And much more just email us if you have time and want to help

info@paperdollmilitia.com


And PS labor by hour is tax deductible as well.

Learn more about the company at liquidskyent.com Please help us take these pieces forwards!Support Circus Arts in the USCurrently in the United States there is no public funding for the Circus Sector.  Many people are trying to change this through building awareness of circus.  A major contributor to this movement is the organization Circus Now.  Paper Doll Militia were one of the first companies in the United States to become members of this organization.  We are grateful for the work they are doing and thrilled that New Orleans Fringe is highlighting Circus Arts this year.  This will certainly add to the awareness of the incredible work being made in the United States right now.  By supporting Paper Doll Militia in going to New Orleans you are supporting Circus in the US and hopefully someday the next generation will benefit as well.  If you want to help but don’t have the cash, don’t worry.  The stage is held together by nuts and bolts, but also hands and man hours.  An hour of your time can help us!• Online Marketing with Social Media• Helping us reach our audiences/research New Orleans Press• Provide a place to stay for our cast in New Orleans• Costume Mending• And much more just email us if you have time and want to helpinfo@paperdollmilitia.comAnd PS labor by hour is tax deductible as well.

story:
Company 2016 is going to Folkwang University to perform Shakespeare, and we need your help!

Folkwang? Shakespeare? What?

The Folkwang University of the Arts in Essen, Germany, is hosting an international Shakespeare Festival 2016 next April, and the Victorian College of the Arts' Co '16 is invited! We'll be sending our very own cast of William Shakespeare's 'Much Ado About Nothing' to perform in Germany alongside several other internationally recognised drama schools. 

We are a group of students studying Theatre Practice in the Victorian College of the Arts (VCA) at the University of Melbourne. The group of us are a diverse bunch - heralding from QLD, SA, NSW, WA, TAS, good ol' VIC and as far as Singapore, as well as our own German ex-pat - and we'll be putting our own Aussie acting chops to the test alongside schools from around the globe.

This is a fantastic opportunity, and we need support to get the cast there! That's why we're opening this up to our friends, family and the general public to help us raise funds for our flights before we jet-set off to a world of Ye Olde Bards and Bratwurst - a deadly mix!

Ye Olde Deal

Thankfully our accommodation and meals have already been sorted, but it will cost upwards of $11000 to cover the flights of 12 acting students.

In return for your wonderful support of this project, we pledge that we will;

A) Do you all damn well proud on an international stage.

B) Keep you updated on our progress, in rehearsal and during our time in Germany, showing you exactly what your support is doing for us as up-and-coming performers and Shakespearian actors.

C) Offer up a range of exciting perks depending on your level of support!

How your donation makes a hell of a difference

$11000 is a lofty goal, but it doesn't faze us. The fact is that ANY money we raise goes directly to alleviating the costs of individual students. Only 12 of us will be chosen to travel to Germany out of 27, and all 27 of us want to make sure that each and every person cast in 'Much Ado' can take up this opportunity, regardless of financial situation.

Every dollar raised means less dollars we are in debt. We're all students, and our course is an intensive 40 contact hours per week - that's a full time job in itself. A lot of us are working on the side to support ourselves but there's very little room for us to save for things like this. We appreciate absolutely ANY support you can spare us!

The Broader Campaign

We're raising money here, but we've also kicked ourselves into action beyond the computer screen - we have a number of events coming up in which we'll be performing or throwing a generally good time, during which you can donate your spare change, see the talent that will be going overseas and get to know us better!
Keep an eye on our campaign page for updates on events!

THANK-YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT, WE LOVE YOU!

Love, Co '16
xoxo

story: Fenix, the dance team I am very proud to be part of have won a bid to compete at the Dance Worlds competition in Florida 2016. This is a very big deal but the bid is unpaid therefore we have to raise all funds to enter ourselves! It's £250 each just to enter along with all the other costs of getting to America etc. this team and competition means the world to me and it would also mean so so much to me if you could support me in my fundraising efforts! If all my Facebook friends donated just £1 I would reach my target! Thank you for reading and hopefully thankyou for your donation no matter how small x

story:
Short Summary

The Yellow Wallpaper is a landmark work of American literature, written by Charlotte Perkins Gilman, a woman who went on to be one of the most influential writers and speakers of her time.  The beauty of the story lies in the craft with which it is written, and the strength of its images.  It is a compact and precise work, layered with facets of understanding about imagination, creativity, self-actualization, depression, freedom, constraint and what defines “madness” in relation to societal structures and norms.

This production of The Yellow Wallpaper will use a multidisciplinary approach.  Through scripted scenes, movement, video and sound, the intention is to weave together a production that is part scripted narrative and part expressionistic.  These two elements intertwine to provide a vehicle in which the fantastical and surreal world of Charlotte’s imagination is realized through movement, sound and video, as well as text.  The story is told through a trio of characters, Charlotte, John and Jenny.  This trio explores the dynamics of marriage, duty, passion, love, friendship, female camaraderie and survival.  

Conceived by: Grace Carter

Written by: Sue Mach

Directed by: Philip Cuomo

Cast: Grace Carter, Christy Bigelow & Chris Harder

Design Team:  Paige McKinney • Movement Design, Bill Tripp • Scenic Design, Stephen Slappe • Video Installation Design, Ron Mason Gassaway • Sound Design and Composition, Daniel Meeker • Lighting Design, Alison Heryer • Costume Design.

What We Need & Where it Goes

All funds contributed to this project will go directly to paying the artists and designers contributing their time and talent, as well as materials and supplies needed to accomplish the final theatrical experience. We have received generous support from CoHo Productions and the Oregon Arts Commission and additionally await possible grant monies from the Regional Arts and Culture Council.  We need your support to help us raise 9,000.00 dollars.  

The Impact

Charlotte's story changed community perceptions when it first appeared in writing over 100 years ago.  The themes of freedom and self-actualization are still very prevalent today, with women's issues at the forefront of our national and world politics.  Our interest is in a collective, immersive and viscerally shared experience that will shed light on the subjects in a new and unique way.  

Risks & Challenges

Our goal is to create a unique experience of transformation for the audience.  The story demands transformation of character and also transformation of space.  The multimedia elements we envision are inventive.  The movement choreography will develop organically and take time.  The staging and emotional journey for the characters will be discovered over months of rehearsals as we bring the script to life.  We are experienced theatre professionals and working artists who make our living in Portland, Oregon.  We call this community home and embrace a belief that diverse local arts economies can be the foundation for positive change in our culture. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our funding link with those you think would be interested in supporting a project of this nature!  Every little bit helps.  Thank you for your consideration!

Best,

The Yellow Wallpaper Team

Photo Credit: Holly Andres

story:
When it comes to live theater, very little space is provided for queer stories, particularly those that center the experiences of queerness intersecting with marginalized identities of race, gender, class and age.

When space is created for these erased stories, the queer, trans and gender non-conforming artists responsible for that creation are too often under-compensated or not compensated at all.

OCCUPIED seeks to repair this injustice towards QTGNC artists and reimagine theater centering QTGNC stories.

And guess what?!

There is so much that YOU can do to help bring this change to fruition!

By donating ANY amount to OCCUPIED, your generosity and solidarity will help pay:

  1. The six actors volunteering 30+ hours to this project
  2. The sound designer & lighting designer generating our immersive ambience
  3. The artist who designed & drew our poster art
  4. For set pieces including a fully functional door, bathroom signs and wall decor
  5. For rehearsal space
  6. For printed scripts

Thank you for your support! 

And come out 7:30pm, Friday, October 14th to the Dixon Place Lounge at 161 Chrystie St, New York, NY to see OCCUPIED!

 

The Dixon Place Lounge is open before , during, and after the show! Bar proceeds directly support DP's mission & artists.

story:
Thank you so much for your interest in PIN* AND THE BLUE FAIRY! We hope you will consider supporting our two-week workshop, in preparation for our upcoming work-in-progress performance at Dixon Place. As this is our earliest stage of development, we truly cannot do this without you.

We are looking to the magical, strange, and stunningly human tale of The Adventures of Pinocchio (by Carlo Collodi), as a launch pad for discovering a new story. PIN* AND THE BLUE FAIRY is about a young trans* teenager, Blue, who searches for a grounded and felt sense of reality. When Blue comes into their identity and is met by obstacles preventing their transition, Blue dreams and enters Pin’s world as the Blue Fairy, helping Pin along their journey to become a “proper” boy.

noah kat baus is a writer with a bold voice, full of heart and truth, and I am so thrilled to have the opportunity to dive into this world with them for this piece. With the help of Ben Gunderson of OUTLIERS Theatre Co, we are assembling a community of artists who identify as queer, trans*, and non-binary to drive this workshop of PIN* AND THE BLUE FAIRY. We hope to be part of a greater movement in art and theater, trying to tell stories that help us understand how we move forward and care for one another during this divisive political and cultural moment.

Join us by supporting this project with a contribution! Upon giving, we hope you will attend our open rehearsals and upcoming events geared toward engaging the larger LGBTQ+ communities in the NYC area.

Thank You,

Adin Walker

Our Indiegogo goal is to raise $5000 in 40 days. These donations will be used to pay a 16-person team of queer, trans, and non-binary artists. It will also pay for quality rehearsal space in NYC, and basic props and costumes for our work-in-progress performance at Dixon Place.

Because OUTLIERS Theatre Co is a non-profit, Indiegogo releases all monies raised, regardless of whether or not we reach our crowdfunding goal.

Though the workshop will culminate in a performance at Dixon Place, we won't be able to make any money from ticket sales to help offset our expenses. This is why the support of our friends and allies is extraordinarily important! PIN* AND THE BLUE FAIRY was only recently green-lighted by Dixon Place, and we have just 40 days to raise the funds. This project will not be possible unless we rally a group of like-hearted people who wish to help us transform this creative seed into a beautiful, inclusive, heartfelt work of theatre.

There are too few stories out there about the teenage trans experience, and this story aims to give dignity and voice to young people and audiences of all identities.

OUTLIERS Theatre Co. is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of OUTLIERS Theatre Co. must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

We've got an excellent team assembled and it's growing every day! It includes:

ADIN WALKER – Director / Co-Choreographer / Conceived By

NOAH KAT BAUS – Writer

SOPHIE ANDREASSI– Associate Director / Co-Choreographer

JESSE JAMES KEITEL – CAST (Blue) / Costume Designer

TOM PHELAN – CAST (Pin)

JERRY CLICQUOT – CAST (Geppetto / Blue's Father)

IAN FIELDS STEWART – CAST

SOPH MENAS – CAST

JAX JACKSON – CAST

RAVEN WHITE – CAST / Associate Choreographer

LAUREN FELDMAN – Dramaturg

REBECCA FELDMAN – Casting Director

MIRIAM SALZMAN – Stage Manager

KELLEY SHIH – Lighting Designer

WESLEY CORNWELL – Design Consultant

BEN GUNDERSON – Producer (OUTLIERS)

ADAM HYNDMAN – Associate Producer

ADIN WALKER (Director / Co-Choreographer / Conceived By) Adin choreographed the NYC premiere of Jaime Jarrett’s Normativity with NYMF and is currently directing Gruesome Playground Injuries at TheaterLab NYC. Assistant directing credits include A Midsummer Night's Dream and Lady Windermere's Fan at CalShakes, Vanya, Sonia, Masha, and Spike at the Guthrie, Yehuda Hyman’s The Mar Vista at 14th Street Y, and the upcoming productions of Basil Kreimendahl’s Orange Julius at Rattlestick (dir. Dustin Wills) and Taylor Mac’s Hir at Woolly Mammoth (dir. Shana Cooper). Adin studied at Princeton where he wrote about fairies and directed and co-choreographed a reimagining of Singin' in the Rain for which he received the inaugural "Music Theater Award." www.adinwalker.com.

NOAH KAT BAUS (Writer) noah is a translator, adapter, and director from New Orleans. They began working in theatre in 2014 while attending Harvard College, where they studied English and drama with a focus in contemporary and experimental work and received the David McCord prize for creative talent in drama. Their thesis project was a new translation, production, and critical examination of Frank Wedekind’s Spring Awakening (translator, director, co–set designer). Other credits include Dog Sees God (director, co–set designer) and Jacques the fatalist and his master (translator, adapter, director). Pin* and the Blue Fairy is their first NYC production.

REBECCA FELDMAN (Casting Director): Freelance Casting Director/Casting Assistant at The Public Theater. In addition to work at the Public: Off-Broadway (as Casting Director): The View UpStairs (Spring 2017); Broadway (as Casting Assistant): Shuffle Along (George C. Wolfe), A Delicate Balance (Pam MacKinnon), A Raisin in the Sun (Kenny Leon), Lucky Guy (George C. Wolfe).  Film (as Casting Assistant): Lady Bird (Greta Gerwig).  Other select Casting Director credits: bimonthly reading series for The LGBT Center & Tom Kirdahy Productions, Normativity (NYMF), Beardo (Pipeline Theatre Company), Anna Christie (The Wild Project), Drama League DirectorFest 2014 & 2015, The Gray Man (Pipeline Theatre Company),  Feeling (Glass Bandits), Junk: A Rock Opera (multiple engagements), Kid-Friendly* (webseries).  www.rebeccamfeldman.com

DIXON PLACE has been an artistic incubator since 1986, and is a Bessie and Obie Award-winning non-profit institution committed to supporting the creative process by presenting original works of theater, dance, music, puppetry, circus arts, literature & visual art at all stages of development. Presenting over 1000 creators a year, this local haven inspires & encourages diverse artists of all stripes & callings to take risks, generate new ideas & consummate new practices. www.dixonplace.org

OUTLIERS THEATRE CO. makes work that represents the underrepresented. It builds programming around core values of immediacy, community, inclusion, advocacy, boldness, and compassionate refusal. www.outlierstheatreco.org

If you aren't able to contribute money at the moment, you can:

  • Share this campaign on FB or Twitter!
  • Volunteer your time with an organization that advocates or provides services for the LGBTQ+ community.
  • Reserve a ticket to the February 2 work-in-progress performance of PIN* AND THE BLUE FAIRY at www.dixonplace.org.

story:
Education is the freedom of the mind. Freedom is a human right, but education is still a privilege. 

I was forced into withdraw from Uni today, after one semester, because student finance decided I am not worth the 9000£ fees. So education apparently is not about your passion, efforts and commitment, but is all about either you can afford it or not. Now they want ME to pay for the fees anyway, even though I have no money and I work just enough to afford my rent.

Though my heart is broken, I am so grateful for the beautiful experience I had the past semester, I met fabulous talented people, and I grew up so much. Educating yourself, studying something you really love, like theatre in my case, is the best chance you can ever give to your self.

Please help me to extinguish this dept that would probably end up being the end of me, financially and socially. Anything from one pence can be the biggest help for me.

I am not gonna let this put me down, I will keep working to creat the lifeI know I deserve, even if I don't have money!
