Freedom is a human right, but education is still a privilege. I was forced into withdraw from Uni today, after one semester, because student finance decided I am not worth the 9000£ fees. So education apparently is not about your passion, efforts and commitment, but is all about either you can afford it or not. Now they want ME to pay for the fees anyway, even though I have no money and I work just enough to afford my rent.Though my heart is broken, I am so grateful for the beautiful experience I had the past semester, I met fabulous talented people, and I grew up so much. Educating yourself, studying something you really love, like theatre in my case, is the best chance you can ever give to your self.Please help me to extinguish this dept that would probably end up being the end of me, financially and socially. Anything from one pence can be the biggest help for me.I am not gonna let this put me down, I will keep working to creat the lifeI know I deserve, even if I don't have money!

story:
The Susan B Anthony Society For The Sisters Of Gertrude Stein
From the Desk of
Lulie Stanwyck
01/11/1956

Dearest Sisters,

As you're all aware the Cold War is at it's peak, but nothing will stop us from once again gathering to celebrate our Annual Quiche Breakfast this coming February.

Subsequently I have placed Veronica Schultz in charge of renovating the Susan B Anthony Society for the Sisters of Gertrude Stein headquarters to Federal Emergency Management Agency Fall Out Shelter Standards.

This is not a task that one woman alone can complete, so I am asking you, fellow widows, to band together to help raise the funds required to fully ensure our safety in the completely unlikely event of a Communist attack on our beloved United States of America.

Even the smallest donation will ensure our 1956 Annual Quiche Breakfast will be the best yet!

Yours in service,

Lulie Stanwyck
Society President


A Note from Buildings And Grounds Chairman- Veronica Schultz

Alright Fellow Widows, it is my task as Buildings and Grounds Chairman to ensure the safety of all our Sisters when they are in attendance of society events, so I am completely renovating our Community Centre basement to proper Fall Out Shelter Standards, but I need your help.

On the right hand side of this page you'll see a number of items we require to fit out the basement, from storage and supplies to reinforced glass and our special radiation proof, steel, security door. Support your fellow sister by selecting an item and donating it's value.

In total renovations to the Community Centre will cost $10,000 and we have a limited amount of time before our Annual Quiche Breakfast this year to get the renovation complete. So dig deep and support your fellow sisters, WE NEED YOU! 


From the Men in the Other Room

'5 Lesbians Eating A Quiche' began it's life in Chicago in 2011 where one half of Imprint Theatricals, Sean Bryan, was lucky enough to see it's premiere season. From the moment the show ended Sean knew he had to bring it to Australia.
From there the show went on to an award winning run off Broadway and numerous return Chicago seasons.
When Sean met Nathanael Cooper and realised that they were on the same wave length with their love of boutique theatre experiences Imprint Theatricals was born, and the perfect opportunity to bring '5 Lesbians Eating A Quiche' to Australia arose.

Imprint Theatricals intends on leaving a mark on audiences across the globe through diverse and unique producing of live theatrical events.

Sean has produced theatre in both the United States and Australia including the new musicals MARGARET FULTON: QUEEN OF THE DESSERT and FACING EAST, the acclaimed cabaret production I AM PLAYING ME and the Australasian Premiere of the Broadway musical [TITLE OF SHOW].

Nathanael is one of Australia’s leading arts and entertainment journalists with a decade of experience as an entertainment editor at the country’s top newspapers.

When '5 Lesbians Eating A Quiche' premieres on February 3, 2015  at the Brisbane Powerhouse it will be the result of a year's worth of development, hard work, blood, sweat, and eggs. 

Funds raised through this campaign will go towards bringing the production to life in Brisbane. The $10,000 we aim to raise will be broken up as follows:
-Set and Technical Requirements $3,000
-Costumes and Props $2,000
-Transportation $2,000 
-Marketing & Publicity $3,000
Any additional funds raised will go towards furthering our reach through marketing, and developing a tour model to take the Sisters on the road.

We want you to be a part of our journey as Imprint Theatricals from the very beginning by helping to make this outrageous, laugh out loud, comedy explode onto the Australian stage. So chip in what you can, and immerse yourself into the world of '5 Lesbians Eating A Quiche.'

5 Lesbians Eating A Quiche

Part of MELT: A Celebration of Queer Arts and Culture
Visy Theatre, Brisbane Powerhouse
February 3-8, 2015
Book Tickets:
Online www.5lesbians.com.au
Via Phone 07 3358 8600

Presented by special arrangement with Samuel French Inc.

story:
Why support Fizzy Drinks With Two Straws?

We are passionate about making new art which is accessible to all. We strive to make theatre that is exciting and that can be used to make a difference, inspired by the current state of the world around us. 

What we need  & what you get

There are lots of things that go into the making of a play, which is why we need your support.

  • PRINTING, so that we can spread the word about our lovely little play.
  • COSTUME, so that we can make our cast look prettier than they already do.
  • REHEARSAL SPACE, because these things just don't come free and my sitting room just isn't big enough. 
  • BUT, we can promise to give you something in return for your support. Shout outs on our social media, signed copies of the programme and the script and free tickets to the show. and of course our eternal gratitude. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot support us by donating, there are plenty of other ways that you can:

  • Come to the show! Buy tickets and give us your feedback. This kind of support us invaluable to us.
  • Tell people about the show. Like our Facebook page and our twitter page (twitter.com/fizzydrinksplay)

story:
Hello. We are ARGONAUT.

ARGONAUT is a young, new theatre company set up by Rory Horne and Nina Cavaliero.

We've made a play. It's called Action at a Distance.

We are taking this play to the 2017 Edinburgh Festival Fringe, where it will have a 17-performance run at ZOO Southside.

We're very excited.

 

Here's some more information about the above:

  • ARGONAUT was set up by Rory and Nina in Norwich earlier this year. Rory and Nina are both about to graduate from the University of East Anglia (UEA).
  • Action at a Distance started life as Rory's American Studies Year Abroad Dissertation. Rory and Nina then fleshed it out for performance at Norwich's Maddermarket Theatre in February of this year. The show enjoyed three sold-out performances. (This was an Orange Skies Theatre production, in association with UEA Drama Society.)
  • The Edinburgh Festival Fringe is the biggest arts festival in the world. Each year, hundreds of thousands of creatives from theatre, comedy, music, dance, cabaret and pretty much everything else descend on Scotland's capital city for the whole of August. It's a lot of fun.
  • ZOO Southside is one of the Fringe's two ZOO Venues located on Nicolson Street in the heart of Edinburgh. 

 

About the play:

Action at a Distance is a play about money, war, disconnect, American foreign policy, truth, morality, desperation, obsession, compulsion, goodness, care, reliance and love.

In a small town in Nevada, out-of-work plumber Chris stumbles across Josh, a charity worker exposing the truth behind U.S. drone strikes in Syria and Iraq. Her fascination in his world and determination to win his approval sends her down a path towards the darkest of ethical dilemmas. The play explores the relationship between money and morality, and the detachment of American citizens from the international actions of their country.

“An ingenious plot and a head-f**k of a concept… A really scary, exciting bit of work.” (Steve Waters)

The play takes an original and indirect look at events in the news, showing the different and unique ways in which they interconnect with the lives of regular citizens. It is a project about which we are all incredibly passionate, both because of its relevance to ongoing global events and because of the very human, interpersonal story at its centre.

We will soon be taking the play back into development and rehearsals with new rewrites, new staging and a wonderful new cast, Rosa Caines and Dom Luck, with Nina also taking on a small role. Erin Fitzsimons will be our Production Manager and Molly-Rose Curran our Creative Consultant and Marketing Manager.

 

Where you come in:

We need your help to make this wonderful opportunity a reality.

Taking a show to Edinburgh is expensive for anyone, but particularly student companies trying to do it off their own backs. The show has had some wonderful responses and feedback so far, and started some very interesting conversations about its subject matter. We want to extend these conversations as far as we can, and a run of performances at the Edinburgh Fringe is a fantastic opportunity to do just that. We all care deeply about this project and are desperate for more people to see it.

Where the money will go:

First and foremost, we need to cover the cost of our venue. We are part of the way towards reaching this, but your donations will help us to reach the total amount we owe to ZOO.

Our next largest cost is marketing. The main way you get an audience to come to your Fringe show is by pounding the pavements of Edinburgh, handing out flyers and putting up posters, making it known and recognisable. That means, to have a significant impact, lots of materials are needed, which cost a fairly large amount of money. We will need enough flyers for the duration of our run, and posters to replace the ones that get pasted over (it happens). 

We also need to cover the cost of public liability insurance, as well as a small amount for props.

What we can do for you:

We have a number of exciting perks and rewards down the right-hand side of this page. We want a way to say thank you for your support. Check them out and select the one you want! We can't wait to show you our gratitude.

 

Finally...

If you're still reading, we love you. You're a superstar and we really appreciate your interest in 'Action at a Distance'.

It might be a cliche, but every little does help. Any donation you can make would be massively appreciated. Even if that can't be a financial one, it would be wonderful if you could spread the word about our show.

Come and say hello on our very fresh Twitter and Facebook accounts! When the Fringe programme goes live in June, we'll post the ticket link here. Of course, if you're in Edinburgh from 4th - 22nd August, we'd love for you to come and see the show.

If you would like to get in touch with us, you can email argonauttheatre@gmail.com.

 

Thanks and love,

ARGONAUT x

 

(Graphics and designs by Daisy Minto)

story:
Who we are

Euphonia Studio is the practice of the London-based  director, musician and scenographer Alisdair Kitchen. Working both independently, and with a community of talented associates, he creates acclaimed opera & theatre productions, concerts, exhibitions, and designs for performance.

To look at some of our previous work, please have a look at our website here. 

What We Need & What You Get

Any funding we seek will go towards two main areas:

  • Fees for our talented performers
  • The hire of our venue, the The Drayton Arms Theatre.

As a thank-you for your generous support, we are offering a range of limited edition prints, recordings, and original artwork - have a look at the side-bar opposite! 

The Impact

Euphonia Studio is proud to have a track record of excellent work, but currently most of our productions operate on a profit-share model, as we rarely have the funds to offer guaranteed fees to our performers and creatives. We want to move away from this risky and limiting model - this Autumn season marks a step in the right direction, as we are offering fixed fees. As Artistic Director, I am personally investing over half the funds needed for this project, but without full funding, we will run at a loss, which in turn has a detrimental impact on our ability to produce work in the future. The picture with full funding is much brighter - we can invest in our future, continue to build on our acclaimed work of the past few years, and offer more, better paid opportunities for talented artists. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, you can still be an immense help by spreading the word about our campaign; please use the Indiegogo share tools and look out for our messages on social media!

story:
Short Summary

International High School is a Title I School in Paterson, NJ that prides itself on creating a school culture that respects diversity and celebrates the multicultural atmosphere of Paterson. We offer a curriculum of international and global studies and hold our students to a high standard of excellence and seriousness of purpose. However, due to educational budget cuts, there is currently no funding for the performing arts in our school.

In an effort to revitalize the importance of the arts in education, I am volunteering to establish a Musical Theater Program in our school and am asking for your help in donating supplies and/or funding for our new and exciting program.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $2500 in order to pay for the supplies needed to run our first show, which is set to take place on Friday, November 21st. Every dollar raised will go towards purchasing the licensing rights, scripts, sets, costumes, and equipment needed to run our first Fall Show and Spring Musical! If we exceed our fundraising goals, the additional money will be put towards purchasing the sound and microphone equipment for the school.

In appreciation of your donation of $25 or more, we offer a variety of benefits designed to bring you closer to the work on International's stage. Please check a list of our perks, which are listed on the right side of this webpage.

If we do not hit our fundraising goal, the money will still go towards the performance of the show, but will run using only the resources we could afford using the donations. Any funds remaining will be conserved for the spring musical. Either way, 100% of the fundraising efforts will be used towards the enhancement of the performing arts program in the school.

The Impact

This school has the potential of having a phenomenal music and theater department. The school was originally built to contain a nationally recognized theater program, equipped with dance studios, practice rooms, and an auditorium with a full set of lights and equipment. However, due to unforeseen relocations of the program and the lack of funding, the school had to postpone the option of adding music and theater to their academic programs. The practice and dance rooms were turned into classrooms and storage space.

With your help, you would help start the change of these rooms back into what they were originally intended for and touch the lives of many adolescents for future years. The students in this school make a choice to attend International High School for the academic environment that is well-maintained and the love and care they receive from their teachers and administrators. With your donations, our students will have a chance to stand in the spotlight and learn to develop their creativity, spontaneity, confidence, and stage presence and have a deeper understanding of community and teamwork.

    Risks & Challenges

    Up until this point, there has never been a theater program at this school. Extracurricular activities are at a minimum at International and the implementation of this program is in its experimental phase. The administrators fully support the idea of creating a new Performing Arts Program and are waiting to see the results of this first year. There is no precedent for this and so there are many variables as to whether or not this effort will be a success or failure. Will we have the materials to make a quality show? Will people come to watch us perform?

    I have worked with performing arts for many years and see a potential in our students who, if given the chance, will deliver great performances and become part of a quality program. All of the tools are there: the stage, the students, the lights. We just need the funding to ensure the program's launch is a success.

    I am setting the bar high and am getting the school involved in the Rising Star Awards, making sure that there is coverage from local newspapers, and am planning on entering the students in theatrical collegiate competitions. Our students are talented and are motivated to ensure its success. We are currently rehearsing and know that we can make a lasting impression to keep the theater program alive and running.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We can use your help in other ways if you are not able to contribute financially. Get involved by spreading the word! Copy this link and share it on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or any other social media site. If you would like to personally help or know of any other ways you can assist us, please contact me at kreisch@paterson.k12.nj.us and let me know your ideas!

    I am looking forward to hearing from you and thank you for your anticipated help and support!

story:
Wearing Black
Death ends a life, not a relationship.

A New Musical
by Riley Thomas
Presented as part of the 2015 New York Musical Theatre Festival

 Theater 3 - 311 W. 43rd St

Thursday, July 9th at 8PM
Friday, July 10th at 9PM
Saturday, July 11th at 1PM
Monday, July 13th at 5PM
Wednesday, July 15th at 1PM

Synopsis

When his twin brother Charlie suddenly passes away, all Evan wants to do is forget their complicated relationship and move on, but the tangled relationships Charlie left behind keep Evan from truly letting go. As he falls into a spiral of self-destruction, Evan must make a stark decision: either accept and forgive his dead twin brother, or become him. Set to a lush, contemporary musical theatre score, Wearing Black explores how people grieve, and the different ways they accept and reject love. 

History

Wearing Black performed a 15-minute snapshot at the 2011 West Village Musical Theatre Festival, then performed the first act as part of the 2013 FRIGID Festival where it was awarded Best Original Score. Wearing Black also performed a 15-minute snapshot as part of the 2013 NYMF event Riley Thomas: Looking Forward.

About the Author

Riley Thomas is a New York based playwright/composer. Thomas’s previous musical Stuck ran at NYMF 2012 where it won four accolades: the Theater for the American Musical Prize, the DIMF Production Award, and honorable mentions for Best Book and Best Music. Stuck has since gone on to be a made into a full-length Hollywood feature film starring Giancarlo Esposito, Amy Madigan and Ashanti with an expected winter 2015 release. Executive Director of Dark Prophet Productions since 2010, Thomas has been awarded the 2012 Anna Sosenko Assist Trust Grant and the 2009 Johnny Mercer Songwriter’s Certificate.

Goals at NYMF and Beyond

The success of Stuck and the respectability of the platform of the New York Musical Theatre Festival (NYMF) will lure a great director and star-quality lead, which will draw the audience. Once seated, the audience is sure to be captivated, stimulated and thrilled by the passion, poignancy and raw emotional power of Wearing Black. By creating a fulfilling night of theatre for each theatergoer, Thomas intends to demonstrate his unique voice as a writer and influential player in musical theater.

Wearing Black follows in the footsteps of smash successes like Rent, Next to Normal and Bare in the way it handles its material: by using the characters and story to create the spectacle. The small personnel requirements, humble scope of the show, and star vehicle potential make it a perfect contender for an Off-Broadway run, as well as keep it eminently producible at regional theaters and colleges.

story:
Short Summary

Hi there! I'm Sam. I’m a queer performing artist based in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Under the pseudonym TOLVA, I create multimedia performance work that combines experimental electronic music, video, and live performance. This work usually, in one way or another, explores the intersections between sexuality, gender, sex, and technology. 


This September, I’ll be premiering a new solo piece, entitled BIG CRUNCH, as part of the Philadelphia FringeArts Festival. The show is set in a dystopian future America in which rigid gender roles are heavily enforced, and straying from them results in serious punishment. I play a cyborg who spends its days locked up in a room packaging make-up products, until one day something goes wrong in its wiring and things...well, you can use your imagination until Fringe time.


I'm being joined in this endeavor by some awesome collaborators, including J.D. Stokely (dramaturg/second-pair-of-eyes), Najee Haynes-Follins (co-designer), Stephen Piccarella (musical co-mastermind), and Max Basch (cinematographer/videographer). 


We’re trying to raise $1,000 to cover space rental, production costs including costumes and a small set, and a little promotional budget. Making theatre is pretty costly, and even though this is gonna be a down-and-dirty DIY type of show, everything costs money. Also, we have awesome perks, including a limited-edition zine to accompany the show, and a physical copy of the show’s electronic score.


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
This play’s conception

This play began as some funny monologues I wrote in grad school for Amie while she was pregnant about how weird people get about hiring a pregnant actress. Fast forward a year, we’ve both graduated and moved to New York and I can’t get those monologues out of my mind. I start to seriously write Essie’s story— and ironically, that was nine months ago. 

Synopsis: Essie is a mid-career New York theatre actor with a shot to finally star on Broadway. She and her husband Walter have been trying to conceive for five years. Amazingly, they do! The pregnancy and the Broadway role go head to head for Essie’s future— until a fetal disability diagnosis threatens to sway the balance. 

This is a play for and by women artists (with some ally men pitching in). We're pro-life and pro-choice, we have kids and we don't, we're beginning career and mid career. We're not here to tell every woman's story about family/ career/ pregnancy/ abortion: we're here to tell one woman's story. Essie's story.

We’re pregnant, and we’re nesting

Creating a new play is a lot like having a baby. You do all the right things, make all the right plans and still have some unexpected surprises. I know this first-hand, as I was the 2012 Best Short Solo winner at United Solo, and I’m so happy to be back to do it again with this great team. Here are our expenses, in order of need:

  • ADMINISTRATIVE: $1110. Most of this is the United Solo festival fee, then rehearsal space and performance space for our June reading (ah, New York City prices). 
  • MARKETING: $700. We believe this show sparks a crucial conversation about women, arts careers, and families, and how hard it gets when those three butt heads. We want the audience packed on September 20 to talk with Essie about it.

  • ARTISTS: $525 total ($125 each for actor, director, playwright, plus $75 for sound designer and $75 for stage manager). We believe in Essie and this story. We’re also professional women with families. And we believe that every artist should get respected for their work with some form of thank-you payment.
  • FILMING: $300. We are pursuing avenues to broadcast this show with community television networks. Our amazing colleague Lee Ann Hoover has graciously cut us a family-and-friends-only deal to film and edit the show. Help us put Lee Ann’s generosity in action and get this show into local household TVs! 

The minimum we need to make this show happen is our administrative and marketing costs ($1810). We'd love to pay ourselves, and we'd love to pay Lee Ann to film it (the whole shebang, $2635). Please help us go all the way!

We’re planning for this baby’s future

I know it can feel like a lot to support a show you maybe can’t come see. We may only be at United Solo one night, but then we’re taking the show to YOU. Essie’s going on a road trip.  

  • Women need to talk about infertility, pregnancy, abortion— not with politicians or protestors, but with each other in a safe, open space. Theatre is that space.
  • Amie’s already toured a show about a similarly hard topic to great success. She’s experienced leading difficult talk-backs with a variety of audiences (we’re working with a pro, people).  

I know that many of you reading this can't come to the show in September but wish you could. That's why raising funds for filming and marketing is so important. You're investing in the future of women listening to women through the power of art. 

Nobody said it was easy

We’ve all had experience producing theatre in a festival, and we’re so excited for United Solo. We’re ready to tear it up. But we’ve never produced a tour before (scheduled venues, organized transportation, squared away with Equity… and all the things we can’t yet see). We’re not old hands at these TV discussions (but we know this story is important and we’re going to keep fighting for it). We’re going big and praying we don’t have to go home. That’s where you come in. We’re going to rely on your support, insight and advice long after this campaign is over and it’s curtains on United Solo. We’re in it for the long haul and hope we can count on you. 

This baby needs Love, not just Money

We know not all of our friends will be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can’t show Essie that you’re standing with her. 

  • We share, you share! Publish this campaign and other Essie news to your peoples. 
  • If you know of a place we can take Pregnant Pause on tour, reach out. Sending an email on our behalf, to connect us with new friends and a new audience, is free for you and great for us :) 
  • Most importantly, support the women around you. Listen to them and let them know you’re in this together. 

And that's all she wrote.

story:
We are taking up a bold new version of Macbeth, which is set in a prison and performed entirely by a cast of three. As excited as we are to go, all the fees for Edinburgh are adding up, so in order to make this happen we need as much help as we can get. We've booked our venue, and are already deep in the rehearsal process, but we are in desperate need of some financial help in order to finish this project and get to the Fringe. The money will be used for various expenses e.g taking out performance liability insurance, transport, prop/costumes and the venue fee. Anything at all you can give is hugely appreciated and you will be safe in the knowledge that you are helping new artists break through in the UK acting industry. Thanks!

For your information we will be performing at Paradise Green during the first week of the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.

story:
THANK YOU! THANK YOU! THANK YOU!

We are so grateful for your support over the course of this campaign. We are very happy with the results, but if you would still like donate you may do so through our fiscal sponsors Fractured Atlas. Your donation will be tax-deductible.

Donate Here


Tight Braid Group will premiere Won't Be a Ghost  in April 2016 at The Brick Theater in Brooklyn. We need your help to compensate the 18 contributing artists, rent rehearsal space, build sets, and cover theater fees. Together we can make it happen!

Tight Braid Group is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Tight Braid Group must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Note: If you'd like to claim a perk, do so by clicking on the perk description box to the right. -->

The Project:

Won't Be a Ghost entwines the stories of two queer truth-tellers: Magnus Hirschfeld, early sexologist and gay rights advocate, and US Army whistleblower, Chelsea Manning. Taking structural cues from Ancient Greek tragedies, a chorus guides the audience from the gardens of Hirschfeld’s Weimar-era Institute for Sexual Science to a US Army base in Iraq, where Manning tells her story via instant messenger. Hirschfeld and Manning, both leaders in queer and trans* rights during times of war, challenge the State's control of information and censorship of their bodies. In the face of persecution, they channel the sensual strength of queer icon St. Sebastian and the prophetic vision of Kassandra (Aeschylus’ Agamemnon), engaging in a timeless struggle for truth and search for utopia. Through rituals of healing they find grace in the unjust, refusing to become martyrs.

With Won’t Be a Ghost, Tight Braid Group aims to illuminate two historic moments of transgender resistance. In national politics and in the arts, we are experiencing an unprecedented moment of transgender visibility. But visibility alone does not lead to transgender rights, and we have recently seen an increase in hate crimes, suicide, incarceration, and anti-trans legislation. We believe that trans voices must tell trans stories for change to occur, and to that end we have spent almost two years building a cast that reflects the sexually diverse group of characters in Won’t Be a Ghost.

Over the course of development, Tight Braid Group has presented the play at the Prelude Festival, HERE Arts, and Dixon Place. The Kilroys awarded Won’t Be a Ghost an Honorable Mention on their 2015 list. It has been a long time coming, and we cannot wait to premiere this piece at The Brick.

Who We Are:

Tight Braid Group is a performance collective founded by Francis Weiss Rabkin and Leslie Allison. We are poets, choreographers, musicians, activists, and visual artists making plays that prioritize emotional and political engagement.

Francis Weiss Rabkin, writer/director
Leslie Allison, composer
Sophie Traub, assistant director/dramaturge
Ian Gerson and Brooke Herr, set design
Nahanaeli Schelling, producer

CAST
Christian Appel as Chelsea Manning
Gordon Landenberger as Magnus Hirschfeld
Patrick Costello as Karl Giese
Michael Newton as Adrian Lamo
Rosza Daniel Lang/Levitsky as Dora

CHOIR
Yonah Adelman
Leslie Allison
Arla Berman
Thea Garlid
Katie Looney
Aya Sato
Nahanaeli Schelling


The Budget:

Our two biggest expenses are space rental and compensation for our artists' 100 rehearsal hours and 7 performances. It is our top priority to offer every contributor a decent artist’s fee, and there are a lot of us: 5 actors, 6 singers, 2 designers, a choreographer, composer, writer, producer. 

We need to raise:

$10,000 for artists' fees
$4,600 for theater rental and rehearsal space
$2,400 for Lighting and Set design, and materials
$500 for transportation, promotion, and incidentals


Perks:

Sponsoring Trans Access Initiative
We want to make theater that reaches all different kinds of audiences. It is important to us that transgender people get to see this play, specifically transgender people who might not be able to afford a ticket or usually have access to theater. Using the Foundry Theatre's Audience Ambassadors program as a model, we will reach out to several community organizations such as Sylvia Rivera Law Project, APICHA, Black and Pink, and the Audre Lorde Project.

Tote Bag


Tight Braid Group Tote (logo designed by Molly Schaeffer)

Original Art


Collage by Brooke Herr 



Artwork by Ian Gerson (sample pictured: Night Drawing, 2016)



Martha (Ugly Duckling Presse 2015) by Leslie Allison

AND MORE!

story:
Nous sommes les huit finissantes 2016 de L’École de danse de Québec (L’EDQ)! 

À sa dernière année du programme Danse-interprétation (DEC technique en partenariat avec le Cégep de Sainte-Foy), notre groupe est à la fois hétéroclite et homogène. Il n’a pas froid aux yeux quand vient le temps de relever de grands défis. Ayant des parcours différents, nous évoluons ensemble, formant un tout, afin d’accomplir notre Projet de fin d’études. 

Ce projet unique au Canada se concrétise par la réalisation et la production d’un spectacle (deux représentations) qui intègre et met en synthèse l’ensemble des apprentissages de cette formation supérieure en danse contemporaine. Notre soif d’apprendre nous a permis d’acquérir un énorme bagage artistique. Nous adorons la complexité, la physicalité et la virtuosité de la danse. 

Cette année, nos corps d’interprètes sont prêts à explorer l’inexploré. Pleurs, joies, déceptions, récompenses, des émotions au rendez-vous pour nous faire grandir et nous permettre de devenir la meilleure version de nous-mêmes. Réunies pour une dernière fois, nous déploierons l’énergie et le temps nécessaires à l’obtention d’un spectacle inégalé dont nous voulons être fières.

Ce spectacle sera présenté les 6 et 7 mai 2016 dans un cadre professionnel et destiné au grand public. Cette présentation de chorégraphies variées sera accueillie à la Salle Multi de Méduse, lieu de prédilection pour la présentation de la danse professionnelle à Québec. Soutenues par L’École de danse de Québec et sous la direction artistique de Lydia Wagerer, nous, finissantes 2016, sommes des interprètes et collaboratrices à la création de chorégraphes professionnels. 

La production inclut le travail de trois chorégraphes aux univers hétéroclites : Peggy Baker (Toronto), Robert Desrosiers (Toronto) et Alan Lake (Québec). Avec une imagination surprenante, Robert Desrosiers a une réputation internationale tout comme Peggy Baker. Celle-ci est l’une des danseuses contemporaines des plus influentes de sa génération et elle est d’ailleurs membre de l’Ordre du Canada depuis 2006. Finalement, Alan Lake, diplômé de L’École de danse de Québec en 2007, possède maintenant sa propre compagnie et a présenté deux de ses créations à La Rotonde, Centre chorégraphique contemporain de Québec.

Cet événement vise à faire rayonner la danse contemporaine dans la Capitale culturelle ainsi que de mettre en évidence l’énergie, l’entreprise et la créativité des jeunes artistes de l'École. Ce projet nous aidera énormément pour notre futur métier d’interprète en danse contemporaine et le spectacle est important pour nous, car il fait le pont entre notre vie étudiante et notre vie professionnelle. De plus, le projet aura une excellente visibilité dans la communauté de la danse. Il rayonnera jusqu’à Ottawa puisque nous irons y présenter une partie de notre travail lors du Festival Danse Canada. 

Votre contribution nous aidera à couvrir une partie des dépenses de la production sur scène, soit la direction technique et les éclairages.

Il n’a pas froid aux yeux quand vient le temps de relever de grands défis. Ayant des parcours différents, nous évoluons ensemble, formant un tout, afin d’accomplir notre Projet de fin d’études. Ce projet unique au Canada se concrétise par la réalisation et la production d’un spectacle (deux représentations) qui intègre et met en synthèse l’ensemble des apprentissages de cette formation supérieure en danse contemporaine. Notre soif d’apprendre nous a permis d’acquérir un énorme bagage artistique. Nous adorons la complexité, la physicalité et la virtuosité de la danse. 
Cette année, nos corps d’interprètes sont prêts à explorer l’inexploré. Pleurs, joies, déceptions, récompenses, des émotions au rendez-vous pour nous faire grandir et nous permettre de devenir la meilleure version de nous-mêmes. Réunies pour une dernière fois, nous déploierons l’énergie et le temps nécessaires à l’obtention d’un spectacle inégalé dont nous voulons être fières.
Ce spectacle sera présenté les 6 et 7 mai 2016 dans un cadre professionnel et destiné au grand public. Cette présentation de chorégraphies variées sera accueillie à la Salle Multi de Méduse, lieu de prédilection pour la présentation de la danse professionnelle à Québec. Soutenues par L’École de danse de Québec et sous la direction artistique de Lydia Wagerer, nous, finissantes 2016, sommes des interprètes et collaboratrices à la création de chorégraphes professionnels. 
La production inclut le travail de trois chorégraphes aux univers hétéroclites : Peggy Baker (Toronto), Robert Desrosiers (Toronto) et Alan Lake (Québec). Avec une imagination surprenante, Robert Desrosiers a une réputation internationale tout comme Peggy Baker. Celle-ci est l’une des danseuses contemporaines des plus influentes de sa génération et elle est d’ailleurs membre de l’Ordre du Canada depuis 2006. Finalement, Alan Lake, diplômé de L’École de danse de Québec en 2007, possède maintenant sa propre compagnie et a présenté deux de ses créations à La Rotonde, Centre chorégraphique contemporain de Québec.
Cet événement vise à faire rayonner la danse contemporaine dans la Capitale culturelle ainsi que de mettre en évidence l’énergie, l’entreprise et la créativité des jeunes artistes de l'École. Ce projet nous aidera énormément pour notre futur métier d’interprète en danse contemporaine et le spectacle est important pour nous, car il fait le pont entre notre vie étudiante et notre vie professionnelle. De plus, le projet aura une excellente visibilité dans la communauté de la danse. Il rayonnera jusqu’à Ottawa puisque nous irons y présenter une partie de notre travail lors du Festival Danse Canada. 
Votre contribution nous aidera à couvrir une partie des dépenses de la production sur scène, soit la direction technique et les éclairages.

story:
Our Story in Three Acts...

Now in our THIRD summer, our Summer Immersion Program (SIP) has proven to exceed the expectations of our students, their parents, the adult actors and our audiences alike.  We are so proud of this rich experience we've created and invite you to become a part of us by giving a gift today! Come let's change the world together and leave it a little better than we found it...

At Three Act Theatre we're making a better world by creating opportunities for generations of human beings to learn from each other - side by side - telling stories that break down walls and confront us with the truth. Please join us on this exciting journey...

SIP is at the heart of what we do, bringing generations together. Teen students, young adult artists and seasoned professionals come together in one room to create a brand new production.  This year in our 3rd Season we present a brand new production - CROAKER: A New Musical.

Tuition fees provide only a portion of the funding needed to realize this production on stage, and many teens cannot even afford tuition.  Your donations allow students who cannot afford tuition the ability to participate in this exciting summer workshop production.

    We Need YOU...Make A Gift That Matters!

    We need $15,000 by the end of June 2016 to help pay for this $40K+ teen program & stage production of CROAKER. 

    Your tax-deductible gift is a TRIPLE THREAT because it:
    • Creates real jobs for professional artists.
    • Provides scholarships for students without financial means.
    • Brings our production of CROAKER to life for audiences of all ages.

    Every dollar counts and will go directly to the production of CROAKER: A  New Musical by Jason Marks & Debra Clinton.  Your gift helps pay for things like:

    • Theatre rental.
    • Rehearsal space
    • Costumes
    • Scenery & Props
    • Director, Choreographer, Musical Director and Design Team
    • Composer/Lyricist
    • Printing of scripts, scores & Playbills at the show!

    YOU Matter...Let's Make Change Together!

    Your gift provides a life changing experience for young artists in the next generation - the young minds and hearts of those who will become our leaders of tomorrow.  The synergy of learning from generation to generation not only creates better artists, but more importantly, creates better people. Those personal transformations resonate in every story we tell and inevitably into each our audiences.  The impact continues as a vibration in the world as we return to our daily lives.

    The Plain Truth...

    Making theatre is a risky business, and uphill climb, and often not very profitable.  We must rely on the generosity of friends and patrons to help create these works and bring them to life on stage.  We have always found a way to make the magic happen, no matter what, but this year more than even, we truly need your help...

    A gift of ANY SIZE is life changing for us! And there's more you can do...

    What If You Told 20 People About Us???

    Some of you maybe can only afford $20 or maybe just can't contribute all, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • You can MAKE SOME NOISE and get the word out about our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, email and other social media outlets!
    • $20 x 20 friends = $400. Every connection you make for us matters!
    • Make it personal - connect to people in personal messages to let them know how important our cause is!
    • You can economize your efforts by to using the Indiegogo share tools!

    Three Act Theatre Company is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Three Act Theatre Company are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our national charities registration, see details. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Project Summary

In this stunning and unique performance, writer Serena Chopra joins Splintered Light Theater, directed by shadow puppeteer Andryn Arithson, for an unparalleled shadow performance of Chopra's forthcoming book, Ic (Horse Less Press, 2016). 

Through shadow performance, Arithson articulates Chopra's Ic, short for Icarus, in his ascent to the sun of American greatness that, in its brightness is defined by whiteness, in its dominance is a fortress of masculinity, and in its singularity, rejects queerness, otherness and multiplicity. At the apex of his flight, the sun burns away Ic's marginalized identities, and he watches as his shoes, locket, song and clothes fall, as marginalia, into the city lakes below where the sun is scattered and spread around the bodies of divers (also divers, in the Middle English usage, meaning diverse). Who will claim this marginalia? Who will appropriate this abandoned identity? In this conceptual retelling of Ovid's Icarus, Chopra demonstrates the struggle minorities face with integrating their marginalized identities into mainstream institutions, such as in higher education and corporate business. Despite being invited to the sun as part of an institutionalized diversity initiative, Ic must dismiss his "non-normative" identity to become white, masculine and heteronormative, if he wants to thrive in the sun's opulence. Chopra's book-length poem is driven by the bits and roots of language, the syllable, suffix and prefix, toppling the dominance of meaning-making by taking etymological liberties and employing multiple rhythmic profusions at once.

Alongside a scored reading of the poem, Arithson's shadow work depicts Chopra's reconstitution of the classic Icarian ascent. In Arithson's hands, shadow work, an ancient form of live, communal performance, exudes digital qualities while retaining the form's intimate craftwork and primal surge. Using only three lights and a mystery trove of scrapped materials and objects, Arithson's imagination illuminates the tension between the marginalia and corporate wash of identity. The performance takes place in-the-round, where the audience is surrounded, overhead, underfoot and all-about, by the visual sirens of Arithson's craft and Chopra's potent linguistic tumbling.

Both Arithson and Chopra have extensive performance backgrounds in dance, theater, live performance art and film. Ic is Chopra's second full-length book and will be Arithson's second evening-length shadow performance as director and lead puppeteer, of a published work. This first-time collaboration has been a long time in the making and is a beautiful manifestation of two highly imaginative, playful, empathetic and political artists. Their combined work is an artful measure of significant and often overlooked institutionalized oppression. Rather than serving as a didactic soap box, the collaboration is a visual poem, gesturing in the rhythms of light, color, shadow and syllable, rendering the impact of oppression and whitewashing on an individual. Together, Chopra and Arithson open Ic to the collective, unspeakable muscle memory that struggles with contemporary issues of race, queerness, and feminism within and without corporate institutions.

Depending on funding and light construction schedules, Splintered Light Theatre plans to perform Ic between mid-July and mid-August, 2016. To keep abreast with this production's progress and performance dates, please visit the Splintered Light Theatre facebook page.

What We Need & What You Get

UPDATE! We are so excited to have reached our goal. We now have the privilege to use any additional funds to further support venue expenses, marketing, and other costs of production. We will provide updates as we continue work on this special project. Thank you to all of our supporters, you mean the world to us! 

Our greatest funding priority is the cost related to building two shadow lights. Each light costs  $140 to build ($280 total for two lights), plus the cost of labor and manufacturing expertise estimated at $200. This adds up to $480 total for the lights. This price includes using 250 watt bulbs, which will allow us to eventually attach them to dimmers, making the lights more versatile for future performances. Light and puppetry expert, Nick Trotter, is a consultant hired by Splintered Light Theatre to help with the construction of lighting devices.  Nick is a craftsman of puppetry and masks, as well as a trained performer (learn more about Nick at www.nicktrotter.com).

We will also need to rent a fitting venue, which we have budgeted at $200-$300. 

The cost of materials for donors' perks is estimated at $200. This includes printing, envelopes, postage, book copies, and crafting materials. All donors' perks are unique and created by Chopra and Arithson. As a donor you could receive a signed copy of Ic, a shadow vignette, or other handmade artworks by the Ic ladies. 

If we do not completely meet our funding goal, the funds we do receive will go towards the lights and campaign costs first. Without this campaign we will not be able to perform our work, which we have spent many hours and months conceiving of and rehearsing with one light rather than three. Our greatest challenge is raising money for materials to construct lights. 

If you cannot donate, please share our campaign with others who you think would be interested in funding and attending our unique collaborative performance. Thank you for your time and consideration of this project.


Artist Bios

Andryn Arithson is a puppetry artist and co-founder of Splintered Light Theatre. Andryn has been designing and building puppets for over 10 years. Alongside several local artists, she is currently building large-scale dinosaur puppets for a live performance of Ian Cooke's new album, Antiquasauria. Her puppets have been featured in productions by square product theatre, the Colorado Shakespeare Festival, Obscene/Courageous Theatre, and other independently produced performances.  She holds an MA in Theatre and an MBA from the University of Colorado Boulder.

Serena Chopra is a PhD (ABD) candidate in Creative Writing at the University of Denver. She is the author of two full-length books of poetry, This Human (Coconut Books 2013) and Ic (Horse Less Press 2016). She is a dancer with the modern dance company, Evolving Doors Dance and was a 2011-2013 resident artist at the RedLine in Denver. She teaches poetry to children and teens, most recently at the Young Writers Workshop. She also currently teaches in the MFA writing program at Naropa University.

story:
Our Purpose

My name is Fred Rohan-Vargas, the creator and producer of Yaki Yim Bamboo.  Our goal is to raise enough money to put on a spectacular show for children to sing, dance and experience the fun of being who they are and looking forward to what they’ll become. The story we tell will hopefully be a lesson to all of us, no matter how old we are or what fears we develop.  Change is a natural part of our being and should be a part of our understanding as we enter the stages set forth in our life’s journey.

Your support will allow us to fulfill our dream of putting a smile on every child’s face as we reach out to children beyond the theater walls but to schools, institutions and communities that could use a good time for their kids to escape on this magical Caribbean island called Yaki Yim Bamboo. 

Our History

YAKI YIM BAMBOO THE MUSICAL is based on THE ISLAND OF YAKI YIM BAMBOO, a children’s play that was performed with music. It was commissioned by The Sandy Ground Historical Society on Staten Island and later performed at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture for the kids in Harlem. In 1984 a class of middle school students from United Nations International School presented the play with actor Dustin Hoffman’s daughter, Rebecca Hoffman, playing one of the lead roles.

Eventually, the play was performed by two professional children’s theaters, Creative Theatre in Princeton, New Jersey and The St. Louis Black Repertory Company in St. Louis, Missouri, for two of their consecutive seasons.

Like the play, the musical interacts with its audience and fills the room with the flavor of Caribbean culture as the actors dance, sing and talk in the easy to understand West Indian dialect.

Our Budget

We are asking for $15,000 to cover the cost for directors, (both for stage and music) cast, musicians, backstage personnel (i.e. stage manager, set designer, costume designer etc.), operations and supplies. We would also like to video tape the production, so potential contributors, like yourselves, could see what their contributions have made possible. 

Our Thanks to You

I have to admit how excited we are to have people join us in achieving our goal and since they are willing to give, we would like to do the same.  Please take a look to your right at the perks we are offering our contributors. It’s our way to show you our appreciation for your willingness to invest in us.

               

Our Location

If we don’t reach our entire goal, our production will still be done albeit on a shoe-string budget. We are scheduled to make our debut at the 13th Street Repertory Company beginning in March 2016. Since the musical is an interactive production, we will continue to mingle off stage where children can meet the cast and learn about the Caribbean culture. (Please check our website and get a view of our cultural highlights. Feel free to write something in our blog too.  www.yakiyimbamboo.com

Our Challenge

We know we face a tremendous challenge of raising money in a short time. However, we are banking that you will share our vision and help us entertain and teach our children.  We are proud to be sponsored by Fractured Atlas which means any donation you make will be tax deductible. *

Please get the word out for us on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter etc. That alone is worth much more than you think. If you wish to volunteer  or help in any way, we can be reached at rohanvargas@gmail.com.

Our Testimonials

“It was the best play I have ever seen.”    

“At the end of the show I clapped so hard 
  my hands hurt.” 

General comments by students of Muschal School in Bordentown, New Jersey

“I like this story because it is clear and fun. I think it deals with something very relevant to children but hard to dramatize beyond Peter Pan's growing up.” 

Hailey Ratigan 
13th Street Repertory Theatre 
New York, New York

"Though productions, with the name recognition of familiar folk and fairy tales draw the biggest crowds at the Connection, Rita Washington, the Black Rep's education and community programs director, suggests that The Island of Yaki Yim Bamboo will have broad entertainment appeal."

'Set at Carnival, it has a wonderful sense of movement' she observes. “ The audience is involved, they become a group visiting the island. They can even dance the limbo at the end."

The Riverfront Times , St. Louis, Missouri 



Our Contributors
We would like to list and thank the contributors who donated money in the past, so we could get this far in starting a fundraising campaign through Indiegogo.
         
           Millicent Arrindell                     William Bratton                       Fred Crecca
           Keung Hui                                    Daniel Neiden                          Jerry Ospa
           Sheila Rohan                               Ted Rohan                                Victor Santiago
           Greg Taylor                                  Diane Wasinus                        Diana Velasquez
           Susan Hui-Rohan                       Rodrigo del Sola

Opening Day of Our First Performance
We filled the seats of our theatre with lots of children, parents and teachers this past Friday, March 18,  Everyone had a fantastic time with the kids describing the show as "awesome."  We are still hoping for your help so we can complete our goal.

* Yaki Yim Bamboo the Musical is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Yaki Yim Bamboo the Musical must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Our Challenge
We
know we face a tremendous challenge of raising money in a short time. However, we are banking that you will share our vision and help us
entertain and teach our children.  We are proud to be sponsored by
Fractured Atlas which means any donation you make will be tax deductible. *
Please
get the word out for us on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter etc. That alone is worth much more than you think. If you wish to volunteer  or help in any way, we can be reached at rohanvargas@gmail.com.
Our Testimonials
“It was the best play I have ever seen.”    
“At the end of the show I clapped so hard   my hands hurt.” 
General comments by students of Muschal School in Bordentown, New Jersey
“I like this story because it is clear and fun. I think it deals with something very relevant to children but hard to dramatize beyond Peter Pan's growing up.” 
Hailey Ratigan 13th Street Repertory Theatre New York, New York

"Though productions, with the name recognition of familiar folk and fairy tales draw the biggest crowds at the Connection, Rita Washington, the Black Rep's education and community programs director, suggests that The Island of Yaki Yim Bamboo will have broad entertainment appeal."'Set at Carnival, it has a wonderful sense of movement' she observes. “ The audience is involved, they become a group visiting the island. They can even dance the limbo at the end."

The Riverfront Times , St. Louis, Missouri 



Our Contributors
We would like to list and thank the contributors who donated money in the past, so we could get this far in starting a fundraising campaign through Indiegogo.                    Millicent Arrindell                     William Bratton                       Fred Crecca
           Keung Hui                                    Daniel Neiden                          Jerry Ospa           Sheila Rohan                               Ted Rohan                                Victor Santiago           Greg Taylor                                  Diane Wasinus                        Diana Velasquez           Susan Hui-Rohan                       Rodrigo del SolaOpening Day of Our First PerformanceWe filled the seats of our theatre with lots of children, parents and teachers this past Friday, March 18,  Everyone had a fantastic time with the kids describing the show as "awesome."  We are still hoping for your help so we can complete our goal.


* Yaki Yim Bamboo the Musical is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Yaki Yim Bamboo the Musical must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
We are Patricia Cardona Roca, actress and singer,  and Kendra Augustin, actress and writer,  the co-Founders of Leela NYC Theatre Festival. 

We created this festival because we want to give actors a chance to play roles that go beyond their type: accent, age, skin color, size, gender and sexual orientation to show the audience a reality that is not always portrayed in the media, theatre or film.  We aim to turn casting on its ear. We want to acknowledge that people look and speak differently, but allow those lines to be blurred within the plays. Art is supposed to paint the colors of humanity. We believe with love, respect, and education we can be at peace with each other.

We want to support and give courage to those who feel they can identify with our festival to get out of their own closet and lead them and others to a more respectful and peaceful life. Maybe influence other productions to open the doors to the diverse reality we are living in. With your help we will show that this is possible, that non-traditional casting works, and that we are more than our looks! Something we already know but, let's put it on stage!

The inspiration came after Patricia went to a reading of 5 10min plays by The 365 Women a Year NYC Group which Kendra was involved in. She felt something had to be done with the stories of all those women forgotten by history. We thought they had to be heard and seen in a full production. As the project started developing it became influenced by our own experiences as working actresses. We realized that there were so many other people that weren't well represented in the media and therefore ultimately stereotyped, forgotten or delegated as part of the background. That is when we decided to produce an internationally inclusive project that welcomes and celebrates the reality we are living. One where people of all sizes, colors, cultures, and accents exist and live wholly and fully.

Some of our great supporters speaking after 43sec.


Let's start with what you get!

All your perks are tax deductable! See them on the side!


The costs of producing 2 shows including a stipend for cast, directors and crew are:

Artistic team 20 actors, 7 writers, 7 directors, musical director $3100

Professional fees stage manager, lighting and sound: $405

Remainder of rent utilities: $885

PR: $600

Marketing: $400

Graphic designer, website and general administration costs: $278

Fundraising costs Indiegogo campaign and Fractured Atlas comission: $625

Total 1 : $6293 minimum required to provide a stipend to the artistic team. This is the bare minimum we need!

Total 2: $10,589 to provide a complete salary to the artistic team

Total 3: $20,643 to prolong the festival to 5 days in Manhattan for a week and considering additional technical and artistic fees

Total 4: $45,043 for the above and to provide a basic salary to the production team and volunteers involved 

If we don't reach the entire goal we will not print fliers, we will rehearse in our homes, we will still produce a show! We will shorten it or ask people to donate their time but we really hope to not have to do that! 

If the world is a stage, the mainstream media is holding a spotlight on very specific types portraying them, sometimes, as an ideal and also a tradition. It´s easy (in most cases) to welcome them at home. We are not against it, but we want to use more lights, change the color of their lenses, to show that the same lives can be led by other types,  Your contribution can make a difference!

Our final challenge is to get the budget. We already have 35 artists, one stage manager,  PR and Marketing, an accent coach, a video editor on board, so we strongly believe that by sharing our campaign amongst all our friends and family we will reach people that identify with Leela and we can achieve the minimum goal of $6293

Look at our program in www.leelanycfestival.org 

Our plan is a strong marketing campaign. We've already been on 2 radio shows and one podcast. As soon as we get the recordings we will upload them. We have 2 blogs that will publish our story and we will have at least one other radio show!

Shout out our campaign! on your Facebook page, Twitter, via email to your friends, colleagues, family, anyone you can think of.

Can you provide us with?

1. Rehearsal space with piano

2. Choreography services

3. Free use of keyboard

4. Free printing of posters/cards

5. Costumes

6. Props

7. Set design/decoration

8. Volunteers (ushers, photographer, box office and more)

If you can provide any of these please contact us @ leelanycfestival@gmail.com

story:
About Toonspeak and Our Appeal for Help

  • Set up in 1987, Toonspeak is a young people's theatre project, and registered charity, serving North Glasgow communities which are among the most deprived in the UK.  We provide young people aged 11-25 with completely free performing, learning and other creative opportunities which inspire them and help them achieve positive futures.
  • Courtnay, Connor, Jasmine, David, Shelby, Matthew, Jamie and Andrew are an amazing group of young people who regularly give up their free time, despite challenges in their own lives, to support Toonspeak and other young people in their community.


  • We are asking for your help to give these fabulous young people a well-deserved and life-changing opportunity to take part in an exciting theatre and cultural exchange project in Germany this summer. It's an amazing opportunity and Toonspeak are so fortunate to have been asked to attend, but we really need your support!

What Do We Need & What You Get

  • Toonspeak needs to raise £2500 to send 8 young people on a trip of a lifetime to the Move On! Theatre Exchange at the Youth Culture Centre in Oldenburg, Germany at the end of August 2015.  Our young people will come together for 2 weeks with young people from 5 other European countries to learn about each other's cultures and to create a piece of political theatre in a residential environment.  The total project will cost £5000 (for flights, accommodation, young people's passport applications and food) and we're hoping to raise £2500 through crowd funding.  The young people will also be doing a bag-pack and other fundraising activities to help raise money this summer. 
  • As well as investing directly in these young people's futures, your donation will be rewarded with a series of lovely Toonspeak perks including social-media shout-outs, personalised thank you cards and use of Toonspeak's amazing black-box studio space!
  • Even if we don't quite reach our goal, every penny we raise will be spent on sending these amazing young people on this life-changing trip.  Every donation, no matter how small helps!

The Impact of Your Donation

The impact of your donation for each participant's continued learning and development is invaluable. Sharing social and cultural differences, learning to work and connect with other young people from across Europe on a completely level playing field as well as learning new languages, new skills and techniques from professional theatre makers will be a challenging, exciting and perspective changing experience.

“It isn’t just a project or a holiday it’s life changing. A lot of people don’t understand that for people from deprived areas of Glasgow how life affirming this could be.” Jasmine Main – Toonspeak Young Director

“This is an incredible opportunity for anyone involved in the Arts like me who wants it to be their future career.” David McMahon – Toonspeak Young Director

The trip will be an escape from reality for some of the young people who have to deal with the daily life of being a Young Carer or being unemployed.   Some of the young people have never had a passport or been on an aeroplane before. 

“This would be my first time abroad and I’d get to meet loads of new people from six different countries….engage with them and learn more about their culture.” Matthew Docherty – Toonspeak participant

Toonspeak has a great track record of providing free, skill-building theatre activities and trips, like this one, for young people. Over the last 28 years we have helped many disadvantaged young people in North Glasgow to improve their confidence, make plans for their future, gain a broader understanding of themselves and the world and achieve positive outcomes.  Many of the young people we work with have gone on to college, university, employment or even to successful careers in the performing arts - a fabulous achievement given the social problems that exist in their communities.  Toonspeak was named as Scottish Charity of the Year 2014.

Young people are at the heart of Toonspeak and we support 6 of our current participants to fill half of the 12 places on our voluntary Board of Directors (4 of the young people who are going to Germany are on our Board of Directors).  Anyone, regardless of ability or personal circumstances can take part in Toonspeak. We always provide free transport and refreshments to prevent any barriers to taking part for those who have little or no access to spare cash.   You can find out more about our work by visiting our website www.toonspeak.co.uk

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help. We'd be so grateful if you could help us get the word out about our campaign by sharing with your friends and family and on social media. 

Thank you.

story:
My name is Christina Clingerman Hemphill. I am the playwright behind "A Symphony for Portland." I grew up in Indianapolis, Indiana. I majored in music education at Butler University, Jordan College of Music, where I was fortunate to be in the choir for Leonard Bernstein's "Mass." One of my best memories ever was listening to Mr. Bernstein, sitting on stage with us, giving us notes on our production. In my thirties, I returned to college to become a paramedic in Texas, where I had ample opportunities to meet and assist homeless men and women.  Over the years I've also been a church musician, directing large groups of musicians and singers, even writing skits and producing parish productions of musical events. I am also a wife, a mother and a grandmother. All this in my background came together the day I wrote "A Symphony for Portland."

"A Symphony for Portland" is the story of a high school senior, named Starr, who one day must choose between her loving, but distant and controlling widowed father and Jesse, a man she met one day in the park that she has fallen for. She also meets Jordan and his partner, Aaron, a homeless couple who will offer her a third alternative, to become homeless with them and their friends, Sarah and Brianna. What will she choose to do? What would you do?

By supporting this project, you will not only bring a musical to the stage, a worthy endeavor in its own right, but you will also help me bring it to towns and cities across the country, where I will engage the cooperation of homeless shelters, especially those whose focus is on young people. In exchange for venue and marketing assistance, they will receive tickets that they can sell for themselves. Plus, they will be invited to have someone present at the theater ready with information of what their particular shelter provides to the local community and to answer questions the theater goers might have. We will begin on the West coast where I live and head east toward Broadway, giving as many performances as possible on the way.

The $35,000 I am asking for will be for the initial staged readings and expenses related to starting and running a traveling theater company. Everyone who donates at least $10 will receive a reward version of the song "The Holidays" mailed to you. Other levels will include additional sheet music of other songs from the play, some of which will be autographed. At different levels, there will be small posters added, an logo umbrella and at the higher levels, comp tickets. For any donation amount, I am already grateful. And for sharing my project with others, I am truly thankful. I do ask that you read the read the following notice before donating.

"A Symphony for Portland" is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of "A Symphony for Portland must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law."

HERE ARE SOME OF THE WAYS YOUR DONATION WILL BE USED.

$10 will help print the programs for the staged reading. $20 will help print scores and scripts for the actors and musicians. $50 will go toward getting some of the songs recorded and put online so you can hear what you're donating toward.  $100 will help pay for my arranger. $250 will help with venue rental. Of course, there are and will be other expenses, but nothing will be wasted. Anything amount over the request amount will go toward the full production. Anything over and above that will be handled according to my agreement with Fractured Atlas.

WHAT IMPACT WILL MY DONATION HAVE? 

The biggest impact your support of this project may bring, none of us will ever know. What if a parent or older sibling sees the musical, finds it hitting a little too close to home, and feels the need to call that one older teen/young adult still living at home, to let them know, remind them, that they are loved, right then and there? And what if by telling them, "Have I told you today 'I love you?'", and "I'm not giving up on you, or us," keeps that young person from running away that night? or even more miraculous, keeps them from attempting suicide that night?

I hope you will help me get this project on the road, because "what if?" has the potential to make a true difference in a young person's life.

Thank you.

story:
Our Workshop East

Lenore DeKoven, Artistic Director

presents

The R Word

A Collection of Original 10-minute Plays about RACISM

We need your help to bring these plays to the stage!!

Our Workshop East will present THE R WORD, 10-minute plays on the theme of racism, December 1-3, 2016 at Theatre 54 in New York City.

  • 2 Programs of 6 original plays, in repertory
  • All developed by members of the Workshop
  • Under the direction of Lenore DeKoven

Can you help?

Our writers, directors, actors and producers are donating time and talent to this important project. However, we still need to raise the funds to compensate AEA performers and designers, rent theatre & rehearsal space, build a set/lights--- and of course, advertise and sell tickets. Here's how you can help:

  • Any donation you can make to support this project, and the voices of 10 writers on this important theme--- will help. 
  • Share this campaign with others
  • Come see the shows in December! Click here to be added to our mailing list.
THANK you, in advance-- for any help you can give.  
-----------------------------------------
WRITERS contributing to  THE "R" WORD include:

--------------------------------------

SOME WORKSHOP HISTORY... from Lenore DeKoven:

Our Workshop began in Los Angeles in 1978 when my graduating MFA acting/directing class at UCLA didn’t want to part with each other or me.  In 1981, when I moved back to New York, several of that group relocated to New York as well and formed the nucleus of what became Our Workshop East.

Since those early days, as our ranks grew and flourished, we were joined by graduates from NYU and Columbia theatre and film schools. The Workshop  became a unique creative environment for professional actors, writers and directors. 

Under my personal direction and using the approach outlined in my book, CHANGING DIRECTION, we work together to develop a common vocabulary, encourage individual growth and develop the techniques to serve any professional situation. It is a gym in which trained writers, directors and actors exercise and further refine their craft, expanding their abilities through mutual collaboration in a supportive and challenging environment.  Thus the work on any given night might include the development or direction of a play or screenplay, preparation of an actor’s audition or a singer’s aria or work on a scene from a Shakespeare play from both acting and directing points of view. Notable Workshop alumni include Ang Lee, Lisa Cholodenko and Debra Granik.

From time to time the Workshop has initiated a group project that might utilize some or all of the crafts: acting, writing and directing, often encouraging members to cross over into less familiar disciplines. Our presentation history is below.

WORKSHOP PRODUCTIONS

THE NEXT INGREDIENT A compilation of member work, Bowerie Lane Theatre

DAYS TO COME by Lillian Hellman, Hudson Guild Theatre

PACK OF LIES by Hugh Whitemore, Theatre of the Open Eye

THE LOVER by Harold Pinter, One Act play presented twice with different directors and different through lines, West Side Dance Project

O’HENRY’S SHORTS, Original one acts adapted from O’Henry short stories, Ernie Martin Studio Theatre 

COUNSELLOR AT LAW  by Elmer Rice, Producers Theatre

THREE MEN ON A HORSE  by George Abbott and John Cecil Holm, at the Masterworks Lab Theatre

DOWNSIZING, Original ten-minute plays,  TBG MainStage


For more information visit our FB page!

**Please also share this campaign with your friends and family via an email or social media. The more buzz we can create the closer to the stage we will be!**
story_txt:
Our Workshop EastLenore DeKoven, Artistic DirectorpresentsThe R WordA Collection of Original 10-minute Plays about RACISMWe need your help to bring these plays to the stage!!Our Workshop East will present THE R WORD, 10-minute plays on the theme of racism, December 1-3, 2016 at Theatre 54 in New York City.
2 Programs of 6 original plays, in repertory
All developed by members of the Workshop
Under the direction of Lenore DeKoven
Can you help?Our writers, directors, actors and producers are donating time and talent to this important project. However, we still need to raise the funds to compensate AEA performers and designers, rent theatre & rehearsal space, build a set/lights--- and of course, advertise and sell tickets. Here's how you can help:
Any donation you can make to support this project, and the voices of 10 writers on this important theme--- will help. 

Share this campaign with others
Come see the shows in December! Click here to be added to our mailing list.
THANK you, in advance-- for any help you can give.  -----------------------------------------WRITERS contributing to  THE "R" WORD include:


--------------------------------------SOME WORKSHOP HISTORY... from Lenore DeKoven:Our Workshop began in Los Angeles in 1978 when my graduating MFA acting/directing class at UCLA didn’t want to part with each other or me.  In 1981, when I moved back to New York, several of that group relocated to New York as well and formed the nucleus of what became Our Workshop East.Since those early days, as our ranks grew and flourished, we were joined by graduates from NYU and Columbia theatre and film schools. The Workshop  became a unique creative environment for professional actors, writers and directors. Under my personal direction and using the approach outlined in my book, CHANGING DIRECTION, we work together to develop a common vocabulary, encourage individual growth and develop the techniques to serve any professional situation. It is a gym in which trained writers, directors and actors exercise and further refine their craft, expanding their abilities through mutual collaboration in a supportive and challenging environment.  Thus the work on any given night might include the development or direction of a play or screenplay, preparation of an actor’s audition or a singer’s aria or work on a scene from a Shakespeare play from both acting and directing points of view. Notable Workshop alumni include Ang Lee, Lisa Cholodenko and Debra Granik.From time to time the Workshop has initiated a group project that might utilize some or all of the crafts: acting, writing and directing, often encouraging members to cross over into less familiar disciplines. Our presentation history is below.
WORKSHOP PRODUCTIONS
THE NEXT INGREDIENT A compilation of member work, Bowerie Lane Theatre
DAYS TO COME by Lillian Hellman, Hudson Guild Theatre
PACK OF LIES by Hugh Whitemore, Theatre of the Open Eye
THE LOVER by Harold Pinter, One Act play presented twice with different directors and different through lines, West Side Dance Project
O’HENRY’S SHORTS, Original one acts adapted from O’Henry short stories, Ernie Martin Studio Theatre 
COUNSELLOR AT LAW  by Elmer Rice, Producers Theatre
THREE MEN ON A HORSE  by George Abbott and John Cecil Holm, at the Masterworks Lab Theatre
DOWNSIZING, Original ten-minute plays,  TBG MainStage


For more information visit our FB page!

**Please also share this campaign with your friends and family via an email or social media. The more buzz we can create the closer to the stage we will be!**

story:
Short Summary

My name is Benjamin Stopek, I am funding a senior project at SUNY Purchase. The show A.G.i.G:A.B.I.T.E. will go up in the Underground (in the Performing Arts Center), the first week of November.

Your contribution will assist in getting costumes, provide projection software, and supply the production with props.

The show is highly minimalist, relying mainly on projection. I am passionate about this approach, since I believe that the future of theatre lies in projection, and the ability to borrow narrative techniques from the silver screen. 

What We Need

  • $200 for costume.
  • $200 projection software and hardware rental.
  • $100 for props.
The Impact

I hope that this production will serve as an inspiration to students at SUNY Purchase, to pursue their own creativity when approaching theatre. We are the new generation of theatre makers, and we have the power to change the future of our craft.

Highlighting questions pertaining to perception v.s. reality, gender, and the idea of a collective subconscious. The show hopes to be a starting point for discussion of these topics.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please share a link to this page on your facebook or other social media.

      Just come see, it will be an experience to remember.
