story:
Wisps of damp fog run up your arms and a gentle snow begins to fall as your ears fill with the clash of steel on steel, all while soaring operatic Heavy Metal music pounds in rhythm with your heart. This is Aeterno Elementum.

The Story…

Aeterno Elementum takes place in a world filled with cruelty and hate, where suffering and misery have become so commonplace that the very heavens themselves become twisted and corrupted. One man, with the best of intentions, sets about trying to restore purity to the world, but succeeds only in hastening the world’s tragically inevitable, and necessary, death. Four men hold the key to the world’s rebirth: a disgraced Samurai, a corrupt nobleman, a former assassin, and a unconquerable warlord. And behind it all stands the Demoness, borne of mankind’s cruelty, who has come to orchestrate the world’s ending.

Aeterno Elementum isn’t a story that will just occur on stage, it will play out around you and amongst you. You’ll feel the heat of the flames as betrayal claims a man’s honor. You’ll hear the waves break against the rocks as envy and desire dooms a man’s soul. You’ll see assassins creeping through the audience, perhaps even sneak right past you, as they hunt a man who couldn’t escape his past. The drums of war will echo in your chest as mankind makes one final stand.

That is Aeterno Elementum: a story you’ll experience with every sense your body possesses. An experience you won’t get anywhere else

The People…

Jeremiah Johnson began Ara’Kus Productions six years ago when he first began composing Aeterno Elementum. It began with just a small group of friends playing in bars and clubs, but it quickly became clear that they couldn’t tell the story they wanted to in such limited venues. That’s when they began taking their songs onto the stage, using their heavy metal music to craft an opera unlike any other. The uniqueness of Aeterno Elementum quickly brought in waves of talented and passionate people who were eager to take part, volunteering their time and talents to bring Aeterno Elementum to life. From a small group of musicians, we’ve grown into a full blown theater production company of nearly sixty people, featuring a full heavy metal band and choir, as well as:

  • Fire Dancers

  • Acrobats

  • Actors

  • Live Steel Combatants

  • Costume Designers

  • Writers

  • Sound Engineers

  • Lighting Experts

What We Need to Succeed

We’re seeking to raise $9000 dollars in order to pay for our production costs and allow us to create the best show possible. The money will go towards:

  • Set Construction – $2000.00

  • Set Storage – $556.00

  • Costumes – $1000.00

  • Liability Insurance (We work with lots of pointy objects.) – $700.00

  • Fire Permits (Those pointy objects are sometimes on fire.) – $450.00

  • Theater Deposit – $2400.00

  • Advertising – $3310.00

  • Programs – $315.00

In exchange for your support we’ll be offering you variety of perks, ranging from signed CDs, photos and t-shirts to VIP tickets that get you a backstage tour and the best seats in the house. You can see a full range of our Perks and detailed descriptions right over there -->

And here's an example of the drawings you can expect from the Demonic and Greater Demonic Possession perks:

In addition to these perks, because we're working with Fractured Atlas, you can opt to get a tax deductible receipt for your donation, minus the value of any items you may be receiving.

Risks and Challenges

We’re a group of artists and creators that are incredibly passionate about this show, and we’ve had six years of experience bringing the apocalypse to the stage with limited resources. We’ve brought to life epic fights between demons and knights with an impossibly small budget, so we know how to get the most of our resources. That said, this is without a doubt our most ambitious project to date and is going to represent both a significant challenge to pull off and a huge risk for our company.

The costumes alone are going to be a tremendous task to create, and since we’re working with a stage nearly twice the size of what we’re used to, set construction will be a massive undertaking. Getting the lighting, the sound, the special effects and the combat choreography all to mesh together perfectly will be a great challenge. It won’t be easy, but with your support, we’re confident we can do it.

Spread the Word of the Coming Apocalypse

We want you to spread the word of the coming apocalypse. Even if you can’t afford to support us financially, simply spreading the word about our campaign will be a huge help to us. So tell your friends and family. Share this page on Twitter and Facebook. Go out onto the street in a monk’s robe and a sign saying “The End is Nigh!” and yell it out at the top of your lungs.

I’m not sure that last one would actually help… but it would be funny none the less.

Or if you just want to buy tickets to the show, they’re already on sale! You can get them here  !

story:
Hello!


We are Bunbanter's Young Theatre Company. We've devised a show, inspired by all of the recent debate regarding gender equality, that has been heavily featured in the media recently (particularly Emma Watson's UN speech https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p-iFl4qhBsE). We all believe in the connectedness of all people and we want to share this message as best we can!

However, as a primarily educational company working under a not-for-profit, community interest company, we do not have the funds to put on the show without you. We will be using any donations for

- Payment for everyone helping us out, including our mentors and technicians on the day.

- Props, costumes and sets, so our piece can look the best it can.

- Photographs and other material so that we might use it to attract new members to our group.


We know that not everyone has money at these troubling time, so anything you can do would be a great help to us - a share, a like or just a word to a friend would help us immensely!!!


Thanks!

story: Our primary mission is to celebrate the spiritual essence of mankind - that we are spiritual beings having a physical experience here on Earth. When this life is completed, we return to God who is our home. In the meantime, we each have a mission in life. It is our hope that we can assist others in recognizing their mission!

story:
Summary

The Liberty Theatre Foundation is a nonprofit organization located in La Grande, Oregon. Our mission is to restore and operate the Liberty Theatre as a community performing arts center that will serve our region.

Installed in 1930, the Liberty Theatre's iconic eagle blade sign hung on the facade of the building for 15 years before it was removed and scrapped. We see the beautiful eagle sign as symbol of this project and one of the first steps to making the restoration of the Liberty a success. 

La Grande is situated at the foothills of the Blue Mountains in rural Eastern Oregon with a population of about 12,000. During it's height, the town hosted five different theaters. But times changed for the both the community and the entertainment landscape. Today only one of these theaters remains in operation. 

The Liberty Theatre is an important piece of La Grande's and Eastern Oregon's history that deserves to be preserved. However, beyond the preservation is the impact that this theater will have on the members of our community. The theater will host a wide-variety of programming from plays, musical performances, Oregon Humanities talks, dance and more! The Foundation will collaborate with existing community arts organizations like Eastern Oregon Film Festival, La Grande Shakespeare and the Elgin Opera House to increase the accessibility and quality of programming available to the citizens of the Grande Ronde Valley.

You hold the key to our success! Your gift to the sign recreation project relights the Liberty Theatre, reintroducing it to our community as a theater once again. It opens the door for future giving and is a symbol of what many of us know to be true, the Liberty will thrive once again.


What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $2,000 from our online community to help us make the recreation of the sign happen! The total budget for this project is about $40,000. Over 75% of the funds will come from grants. We are aiming to raise the remaining $10,000 from our community through fundraisers and larger individual gifts. We have set a goal of $2,000 online, but it is our ultimate goal to raise more than that. We know our supporters can do it! If we do not meet our goal, funds will still go to support the sign project.

As a nonprofit organization, and a young one that that, we do not have a collection of fancy perks to reward you with. Instead we want your donation to go directly to the sign, not into our operating budget. Your gift makes a greater impact this way!

That said, we do have a few fun things lined out to thank you for your gift. Check them out on your right!

If you are an Oregonian, your gift will qualify you for a tax-credit from the Oregon Cultural Trust.  Match your gift to the Liberty Theatre Foundation with a gift to OCT and receive your OCT gift back as a tax credit. Visit OCT's website for more information. 


The Impact

The installation of the sign on the facade of the Liberty Theatre will have a profound impact on the projection and future of the restoration project as a whole.

Since its closure in 1959, the Liberty Theatre has slowly faded from community memory. Most that pass by the building on the street see the building as retail space only, the former home of Dominos Pizza.  Little do they know that within the walls of the Liberty is a partially preserved theater waiting to be uncovered once again.

You can bring the memory of the theater back to life by helping us put a replica of its historic sign back on the building.  This sign is completely unique. There are no signs left like it in Eastern Oregon! It will be what the Liberty is recognized by for decades to come. 

With this increased recognition comes the opportunity to gather more support for restoring the theater from our community and our region. Your gift to this project multiplies the amount we can raise in the future!

Check out a video done by the La Grande Observer's Tim Mustoe last December that talks about the impact of the project.



Risks & Challenges

Like all restoration projects, the restoration of the Liberty Theatre and the fabrication and installation of the sign could take longer than the projected timeline. In the past, delayed timelines have been as a result of funding constraints. This is why were are seeking assistance from our community early on in order negate this issue.

This project will be partially funded by grants. There is a chance that our grant requests will not be 100% funded. As such, we have built in cushioning into our budget to prevent this from creating a delay in the project.


Other Ways You Can Help

Any gift matters, no matter what the size. Even a dollar moves us one step closer to a beautiful, restored theater.

If you are unable to give at this time, please consider sharing this page with your friends via email and social media. Take a moment to visit our website and sign up for our email list or get in touch with us if you would like to volunteer for our cause.

story:
Support Artistic Innovation

Hi! I'm Lauren Hlubny, a recently graduated experimental theatre director in NYC, and I'm joined by an amazing team of artists, Josh Dent (cellist extraordinaire, Nashville), Christin Call (fearless dancer, Seattle), and Daniel Christensen (valiant actor, Seattle).

We are coming together in Seattle to make a brand-spanking-new theatre piece for the famous experimental venue On The Boards, the newly opened Pocket Theatre, and a variety of other venues around Seattle. 

The piece has everything you could ask for: music inspired by the Beatles, a dancer in pointe shoes and chains, and text from the Father of the Surrealists himself, Arthur Rimbaud. A conversation between mediums of art unlike any other. We plan to take the commonly used word "interdisciplinary" to the next level!

Though this piece means staging a dream in a dream venue, it's also being done on zero budget. 

This is the first production I will be doing since graduation, in the "real world" so-to-speak, and we absolutely need your help. Help a ragtag group of interdisciplinary artists undertake the mammoth task of changing the face of experimental theatre one venue at a time, one dream at a time. Thank you!

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need your help. You, the amazing person with an artist inside waiting to support some people trying to make some dreams happen. The perks we are offering range from poetry to video footage, we're trading art for your generous support of art. 
  • If we don't reach our goal, the production is still happening, but is much less feasible. So every little bit really does help!
Where your contribution goes:
$1200                
Roundtrip airplane tickets to and from Seattle for a Cellist, a Director, and a Cello (yes, the cello gets a seat)
$489
Living expenses for three weeks for Josh + Lauren + cello
$450
Rehearsal Space/any props needed
$161
Indiegogo and Banking Fees
=$2300
Our Total Goal!

The Who (not the band)

Lauren Hlubny is a recently graduated experimental theatre director based in New York City. Past credits include a non-stop three-day long marathon intergalactic jam session titled Emily Dickinson: OUTER SPACE! at NYC's The Bushwick Starr, a full length circus-theatre production titled Cabaret Metamorphoses at the San Francisco Circus Center, and DALI a dance-theatre exploration in New Horizons Original Works Festival in Tallahassee, FL and the world-renowned Salvador Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, FL. 

Christin Call Nobody knows Christin Call, the choreographer/dancer/poet/visual artist. Mostly for existential reasons. Also insufficient branding. She has self-published two collections of poetry, The Mountain? The Mountain in 2008 and cede the crown palaver (failed attempts, false starts, and a sincere apology) in 2014. Christin is a classically trained dancer and also studies Gaga, most recently under Batsheva Dance Company’s Co-artistic Director Adi Sawant in NY.  She is a Co-founder and Co-artistic Director of Coriolis Dance with Natascha Greenwalt.  Their latest work, Unfixed Arias, previewed at the Belltown Collective in May 2014.  

Daniel Christensen has been active in Seattle’s fringe theatre scene since 1999, working with EXITheatre, Annex Theatre, Live Girls!, Theater Schmeater, and The 14/48 Projects, among others.  Most recently he appeared as Stephen in The Lisbon Traviata with Theatre22. By day he’s an electrician.

Joshua Dent began playing cello at the age of fourteen in Kissimmee, Florida. At the age of sixteen he began improvising and exploring genres outside of the classical umbrella of music. His career is always changing; currently, his work ranges from playing in chamber music groups, vaudeville style bands, rock groups, and jazz ensembles, to playing with singer/songwriters and in recording studios. Josh also teaches improvisation workshops to cello studios around the country. With an active and fruitful career, he travels around the United States playing in various genres of music, spending much of the year away from his home base of Nashville.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell Your Friends

Spreading the word is just as valuable as donating. Make sure your friends and family know about this campaign and This is Not a Table for Three by using the IndieGoGo social media tools to share on your networks. 

If you have friends in the Seattle area, invite them to become a part of the experience by seeing the show!

All Because Of YOU

We can't thank you enough for your interest and support. There are so many amazing campaigns out there, and we're grateful that you're considering ours. Together, we can keep the theatre arts edgy and thriving for generations to come. Thank you, thank you, thank you!

Support Artistic Innovation Hi! I'm Lauren Hlubny, a recently graduated experimental theatre director in NYC, and I'm joined by an amazing team of artists, Josh Dent (cellist extraordinaire, Nashville), Christin Call (fearless dancer, Seattle), and Daniel Christensen (valiant actor, Seattle).
We are coming together in Seattle to make a brand-spanking-new theatre piece for the famous experimental venue On The Boards, the newly opened Pocket Theatre, and a variety of other venues around Seattle. 
The piece has everything you could ask for: music inspired by the Beatles, a dancer in pointe shoes and chains, and text from the Father of the Surrealists himself, Arthur Rimbaud. A conversation between mediums of art unlike any other. We plan to take the commonly used word "interdisciplinary" to the next level!
Though this piece means staging a dream in a dream venue, it's also being done on zero budget. 

This is the first production I will be doing since
graduation, in the "real world" so-to-speak, and we absolutely need your help. Help a ragtag group of interdisciplinary artists undertake the mammoth task of changing the face of experimental theatre one venue at a time, one dream at a time. Thank you!
   What We Need & What You Get

We need your help. You, the amazing person with an artist inside waiting to support some people trying to make some dreams happen. The perks we are offering range from poetry to video footage, we're trading art for your generous support of art. 
If we don't reach our goal, the production is still happening, but is much less feasible. So every little bit really does help! 
Where your contribution goes:


$1200
               Roundtrip airplane tickets to and from Seattle for a Cellist, a Director, and a Cello (yes, the cello gets a seat)


$489

Living expenses for three weeks for Josh + Lauren + cello


$450

Rehearsal Space/any props needed


$161

Indiegogo and Banking Fees


=$2300

Our Total Goal!



The Who (not the band)
Lauren Hlubny is a recently graduated experimental theatre director based in New York City. Past credits include a non-stop three-day long marathon intergalactic jam session titled Emily Dickinson: OUTER SPACE! at NYC's The Bushwick Starr, a full length circus-theatre production titled Cabaret Metamorphoses at the San Francisco Circus Center, and DALI a dance-theatre exploration in New Horizons Original Works Festival in Tallahassee, FL and the world-renowned Salvador Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, FL. 

Christin
Call Nobody
knows Christin Call, the choreographer/dancer/poet/visual artist. Mostly
for existential reasons. Also insufficient branding. She has
self-published two collections of poetry, The Mountain? The Mountain in
2008 and cede the crown palaver (failed attempts, false starts, and a
sincere apology) in 2014. Christin is a classically trained
dancer and also studies Gaga, most recently under Batsheva Dance Company’s
Co-artistic Director Adi Sawant in NY.  She is a Co-founder and
Co-artistic Director of Coriolis Dance with Natascha Greenwalt.  Their
latest work, Unfixed Arias, previewed at the Belltown Collective
in May 2014.  
Daniel Christensen has been active in Seattle’s fringe theatre scene since 1999, working with EXITheatre, Annex Theatre, Live Girls!, Theater Schmeater, and The 14/48 Projects, among others.  Most recently he appeared as Stephen in The Lisbon Traviata with Theatre22. By day he’s an electrician.
Joshua Dent began playing cello at the age of fourteen in Kissimmee, Florida. At the age of sixteen he began improvising and exploring genres outside of the classical umbrella of music. His career is always changing; currently, his work ranges from playing in chamber music groups, vaudeville style bands, rock groups, and jazz ensembles, to playing with singer/songwriters and in recording studios. Josh also teaches improvisation workshops to cello studios around the country. With an active and fruitful career, he travels around the United States playing in various genres of music, spending much of the year away from his home base of Nashville.
Other Ways You Can Help
 
Tell Your FriendsSpreading the word is just as valuable as donating. Make sure your friends and family know about this campaign and This is Not a Table for Three by using the IndieGoGo social media tools to share on your networks. If you have friends in the Seattle area, invite them to become a part of the experience by seeing the show!All Because Of YOUWe can't thank you enough for your interest and support. There are so many amazing campaigns out there, and we're grateful that you're considering ours. Together, we can keep the theatre arts edgy and thriving for generations to come. Thank you, thank you, thank you!

story:
Vision Statement
My vision is to revive performing arts, fine arts and culture in the Inland Empire. To expose the talent of youth and adults who live in the Inland Empire and surrounding areas, who may not otherwise have the time, money, or availability to drive out to Los Angeles to audition and partake in this genre of entertainment.

 

The Production
Kitty Come Home is the story of a sassy 19 year old church girl, who leaves home, against her father’s wishes, to pursue her dream career as a singer on the hottest record label in the 1960’s. Upon many test, trials, ups, and downs… she discovers what the world of secular music is really about. Kitty finds her way back home, but with many twist and turns along the way… Kitty Come home is an homage to Motown, intertwining music from that era and music from today, reminiscent of that era. This production is sure to put the music back in musical. Exciting entertainment for people of all ages, especially music lovers!

 

Performances:  TBD upon funding
Tentative Dates: Summer 2012!!!!
Tentative Location: Lewis Family Playhouse @ Victoria Gardens
                                     12505 Cultural Center Drive,

                                     Rancho Cucamonga, CA 91739
Who I Am

Karla Kimble, Writer, producer, spoken word poet, choreographer, actress, dancer, aspiring filmmaker, playwright.

 

How you’re Helping Me?
Breakdown of where the funds will be going: (Estimations)
$2,620 = Theatre Rental, Technician Rental, Front House Staff Rental
$3,000 - $4,000 = Artist Compensation: Actors, Costume Stylist/ Seamstress, Make Up, Hair, stage hands, production assistant.
$1,000 = Marketing: Newspaper, Billboards, radio, ect.
$1,000 = Printing: Scripts, Flyers, Tickets, Programs, Posters, ect.
$2,000 – $3,000 = Stage: Microphones, Set Builders/Carpenters, lighting, sound
$TBD = 1 Million Dollar Insurance Policy for the City of Rancho Cucamonga.
$1000 = Food, water, gas for the cast and production team
$500 = Photographer and Videographer

 

What You'll Receive for Helping Us

If you donate………

$1 - $24
If you donate $1 - $24 dollars you receive a personal thank you notice and recognition as a contributor in the program.
$25 - $49

If you donate $25 - $49 dollars you receive a thank you in the program and on my website.

$50 - $99

If you donate $50 - $99 dollars you receive all of the above plus verbal recognition. If you are a business, small or large, your business will receive recognition as well!

$100 - $249

If you donate $100 - $249 you receive all of the above plus two VIP tickets to Kitty Come Home!

$250 - $499

If you donate $250 - $499 you receive all of the above, a picture with the cast and producer.  

$500 or more

If you donate $500 or more you receive all of the above plus a DVD and autographed poster of the cast.

$1,000 or more

If you donate $1,000 or more you receive all of the above plus, advertisement/promotion of your business on web site, in program, and verbally at the show, and a private dinner or brunch with you, some of the cast, the producer, and other $1,000 plus donators!


Other Ways You Can Help
Please help get the word out about my campaign by sharing with friends, family and co-workers on any of your social networking pages such as Facebook, Myspace, Twitter, and ect.!!!! Thank you so much, your assistance and contributions are greatly appreciated!

story:
Our Story

Hi,

My name is Anthony W Johnson. I am the creator of Ballet Magique. Ballet Magique is a fusion of dance, magic, illusion, music, theatre and wushu. The performers not only dance but perform magic and illusion. We have been offered the opportunity to perform We have been offered the opportunity to perform  for the Chinese New Year celebration in San Diego California. as well as other festivals abroad. 

Our goal is to raise enough capital to mount spectacular performance of our show The Ring of the Rose. 

Ring of the Rose is the story of brothers who upon chance fall in love with the same woman. The brothers are in constant turmoil with their own relationship as well as the cultural differences of the races. This turmoil leads to varied conflicts and choices when one of the brothers decides to take matters into his own hands. The Ring of Rose is a passionate love story full of high intense , and dynamic , diverse dance forms, pulsating magic and suspense with awe dropping wushu martial arts and vibrant costumes. 

The Ring of the Rose was first performed by Ballet Magique in Glendale CA to great success, with four Lester Horton Nominations and offers to perform the 10 minute act in various places around the world. Unfortunately as we were about to move forward Gene Wooley my former partner took ill and needed a liver transplant. He eventually, after many struggles and lots of pain, succumbed to his illness and passed away. Because this was and still is our dream, I am determined to keep his memory alive. One way I believe I can do this is to pick up where we left off, and mount the full version of Ring of the Rose for investors as well as the public who have supported us this far and use the capital from that performance to mount the tour that Gene and me always dreamed of.


Over the years, as a teacher, I have spawned many dancers who have danced for me in Ballet Magique and gone on to fantastic careers with Cirque du Soliel, Alvin Ailey Dance Theatre on on Broadway in shows like The Lion King, Come Fly Away, Movin Out and The Color Purple, as well as tours with Janet Jackson, Christina Aguilera and Britney Spears.


Ballet Magique’s mission is to inspire dancers of all nationalities, and to create a new an exciting form of entertainment fusing not only the cultural arts but media technology and illusion.

By fusing classic art forms, including several different kinds of dance, magic, music, theatre, and visual effects, we elevate all of them to a new and glorious level that entrances all audiences even those who have seen all of our competitor’s productions. 


Ballet Magique Entertainment stands alone in the pantheon of artistic achievement and we are committed to enriching current and future generations by offering a fascinating outlook on the virtuosity of the human body, while engaging the mystique of the human psyche. 


What We Need

The funds that we are raising here will help towards offsetting travel costs to San Diego as well to help mount the show.

 

Other Ways to Help

Ballet Magique has been very fortunate to have had overwhelming pubic support over the years for which we are extremely grateful and truly appreciate.  Every dollar raised will be spent on hard costs to put up the best show possible so we hope that you will reach out to your friends and family on our behalf and help us spread the word so that we can reach our goal and begin our new journey. By advertising space in our dynamic program.  Most of Ballet Magique’s show’s including the  Poway show is advertised all over California as well as our press release will go out through out the US and abroad.. Another way to help is our “Sponsor a Dancer Program. Please email us and we can send you all the necessary materials to join that effort.


If you invest into our cause there are great perks!  Including free Caribbean Getaway! (See side panel!)


You can also see a  promotional video of our last performance of Ring of the Rose here: This performance was part of the Arabesque series at The Alex Theatre in Glendale, CA

http://vimeo.com/17874063


 We want to update the show and revise in memory of Gene. This will be the first performance where Ballet Magique is the only act and can finally make money. Ballet Magique has been mainly seen in festivals so we have not generated any income. By helping us it will change the future success of our company. We will be using all of his music for the show's content. The video features two of Gene's songs that we had in the show.



Indulge into the mystique of Ballet Magique!

story:
We are Theater RED, a Milwaukee-based theater company founded to produce works that provide substantial roles for women, growth for artists, and support new playwrights, especially local work.

We are proud to be presenting the world premiere of A LADY IN WAITING this August at Soulstice Theatre in Milwaukee, WI. Written by local playwright Liz Shipe, A LADY IN WAITING is an adventurous new twist on the legendary story of Robin Hood, told from a female point of view. 

With this show, we honor a tradition of giving held by our partner, Soulstice Theatre. In the charitable spirit of Robin Hood, we will donate a portion of our box office sales to Hunger Task Force.

What We Need & What You Get

Last year, we had a huge response to our Kickstarter campaign for the world premiere of A THOUSAND TIMES GOODNIGHT. This year, by popular demand, we are bringing several rewards to our audiences who don't mind pitching in a little extra to become a bigger part of the show.

As a small theater company, Theater RED often dreams bigger than its production budget allows. This campaign will allow us to fully realize our production plans, all while providing our backers with a unique and fun way to experience the show!

By supporting our project you will be helping us transform not only the theater, but also the lobby space into Sherwood Forest for a complete immerse audience experience – and who knows what you may find in the forest before the show!

From costumes by Liz Shipe to original music by Brian Myers and wondrous lighting effects by Alan Piotrowicz and AntiShadows, LLC, your contribution will bring the characters of Nottingham and Sherwood Forest to life, and transport patrons to the legendary world of Robin Hood for an evening of action, adventure, and fun!

    No contribution is too small. At the $5 level, you can be a part of the show with your name on a Wanted Poster on one of the trees in Sherwood Forest! The reward structure aims to provide unique perks at varying contribution levels to allow you to experience the show in an enhanced way.

    We will use any contributions received to focus first on transforming the theater and lobby to immerse our audience in Sherwood Forest from the moment they walk through the doors. Remaining funds will dress our Merry Men, our Nobles, and our ladies in the best finery.

    The Impact

    Theater RED was founded to provide substantial roles for women, support growth for artists, and produce new works, especially by local playwrights. We are proud to present A LADY IN WAITING, which meets all these founding tenets by telling a classic story for audiences from a uniquely female perspective for a fresh twist on an adventurous classic; providing stage combat training from Dueling Arts International Associate Instructor Christopher Elst in the disciples of broadsword and quarterstaff that will be featured in the show (talk about live action!) And, producing an original play by local budding playwright Liz Shipe. Liz is the author of the SHERLOCK HOLMES TRILOGY and HOME FOR CHRISTMAS, which have both had successful runs in Milwaukee theaters, and she is currently writing a holiday show by commission for 2015.

    Theater RED has had success with fundraising in the past. Last year, Theater RED produced its first world premiere, A THOUSAND TIMES GOODNIGHT, and exceeded its funding goal on its Kickstarter campaign. Theater RED has chosen Indiegogo for A LADY IN WAITING because it wanted to be transparent with its backers that the funding will be used to fully realize the production plans and vision for the show, but the basic plans and design have already been accounted for in the show’s budget.

    Help us “plant” trees, sew costumes, and enhance the performance with lights, music, and props to fully immerse the audience in our world for a night, and share in the action, adventure, and intrigue of Nottingham and Sherwood Forest!

    Risks & Challenges

    We recognize that being dependent on fundraising brings with it risks and challenges, chief of them being that if our funding goals are not fully realized, we will need to make decisions about where the money we are grateful to have raised should be first earmarked. 

    We also realize that Theater RED had a successful fundraising campaign in November of 2013 and contributors might feel less compelled to donate to our theater again in less than a one year period. We hope that our founding principles and this world premiere production resonate with potential backers, and that the perks we are offering offer a unique benefit to supporting our efforts once again.

    Acknowledging our past successes and the help that so many people have provided to Theater RED in the past, we are proud to partner with Hunger Task Force for this production to pay that forward in a small way.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We know that there are many worthwhile projects that ask for your financial support and that it is impossible to donate to them all. We hope you will consider sharing this project with your family and friends. Your endorsement of A LADY IN WAITING as a worthy project means a lot to us, and sharing our project can help spread the word about Theater RED and the work we founded the company to do!

    Merrily yours,

    Christopher & Marcee Elst

story:
Short Summary

This show started out as a way to get young people interested in Shakespeare 7 years ago. Since then, this hybrid of Macbeth and the Star Wars Universe has been performed three times for children's theatre and once at a regional theater in Michigan. This newest production marks its first debut by professionals for a Chicago audience. It is fast paced, epically staged, and a whole lotta fun!

Understand that this is Shakespeare's Macbeth set in the Star Wars Universe. It isn't Luke Skywalker; it's Young Siward. It's not Obi Wan; it's King Duncan. Shakespeare's traditional language is there, but so are the lightsabers!

What We Need & What You Get

EDGE Community Theatre is unique in that it is produced by the company. Everyone kicks in dues, and then from there we assemble our budget. But we are a semi-pro theatre so our professionals get paid once that budget has been wiped out. Your gifts allow this to happen!

Our perks are a mixture of the classic and the fantastic! Any amount helps, but we recommend the Audio Drama. We are recording an old timey radio show of our production complete with scoring and sound effects! So if you are unable to make it to Chicago to see the show live, you can still experience it!

The Impact

Keeping the classics relevant to all people remains as important to our culture now as it did 7 years ago when this project started. This show remains the perfect experience to thrill an old Shakespeare enthusiast or a complete newbie!

EDGE premiered last year with the well received loving tribute to The Princess Bride. Its production team also succesfully mounted two productions of Pirates of Penzance under sail on the Tall Ship Windy at Chicago's Navy Pier. Our track record shows we are dedicated story tellers bringing the exciting and unusual to the stage!

Also...we are colossal nerds! Support your local nerds!

Other Ways You Can Help

We could really use your help spreading the word. I'm sure you are like, duh, everyone wants that. Yeah, but here is the deal - our tickets are live at www.edgeoforion.com. Tell your Chicago based friends to buy 'em up right now. The theatre is cozy so seats are limited! We also have an event on facebook - "MacSith by EDGE Community Theatre (ECT)"

Since then, this hybrid of Macbeth and the Star Wars Universe has been performed three times for children's theatre and once at a regional theater in Michigan. This newest production marks its first debut by professionals for a Chicago audience. It is fast paced, epically staged, and a whole lotta fun!
Understand that this is Shakespeare's Macbeth set in the Star Wars Universe. It isn't Luke Skywalker; it's Young Siward. It's not Obi Wan; it's King Duncan. Shakespeare's traditional language is there, but so are the lightsabers!


What We Need & What You Get
EDGE Community Theatre is unique in that it is produced by the company. Everyone kicks in dues, and then from there we assemble our budget. But we are a semi-pro theatre so our professionals get paid once that budget has been wiped out. Your gifts allow this to happen!
Our perks are a mixture of the classic and the fantastic! Any amount helps, but we recommend the Audio Drama. We are recording an old timey radio show of our production complete with scoring and sound effects! So if you are unable to make it to Chicago to see the show live, you can still experience it!


The Impact
Keeping the classics relevant to all people remains as important to our culture now as it did 7 years ago when this project started. This show remains the perfect experience to thrill an old Shakespeare enthusiast or a complete newbie!
EDGE premiered last year with the well received loving tribute to The Princess Bride. Its production team also succesfully mounted two productions of Pirates of Penzance under sail on the Tall Ship Windy at Chicago's Navy Pier. Our track record shows we are dedicated story tellers bringing the exciting and unusual to the stage!
Also...we are colossal nerds! Support your local nerds!


Other Ways You Can Help
We could really use your help spreading the word. I'm sure you are like, duh, everyone wants that. Yeah, but here is the deal - our tickets are live at www.edgeoforion.com. Tell your Chicago based friends to buy 'em up right now. The theatre is cozy so seats are limited! We also have an event on facebook - "MacSith by EDGE Community Theatre (ECT)"

story:
Short Summary

As Director of Philadelphia Dance Projects (PDP) and a former dancer/choreographer, I have initiated the LOCAL DANCE HISTORY PROJECT. The impetus for this project was practical.  Several cardboard boxes had been following me around for over 30 years from place to place. The contents of these boxes marked “archive” were a jumble of disintegrating papers and odd video formats, slides, photos and super-8 film reels – of myself a dancer/improviser and other artist collaborators   What to do with this?  How to get this history out of these boxes?  These boxes tell a story at a pivotal time for artists in Philadelphia - a story of developing forms and genres, communities and life styles.  

In 2010 through PDP's Local Dance History Project, I invited  Michael Biello, Dan Martin, Jano Cohen and Ishmael Houston-Jones to revisit some of the work of these original artists, including myself, with live performances, a workshop and a forum.  The performances featured collaborations with a new generation of dancers reconstructing  and re-imagining a selection of legacy dance works.

                        [Jano Cohen's  "Snow Falling on Waves"  photo: Brian Mengini]

These regenerated and revitalized ­dance works not only captured the spirit of those original works but also the imaginations of a new sphere of artists and audiences.  The wonderful success of these ‘local dance’ intergenerational works went a long way to validating the value and relevancy of these original artists and their work. It underscored the importance of sharing, preserving AND expanding these “stories” as part of a greater context in the creative community and our city’s history. - Terry Fox, PDP Director and LDHP dance artist

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to raise $7,500 to build the first phase of the Local Dance History Project website. Support will go to designer fees, hosting costs and digitalization of archival materials. If all goes well, and funds are raised, we can launch this phase in the Fall of 2014! And begin to share and gather more stories that are a part of this unique dance history.

Help us launch the first interactive web page of the Local Dance History Project with the TIMELINE. We will begin with a very special look into the evolution of post modern dance as glimpsed through the microcosm of an especially rich and vibrant era of independent dance and performance that was taking place in Philadelphia in the 1970’s and 80’s, beginning with artists; Terry Beck, Michael Biello, Jac Carley, Jano Cohen, Terry Fox, Tonio Guerra, Wendy Hammarstrom, Ishmael Houston-Jones, Steve Krieckhaus, and Dan Martin. 

Were you a choreographer, dancer, musician, visual artist, actor, performance artist, audience member ?  You will be able to tell your story by adding it to the Local Dance History Project TIMELINE.

                                                                                 [Design by Night Kitchen Interactive]

This special dance history will not only be broadly accessible via the internet  - but all the information collected will become part of the Special Collections Research Center of Temple University Libraries where it will find a permanent home.

The Impact

The Local Dance History Project is designed to re-engage audiences in an archival collection of dance & performance work from the 70’s and 80’s and make it relevant to today’s audiences.  It will serve as a bridge for accessing the role artists have played in the city’s cultural history; for connecting to artists and audiences; and grow that history into the 90’s and on into the 21st century. 

Your contribution will make it possible to build a site that engages audiences both old and new, perpetuates these works and preserves these experiences. Please become a part of this exciting project and help us tell our story and your story through the Local Dance History Project Timeline.  

With the Local Dance History Project, Philadelphia will have the first accessible web archive for dance ! 

This robust digital center will present possibilities for live programming as well as archival or static collections for exhibitions. It will serve a model for other cities and their histories creating a larger view of dance nationally.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t support this project financially, you can still help us get the word out. 

Philadelphia Dance Projects' LOCAL DANCE HISTORY PROJECT is a way to express that dance at the local level is important to the community.

story:
After a three year hiatus, the Ann Arbor Poetry Slam has found a new home and filled it with fresh faces! In August of 2013, Garret Potter, a poet from Portland, teamed up with slam veteran Lindsay Stone with the intention of bringing back the second-longest-running poetry slam in the world. Together, they organized and implemented the revival of A2 Slam.

While the Ann Arbor poetry slam and open mic serves a very necessary role in offering community members the opportunity to share their work, one of the purposes of the series is to send a team of poets to represent the city at the National Poetry Slam competition each year.

This year will be Ann Arbor’s first year back, but it won’t be without a boom. Help support a team of some of the most talented, hard-working poets in the region as they work to represent the city with their stories this August in Oakland!

What we need:
 
The Ann Arbor Poetry Slam needs to raise $3,000 to help fund our travels and hotel expenses for the 2014 National Poetry Slam in Oakland California. Additionally, we would like to continue building our relationship with the Ann Arbor community as well as the poetry community in general! To do this, we have put together a collection of really great perks!

Rather it is a book of poetry, a t-shirt, or a one-on-one workshop, the 2014 Slam Team is excited to share their passion and art with you! Take some time to review the perks on the right side of the website to see details about the items, bundles, and passes. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us!
 
The Impact:
  Each member of the 2014 Ann Arbor Slam Team has a different reason for doing poetry. However, the one thing that brings us together is such an amazing community. The poets and spectators who continually show their support at our weekly slams offer an enthusiastic and loving environment. Without them, there would be no us! Because of this, any money we raise beyond our goal will go directly back into the poetry community: continuing to run our weekly slams, bringing in features from all over, and sending future poets to competitions suchs as the Women of the World Poetry Slam, or the Individual World Poetry Slam.
 
Other Ways You Can Help:
  The easiest thing you can do to help us is share this website with your friends, families, and co-workers! Sharing a link on your social networking page can go a long way. But that is not all! Please make it a point to come visit the Ann Arbor Slam Team every Sunday at Silvios Organic Pizza in Ann Arbor Michigan! For only five dollars you can enjoy a night of poetry from some of the best people around, get to know the Ann Arbor Team, and get on the mic yourself!
Not to mention enjoy some delicious food and beverages!
www.silviosorganicpizza.com

story:
The Stella Adler Studio of Acting, a world-class actor training organization based in Manhattan since 1949, has served nearly 4,000 New York City teenagers through its Outreach Division. (Pictured below: the cast of William Shakespeare’s Comedy of Errors, August 2010)


While students in the Outreach Division are trained with the same intensity and integrity as conservatory students, this program is not concerned with creating professional actors, but rather empowering strong, confidant, thoughtful, articulate human beings. (Pictured below: Outreach Division students in rehearsal for Romeo and Juliet)


Reach for Success, a local organization in the heart of Isobel II, serves teenagers who aspire to go to college. They provide space for the program and assemble of group of students. (Pictured below: Students, Adler faculty and ambassadors and Reach for Success staff, June 2013)


The Stella Adler Studio provides theater practitioners and instructors who lead the workshop along with ambassadors, volunteers who participate and help to set a high level of participation. (Pictured below: Movement instructor Joanne Edelmann teaching New York University Bachelor of Fine Arts candidates)


Ambassadors who serve as volunteer participants or ringers who help to set professional standards in the classroom. (Pictured below: two ambassadors from the 2013 workshop)


In July 2012 Tommy Demenkoff worked with twenty students in a one-week pilot program. (Pictured below: Tommy Demenkoff at front center with some of the students)

In June 2013 the Stella Adler Outreach Division led by Tommy Demenkoff made a return trip to Vieques this time with movement instructor Joanne Edelmann. (Pictured below: some of the students after the final performances at the Fortin)


This workshop is designed to encourage every participant – whether they have an interest in a life in the arts or not – to connect with their authentic self, their true voice, their deepest convictions and impulses. (Pictured below: Instructor Tommy Demenkoff leading a class)


The workshop also uses local and regional stories, myths, news, experiences and/or song in creating an original work for a final public performance. (Pictured below: Students in Vieques rehearsing a play based in the Princess Guanina myth, June 2013)


Students reported that the acting workshops make them feel strong and confidant. (Pictured below: a student from the 2013 workshop)


The Stella Adler Studio proposes a June 2014. This program will cost $5,000 and the budget includes instructor salary, travel, meals and accommodation. Again the training is not about creating professional actors but imparting life skills through rigorous actor training. Among these skills are the ability to read great dramatic literature with depth, passion and imaginative intelligence; the ability to stand up tall and aligned and with a rooted voice speak powerful thoughts, powerfully; the ability to work with others to create a scene or play; the ability to embrace given circumstances and passionately empathize with others. These are some of the skills that Stella Adler taught and which the studio’s leadership believes can produce the ingredients of a good life, a committed life, a life worth living.

The Stella Adler Studio of Acting is a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization.

story:
Please feel free to e-mail me at ashleyforche18@gmail.com if you have any questions!

Short Summary

Hello! My name is Ashley Forché and I’m a sophomore at Columbus School for Girls and a dancer at BalletMet. I have been dancing since I was three years old and it has truly become my passion. My ultimate goal is to become a professional dancer. Dance provides me with a joy unlike anything else and has enriched my life in so many ways. When I dance, I am my purest form of myself, the best version of me, and that is why I love dance more than anything in the world. I have been in many performances including The Nutcracker, Swan Lake, Alice in Wonderland, Cinderella, The Sleeping Beauty, and Carnival of the Animals. I have also attended several local summer intensive programs in the past, including BalletMet’s Summer Intensive and Columbus Dance Theatre’s Summer Intensive, but I have not been able to take advantage of out of state opportunities due to limited financial resources. 

This year, I was accepted to the Orlando Ballet School’s Summer Intensive Program. It has always been my dream to attend this program, and I feel so fortunate to have been extended this incredible opportunity. This intensive will allow me to dance all day, six days a week for five consecutive weeks. Dancing at this kind of intensive level over the summer will allow me to grow by leaps and bounds as a dancer. Additionally, it will provide me the opportunity to meet new people, have different instructors, expand my network in the dance world and become a more well-rounded dancer. Attending this intensive would give me the opportunity to further my training to help me achieve my ultimate goal of becoming a professional dancer.

What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $6000 by April 30th. Intensives are very expensive, and this money would not only cover tuition and housing, but plane flights, dance wear, and pointe shoes. However, any amount I can raise would be greatly appreciated, as I am relying completely on donations to make it possible to attend this intensive.

To thank you for helping my cause, I am extending the following perks to my contributors - everyone who donates any amount will receive a handwritten thank you note, and any individual or business will also be promoted on my facebook page (the amount donated will be mentioned unless requested otherwise)!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to donate, please spread the word. Please take the time to share this with anyone and everyone who either has an interest in the arts or would consider helping me on the road to achieving my dreams.

Thank you for taking the time to consider and contribute to my cause!

story:
ThanksKilling The Musical

What happens when you take a terrible movie and set out to make an even more terrible musical? Jeff Thomson, Jordan Mann and David Eck decided to find out. All three were serious creators of musical theatre. They had everything that emerging artists need to make a name for themselves, awards, the respect of their peers and no money.

Being serious is all well and good, but every so often, there's a joy in writing something ridiculous, and as they sought a property to adapt, one name axe murdered its way up to the top of their list.

ThanksKilling. A movie about a foul-mouthed homicidal turkey that didn't include Rob Ford.

After seeing the original film of ThanksKilling, all three realized that this Turkey could not only fly. It could sing.

The original film's shoddy brilliance, its deliberately cliched characters, bad acting, terrible puns, absurd premise and keen self awareness are now the stuff of legend and the creators sought to not just polish the turd before them, but to embrace its turdiness and hold it aloft for all the world to see.

After receiving permission from the film's original creators, and embracing the film's "we shot it in a week for no money" essence, Jeff and Jordan wrote the entire show in three days. They were long days, filled with music, laughter and endless discussions on how many possible rhymes exist for MOTHER F**KER. As Jeff and Jordan wrote, the sublime and ridiculous got together and had a cheap and torrid one night stand and while several souls were condemned to the nether regions of hell, the work was completed and a musical was born in an orgy of blood and feathers and bad bird puns. 

The show was then blessed to be embraced by Balagan Theatre of Seattle, Washington who endowed the show with a cast, a director and the best scenery and costumes that could be had for $4.20.

It was just what was required, and ThanksKilling The Musical burst forth like a necromanced turkey through the innards of an inbred hick to audience adulation and critical praise.

Where will the Turkey strike next? That dear fans, is up to you.


"Is The Show Going to Be Recorded?"

From the moment that we announced there would be a production of ThanksKilling there was one question that was asked, over and over and over again. "Is the show going to be recorded?"

Our Facebook timelines and Twitter feeds were constantly filled with this request and we decided to finally give the fans what they've asked for, and give them to opportunity to put their money where their mouth is, and help us make this universal dream a reality.

So, we've decided to give it a shot and we're asking for your help. Because everyone deserves to be able to turkey trot to GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**KER on the treadmill and sing along to the infectious rock anthem MAN LOVE.


What We Need

We've been crunching numbers for months and the magic number to make this all happen is $15,000.00.

This covers the following:

  • Musical Director - The piano doesn't play itself and the actors need someone to teach them all of the gobble notes they'll be singing.
  • Actors/Singers - We have a cast of eight and while we could ask them to work for free, the ones you'd want to actually hear sing won't work for peanuts.
  • Rehearsal Studio - A room to rehearse for a couple of days, so we don't waste precious time and money in the the studio.
  • Insurance -  If an actor swallows a microphone while singing, we don't want them to sue us.
  • Studio Time - We expect it to take us two days to get it all "In the can". The acoustics in grandmas basement, are not what they used to be and we want to give you the best sound using the best equipment we can afford.
  • Engineer - Someone to mix live as the tracks are being recorded.
  • Post Production - Take everything we recorded in the studio, equalizing the levels, adding sound effects, pitch correction, preparing the tracks to press them onto fancy CD's, iTunes and SH*T.
  • Water - Actors instruments need to be lubricated.
  • Design - Graphic design for the CD cover and liner notes.
  • Duplication/Distribution - Everything we slaved over for a week gets sent out. CD's get pressed, retail packaging is produced, files are uploaded to iTunes, CD Baby, Amazon, etc. because you shouldn't have to look to hard to find Turkie.

If all goes according to plan. We hope to go into the studio the first week of April.

What You Get

Surely you want something in return for forking out your hard earned cash so we have several levels to which you can contribute and get something in return:

  • $25.00 - Poster From the NY Production, MP3 track OF GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**CKER (before the album release) and a ThanksKilling Button
  • $50.00 - CD hot of the presses, MP3 track OF GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**CKER (before the album release), Poster and a Button
  • $100.00 -  CD, MP3 track OF GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**CKER (before the album release) Poster and Button Signed by Jeff Thomson and Jordan Mann
  • $250.00 - CD, MP3 track OF GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**CKER (before the album release), Poster, Button and Sheet Music of GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**KER signed by Jeff Thomson, Jordan Mann and the original Studio Cast (TBA) and a Limited Edition ThanksKilling Hoodie.
  • $1,000.00 - CD, MP3 track OF GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**CKER (before the album release), Poster, Button, Sheet Music of GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**KER signed by Jeff Thomson, Jordan Mann and the original studio cast, Hoodie AND you'll receive a Special Thanks in the printing of the CD.
  • $5,000.00 - Everything above and you'll be credited as a Producer on the Studio Cast Recording of ThanksKilling The Musical.

Other Ways You Can Help

 If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • If you're a huge fan of ThanksKilling and want to see this album get made, help us spread the word and share our campaign with your friends.

Thanks for your time and contributions!!

#GGMF


Photos by Jeff Carpenter Photography featuring; Evan Woltz, Jeff Orton, Larissa Schmitz, Lindsey Larson, Brian Lange, Evan James Hildebrand and Kody Bringman. ThanksKilling made its world premiere at the Balagan Theatre in Seattle, WA November 29, 2013.
story_txt:
ThanksKilling The Musical
What happens when you take a terrible movie and set out to make an even more terrible musical? Jeff Thomson, Jordan Mann and David Eck decided to find out. All three were serious creators of musical theatre. They had everything that emerging artists need to make a name for themselves, awards, the respect of their peers and no money.
Being serious is all well and good, but every so often, there's a joy in writing something ridiculous, and as they sought a property to adapt, one name axe murdered its way up to the top of their list.
ThanksKilling. A movie about a foul-mouthed homicidal turkey that didn't include Rob Ford.
After seeing the original film of ThanksKilling, all three realized that this Turkey could not only fly. It could sing.
The original film's shoddy brilliance, its deliberately cliched characters, bad acting, terrible puns, absurd premise and keen self awareness are now the stuff of legend and the creators sought to not just polish the turd before them, but to embrace its turdiness and hold it aloft for all the world to see.
After receiving permission from the film's original creators, and embracing the film's "we shot it in a week for no money" essence, Jeff and Jordan wrote the entire show in three days. They were long days, filled with music, laughter and endless discussions on how many possible rhymes exist for MOTHER F**KER. As Jeff and Jordan wrote, the sublime and ridiculous got together and had a cheap and torrid one night stand and while several souls were condemned to the nether regions of hell, the work was completed and a musical was born in an orgy of blood and feathers and bad bird puns. 
The show was then blessed to be embraced by Balagan Theatre of Seattle, Washington who endowed the show with a cast, a director and the best scenery and costumes that could be had for $4.20.
It was just what was required, and ThanksKilling The Musical burst forth like a necromanced turkey through the innards of an inbred hick to audience adulation and critical praise.
Where will the Turkey strike next? That dear fans, is up to you."Is The Show Going to Be Recorded?"From the moment that we announced there would be a production of ThanksKilling there was one question that was asked, over and over and over again. "Is the show going to be recorded?"Our Facebook timelines and Twitter feeds were constantly filled with this request and we decided to finally give the fans what they've asked for, and give them to opportunity to put their money where their mouth is, and help us make this universal dream a reality.So, we've decided to give it a shot and we're asking for your help. Because everyone deserves to be able to turkey trot to GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**KER on the treadmill and sing along to the infectious rock anthem MAN LOVE.What We NeedWe've been crunching numbers for months and the magic number to make this all happen is $15,000.00.This covers the following:
Musical Director - The piano doesn't play itself and the actors need someone to teach them all of the gobble notes they'll be singing.
Actors/Singers - We have a cast of eight and while we could ask them to work for free, the ones you'd want to actually hear sing won't work for peanuts.
Rehearsal Studio - A room to rehearse for a couple of days, so we don't waste precious time and money in the the studio.
Insurance -  If an actor swallows a microphone while singing, we don't want them to sue us.
Studio Time - We expect it to take us two days to get it all "In the can". The acoustics in grandmas basement, are not what they used to be and we want to give you the best sound using the best equipment we can afford.
Engineer - Someone to mix live as the tracks are being recorded.
Post Production - Take everything we recorded in the studio, equalizing the levels, adding sound effects, pitch correction, preparing the tracks to press them onto fancy CD's, iTunes and SH*T.
Water - Actors instruments need to be lubricated.
Design - Graphic design for the CD cover and liner notes.
Duplication/Distribution - Everything we slaved over for a week gets sent out. CD's get pressed, retail packaging is produced, files are uploaded to iTunes, CD Baby, Amazon, etc. because you shouldn't have to look to hard to find Turkie.
If all goes according to plan. We hope to go into the studio the first week of April.What You GetSurely you want something in return for forking out your hard earned cash so we have several levels to which you can contribute and get something in return:
$25.00 - Poster From the NY Production, MP3 track OF GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**CKER (before the album release) and a ThanksKilling Button
$50.00 - CD hot of the presses, MP3 track OF GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**CKER (before the album release), Poster and a Button
$100.00 -  CD, MP3 track OF GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**CKER (before the album release) Poster and Button Signed by Jeff Thomson and Jordan Mann
$250.00 - CD, MP3 track OF GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**CKER (before the album release), Poster, Button and Sheet Music of GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**KER signed by Jeff Thomson, Jordan Mann and the original Studio Cast (TBA) and a Limited Edition ThanksKilling Hoodie.
$1,000.00 - CD, MP3 track OF GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**CKER (before the album release), Poster, Button, Sheet Music of GOBBLE GOBBLE MOTHER F**KER signed by Jeff Thomson, Jordan Mann and the original studio cast, Hoodie AND you'll receive a Special Thanks in the printing of the CD.
$5,000.00 - Everything above and you'll be credited as a Producer on the Studio Cast Recording of ThanksKilling The Musical.
Other Ways You Can Help If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:If you're a huge fan of ThanksKilling and want to see this album get made, help us spread the word and share our campaign with your friends.Thanks for your time and contributions!!#GGMFPhotos by Jeff Carpenter Photography featuring; Evan Woltz, Jeff Orton, Larissa Schmitz, Lindsey Larson, Brian Lange, Evan James Hildebrand and Kody Bringman. ThanksKilling made its world premiere at the Balagan Theatre in Seattle, WA November 29, 2013.

story:
Summary

Hello!

My name is Cole Egbert and I am the director of the Oakland Shakespeare Company's new adaptation of "Macbeth" that is being devised, rehearsed, and performed this summer in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. This is an all-student production based on Shakespeare's beloved classic.

The cast and the creative team have already been assembled and our rehearsal period begins on Monday, May 26th. Our opening night is July 2nd, beneath the stone bridge in Schenley Park. We are running this IndieGoGo campaign to raise the money we need to present a quality production.

What We Need

We are asking for $600 for our project:

- $300 will go toward purchasing materials for our costumes, all of which will be assembled by Alathia Campbell, our student costume designer.

- $100 will go toward the permitting that we require to perform in our desired location, as well as toward fire permits for use in the witches' scenes.

- $90 will go toward the various kinds of makeup and ingredients for stage blood and gore that we wish to use throughout the production.

- $100 will go toward the materials we need for our scenery and also toward the props that we will need to rent or purchase for the show.

- $10 will go toward administrative costs, such as printing, and acquiring any office supplies needed during the process of creating the show.

Impact

We need you.

Any amount you can donate will help realize what is an enormously important project for everyone involved, a project with many hearts and souls already invested in it. To prove this to you, we are offering what I feel is an exciting selection of perks for contributors to show us what your donation means to us.

They include:

- Copies of the program signed by the cast and crew.

- Handwritten thank you notes from myself, the director.

- Exclusive copies of the adapted script we are creating.

- Being recognized in the program as a contributor.

- Invitations to dine with the cast and crew before the show.

Other Ways You Can Help

That's not all.

Even if you can't contribute to our project, there are ways that you can help us which will put us deeply in your debt. Spreading the word about our project is just as important as actually contributing to it.

Whether it's using the share tools on IndieGoGo or, especially, spreading the word about what we are doing and the help that we need to your friends and family, we won't be able to thank you enough.

Cheers!

story:
THE PROJECT! (What’s this all about?) 

We - playwrights Naomi Wallace, Ismail Khalidi and director Caitlin McLeod - need your help to stage this exciting World Premiere of the english-language adaptation of RETURNING TO HAIFA by renowned Palestinian author Ghassan Kanafani in London, February 2018!

This is a darkly comic, deeply human story of two families - one Palestinian, one Israeli - forced by history into an intimacy they didn't choose. This is a drama about memory, erasure and resistance, with frontline immediacy that returns politics to its most personal form.

With your help RETURNING TO HAIFA will receive a full four week run at the brave and award-winning Finborough theatre in London (UK) in the New Year. (check out the theatre here http://www.finboroughtheatre.co.uk/)

                            

                    Ismail Khalidi and Naomi Wallace at the grave of Ghassan Kanafani, Beirut.

THE PLAY

“You haven’t asked, but yes, you both may stay in our house for the time being. And use our things. I figure it’ll take a war to settle it all.”  Said, Returning to Haifa

Synopsis:

In 1948, Palestinian couple Said and Safiyya fled their home in Haifa during the 1948 Nakba. Now, in the aftermath of the 1967 Six Day War, the borders are open for the first time in twenty years, and the couple dare to return back to their home. They are prepared to find someone else living where they once did. Yet nothing can prepare Said and Safyya for the encounter they both desire and dread: the long-awaited news about the son they had to leave behind..

Why we're making it happen now:

This project brings a new intimacy to this beautiful and powerful story by turning it into a stage show for the first time. Ghassan Kanafani had extraordinary compassion for all touched by war, displacement and occupation. The questions he posed to us in 1968 about human nature and about the need to remember and to resist remain as pertinent today as they were in 1969. We want it to happen now, as 2018 marks the 70th anniversary of the dispossession of three quarters of a million Palestinians -  a traumatic event which profoundly shaped Kanafani’s life and about which he wrote so passionately before his assassination in 1972.

About the Adaptation (and why it hasn't happened in New York...yet):

This adaptation by award-winning playwrights Naomi Wallace and Ismail Khalidi was originally commissioned by New York’s Public Theater, which had committed to programming the play but subsequently abandoned the production after political pressure from the board.

Determined not to let censorship keep the public from hearing this vital, visionary voice, Naomi Wallace approached many theaters in the US and UK. It was the fearless Finborough Theatre that came forward to offer their stage for Kanafani’s work.

It now receives its long-overdue world premiere.

Help us break the censorship surrounding works by Palestinian authors in english-speaking theaters and bring this beautiful story to the stage.

TELL ME ABOUT THE MONEY!

This play needs the backing and support of a community of people who believe Kanafani’s voice should be heard now in all it's richness and humanity. This time around, we want total creative control. We refuse to be at the mercy of conservative theater boards and big money venues pulling invisible strings that can collapse a project without warning.

We are  determined to present the world class stage production this story deserves, which means assembling a top-notch international creative team. So, this is where you come in:

  • Our total budget is $40,000.
  • We have already raised a huge $30,000 from supportive sources which means...
  • If you help us raise the last $10,000, then this show will become a reality!
  • Your funds go directly to paying the actors, designers and production team. They will pay for materials for the set, costumes, lights and props. Your money = the physical show itself.

In return we are offering some exciting perks for our supporters!

If you are in the UK/Europe at the time of the show we have exclusive free tickets for the Press Night. We also have lovely materials from the rehearsals and production so that you can be in on the process of making this show (signed by the writers and actors!), and on top of that, bespoke workshops for you aspiring writers/actors/directors out there!

THE PRESS! THE QUOTES! (What people have said about this project and the team)

On the project:

“You should support this project if you oppose the censorship of silenced voices, and if you want to allow a broad audience access to the eloquent, humanistic work of Ghassan Kanafani. One of the most gifted Palestinian writers of the past century, Kanafani fiercely opposed oppression with his pen. He is still being pursued beyond the grave by those who malign him as a "terrorist." With your contribution, you can help to right this wrong.”  - Rashid Khalidi, Edward Said Professor of Modern Arab Studies, University of Columbia, NY.

“Please support this. Live 1967, remember 1948, experience the essence of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict: there is a lot at stake in Ghassan Kanafani's deeply humanist Returning to Haifa. Its adaptation to the London stage is long-overdue and more necessary than ever.” - Bashir Abu-Manneh, Reader is Postcolonial Literature, University of Kent, UK.

On playwright Naomi Wallace:                            

“She speaks to, and for, the body as  eloquently as any American writer since Walt Whitman.”

American Theatre

on Wallace's play The Fever Chart: Three Visions of the Middle East:

"Absolutely compelling theatre." Evening Standard

"... a shudderingly poetic meditation on the implacability of death and the universality of mourning." The Scotsman

"... a taut, beautifully written elegy and it reaches out to us now like a prophecy"  The Observer

On playwright Ismail Khalidi:               

“A beautifully crafted work of art that balances the Lebanese-born playwright’s passion for the politics of his homeland with a playful and irreverent comedic sensibility” Wendell Brock, Atlanta Journal Constitution on Tennis in Nablus

“Writing with an ear for contemporary language and a delightful sense of the absurd...Khalidi defuses the solemnity of his story by masking it with comedic zest. And yet he never negates the horror of the final twist.” Wendell Brock, Atlanta Journal Constitution on Tennis in Nablus

“[Khalidi’s] beautiful writing ranges from a kind of hip-hop spoken word to a Greek chorus to chilling hallucinatory interrogations.” Lydia Howell, Pulse on Truth Serum Blues

On director Caitlin McLeod:                                 

Her previous show at the Finborough Theatre: 

★★★★ The Times, The Guardian, Financial Times, Time Out, WhatsOnStage, Evening Standard, Shortlisted for an Off-West End Award - Best New Play, Time Out Critics’ Choice, Evening Standard Critics’ Choice,

“UNMISSABLE.” Lyn Gardner, The Guardian

“Wise and powerful.” Ian Shuttleworth, Financial Times

“Director Caitlin McLeod has fashioned an intense, gripping production… a potent reminder of the unbeatable power of theatre.” Evening Standard

On the transfer to Signature Theatre, New York City –

“Gracefully directed by Caitlin McLeod.” Time Out New York

“A typically first-class production by the Signature, with the director Caitlin McLeod.” Charles Isherwood, The New York Times

“Under Caitlin McLeod’s direction, the four actresses infuse Wallace’s work with deep feeling. [A] stark, elegiac drama.” The New Yorker

 

In whatever way you can, thank you - from all of us - for supporting this project

 

A bit more about the TEAM (their credentials)

Playwright Naomi Wallace’s plays include In the Heart of America, One Flea Spare, The Trestle at Pope Lick Creek, Things of Dry Hours, The Fever Chart: Three Vision of the Middle East, and And I and Silence. Naomi has twice been awarded the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, the Obie Award and the Horton Foote Award. She is also a recipient of the MacArthur Fellowship, a National Endowment for the Arts development grant, the Windham Campbell Prize for Drama, and an Arts and Letters Award in Literature.

Playwright Ismail Khalidi was born in Beirut and raised in the United States. His plays include Truth Serum Blues and Sabra Falling, Tennis in Nablus and Foot. His writing has appeared in numerous anthologies as well as in The Nation, Guernica, American Theatre, Mizna and Remezcla. Ismail co-edited (with Naomi Wallace) Inside/Outside: Six Plays from Palestine and the Diaspora. He is currently under commission from Noor Theatre and Actors Theatre of Louisville and is currently a visiting artist with Teatro Amal in Chile.

Director Caitlin McLeod is the winner of a Sky Academy Scholarship and the Buzz Goodbody Best Director Award. She returns to the Finborough Theatre where she directed three sell-out shows, one which subsequently transferred to the Signature Theatre, New York City. She is the Artistic Director of new-writing company The Coterie. https://www.thecoterieplatform.com/

Caitlin has directed/associate directed at Shakespeare's Globe, the National Theatre, the Almeida, the Royal Court and Hampstead Theatre.

Writer Ghassan Kanafani:                    

Kanafani was killed by Mossad in a car bomb explosion in 1972, along with his young niece Lamis. Kanafani is of course not the only writer to be murdered because of his revolutionary vision. That list includes Garcia Lorca, Victor Jara and Ken Saro-Wiwa, to name just a few.

45 years after his untimely death, Kanafani is still one of our greatest writers on one of the most intractable and oppressive military occupations..

Kanafani (1936-1972) is widely regarded as one of Palestine’s greatest novelists. He was also an intellectual, visual artist and political activist. His novellas and short stories, now translated into dozens of languages, are considered as ahead of their time, both in form and content. Returning to Haifa is testament not only to Kanafani’s principled commitment to the politics of liberation, but also his deep empathy for the “other” as well as his modern approach to storytelling. Kanafani’s obituary in Lebanon’s The Daily Star states: “He was a commando who never fired a gun, whose weapon was a ball-point pen, and his arena the newspaper pages.”

PEOPLE POWER! (What else you can do to help us)

  • Please spread the word out about our campaign on Facebook and Twitter, help us make some noise about this exciting project!
  • Pass the campaign onto anyone you think might be interested in supporting us.
  • Please use the Indigogo share tools as they are quick and easy!
