Returning to Haifa is testament not only to Kanafani’s principled commitment to the politics of liberation, but also his deep empathy for the “other” as well as his modern approach to storytelling. Kanafani’s obituary in Lebanon’s The Daily Star states: “He was a commando who never fired a gun, whose weapon was a ball-point pen, and his arena the newspaper pages.”PEOPLE POWER! (What else you can do to help us)
Please spread the word out about our campaign on Facebook and Twitter, help us make some noise about this exciting project!
Pass the campaign onto anyone you think might be interested in supporting us.
Please use the Indigogo share tools as they are quick and easy!

story:
So what's this project all about...

Toronto indie theatre companies, Seventh Stage Theatre and Discord and Din Theatre, are producing the Canadian premiere of critically acclaimed play Lela & Co. by British writer Cordelia Lynn. 

This is the untold story - until each night of performance - of a woman sold into sex trafficking during a time of war. While an incredibly difficult subject matter, this brilliantly constructed piece of theatre will allow for a silenced voice, representing the voice of many, to be heard. 

Furthermore, we will raise awareness about sex trafficking by having representatives from related charitable organizations at each performance to provide information to our audience and collect donations for their cause.

Through the power of theatrical story-telling, we hope to bring awareness, compassion and accountability to an issue that not only affects millions beyond our borders, but also in our own country. This is the kind of awareness-raising theatrical work both companies have produced in the past and are passionate about continuing to do in the future.

The bottom line...

We need $7777.00 CDN dollars to break even on our baseline pay for all artists involved. Our entire budget is a lean $38,000. We have reached just over $30,000 with the assistance of the Toronto Arts Council, several class/workshop fundraising initiatives and projected ticket sales (at 50% capacity). We are asking for your help for this last leg of the journey. 

Directed by Seventh Stage Artistic Producer Melissa-Jane Shaw and starring Discord and Din Artistic Producer Jenna Harris, this production will give all involved an opportunity to grow and develop as artists in their respective fields. These funds will go towards the rest of our all-female team of designers: Claire Hill (scenography), Verne Good (sound design) and Jazz Kamal (lighting design), as well as to our emerging Associate Producer, Brittany Kay.

Each PERK will receive a Canadian charitable tax receipt via email, in addition to several other items to show you our gratitude and appreciation. Without your generosity this kind of art would not be possible.

What's the impact of this kind of project...

Seventh Stage has a track-record of producing critically acclaimed box office successes, that are politically poignant and socially relevant. Seventh Stage has been nominated for 3 Dora Mavor Moore Awards, has provided 12 Emerging Female Artist Internships and has produced 7 full professional productions and 3 workshops. And we are just getting started! Discord and Din Theatre is making a name for itself in the Toronto independent theatre scene with a critically acclaimed track-record of producing intimate and innovative theatrical experiences. 

*Photos alongside our PERKS are from our past productions

Other ways you can help...

Seventh Stage Theatre is a Canadian charitable tax organization: Registered charitable number: BN 824923528RR0001. If you believe in this project and our organization, we welcome your donations via CanadaHelps.

Should financial support not be in the cards, you can share your enthusiasm and passion for our cause on social media via the Indiegogo sharing tools, and also by using the hashtag #LelaCoTO. 

Thank you for your consideration of our campaign. We hope that you'll join us to together bring this important work to the stage.

story:
What is Gotta Getta Girl?

 

Gotta Getta Girl is an homage to MGM musicals like Singin' In The Rain and The Band Wagon, but with a distinctly gay twist. Many people have enjoyed readings of the show over the past few years and asked, “When can we see a full production?” Well, Amas Musical Theatre is producing its Off-Broadway debut at ART/NY this fall... but we still need to raise money for the production.

 

"Peter and I met 14 years ago, when I music-directed workshops of Peter's show Escape From Pterodactyl Island,"  says composer David Caldwell. "We have written several projects together since then. We were drawn to the idea that became Gotta Getta Girl by a shared love of golden-age, dance-driven Hollywood musicals. When Randy Skinner (4-time Tony nominee; 42nd Street, White Christmas, Dames At Sea) expressed interest in directing and choreographing the show, we were over the moon! He is a master of all styles of dance, particularly of tap from the '30s and '40s." 

 

We hope that you will share our excitement about bringing Gotta Getta Girl to ART/NY this fall. By contributing to our Indiegogo campaign, you can help support the glorious tradition of the Off-Broadway musical. And you can help remind audiences that same-sex love and marriage are to be respected and protected.

 

 

What we need

 

Our goal for this campaign is $30,000. Every dollar will go directly into production costs. Of course, it costs much more than that to mount an Off-Broadway production. Our producer, Donna Trinkoff, is also raising money by traditional means. But every dollar helps. We need to pay for the costumes and set, the rental of the theater, advertising, and of course, salaries for the actors, the director/choreographer, the designers and the crew. Even if we don't reach our Indiegogo goal, the funds will still contribute enormously to paying for the production.

 

 

Why is Gotta Getta Girl important?

 

Of course, we would be thrilled to have a successful production of Gotta Getta Girl; if the show is well-received, it could have a profitable life in stock and regional productions. It could further our careers.  And it could open the minds of those who do not understand gay people or appreciate that they too have a right to love.


 

What are the challenges?
 

The biggest challenge will be getting the public interested in a new, small, intimate Off-Broadway musical in an era when Off-Broadway is in a slump.  But we are well qualified to deal with this. We've both worked Off-Broadway (I music-directed Forbidden Broadway for ten years; Peter wrote Shout! The Mod Musical) and regionally (we worked together on High Hair & Jalapenos).  Peter has examined gay themes in the past, most notably in Howard Crabtree's Whoop Dee Doo!  And, of course, Randy has numerous Broadway credits: 42nd Street, White Christmas, Dames at Sea, and Ain't Broadway Grand (which Peter second-acted!)

 

Peter Charles Morris, Librettist/Lyricist

 

Peter Charles Morris was most recently represented off-Broadway by Shout! The Mod Musical, for which he co-authored the book. (The show is currently being produced by small theatres across the country.) He was the co-author and co-lyricist of Howard Crabtree’s Whoop-Dee-Doo!, winner of the 1994 Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Musical Revue. His musicalization of The Adventures of Mottel, based on Sholom Aleichem’s last book, was commissioned by the Kaufman Cultural Arts Center of New York and performed at Merkin Hall in March 2007. Other produced works include Frankly, Scarlett, a farce co-authored with Phillip George, about the making of Gone with the Wind; The Remarkable Ruth Fields, a musical comedy about the trials and tribulations of a bearded lady, which received five 1992 Backstage Bistro Awards; Listen to the Wind, the 1995 revival of the 1955 British musical for which he fashioned a new libretto; and High Hair & Jalapenos, an original musical revue lampooning Texas which has become a regular theatrical event in San Antonio. His musical version of William Makepeace Thackeray’s fairy tale novella The Rose and the Ring premiered in London in December 2001, and had an international tour of Canada, England and Australia in 2004. He has written numerous one-act plays, winning the Tennessee Williams One-Act Play Competition for The World’s Longest Kiss. His full-length play No Place Like Home premiered at South Carolina’s Trustus Theatre in 2004. He served as script consultant for My Favorite Broadway: The Love Songs, which was performed at NY’s City Center and subsequently aired on PBS. Mr. Morris is an alumnus of the BMI Advanced Musical Theatre Workshop.

 

David Caldwell, Composer

 

David Caldwell composed music and lyrics for All I Really Need to Know I Learned in Kindergarten and Uh-Oh Here Comes Christmas, both based on the writing of Robert Fulghum. He also composed music for Fulghum's novel Third Wish. David was the music director of Forbidden Broadway from 2004 to 2014. He conducted the American premiere of Stephen Schwartz's Children of Eden. He recently music-directed Murder For Two Off-Broadway, as well as three shows in China, with Inner Mongolian authors and casts. He arranged and orchestrated Marvin Hamlisch's song “I'm Really Dancing” for Career Transitions for Dancers' 25th Anniversary Gala, featuring Angela Lansbury, Chita Rivera and Bebe Neuwirth. David is originally from New Hampshire. He is a graduate of Oberlin Conservatory. He is interviewed at length in Oliver Sacks' book about music and the brain, Musicophilia. He is on the faculty of the American Musical & Dramatic Academy, and is married to Alyssa H. Chase.

story:
Our Project

This autumn we are excited to be embarking on a new phase of our choreographic research in improvisation and live-composition languages through a series of week-long residencies awarded by Edinburgh Dance Base (Scotland's National Centre for Dance), DEOS at Teatro Carlo Felice, Genova and Yorkshire Dance, Leeds. Whilst we are receiving some financial support from Edinburgh Dance Base, we still need to raise funds for costs including travel, accommodation and fees for collaborators who will join us at different stages throughout the project. Since these opportunities only came through recently, we are using this crowdfunding campaign to ask our community for assistance as we take on these fantastic opportunities.

Our background in brief: We are dance artists based in London. We met during our training at Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance in 2008 and we have stuck together ever since, as friends and co-workers. We have practiced as choreographers and performers throughout Europe and our experience of improvisation and live-composition is influenced by the work of choreographers who we have encountered, and performed, throughout our career (Trisha Brown, Gill Clarke, Leila McMillan, Claudia Dias, to name a few).

We have always been interested in improvisation practices. Our first experience with live-composition was through composer and musician Diego Ghymers (1976-2015) who introduced us to Soundpainting, a multidisciplinary live-composing sign language created by Walter Thompson in 1974. In a Soundpainting performance a 'conductor' uses a rich sign language (over 1000 signs have been catalogued) to guide artists (musicians, dancers, actors, etcetera!) in an improvised performance. Between 2010 and 2013 we were both members of the London Soundpainting Orchestra, founded by Ghymers. With the orchestra we collaborated with major London institutions, such as Shunt, The Southbank Centre, Blackheath Hall and the London Coliseum. This fascinating technique is central to our current research: we are interested in developing and subverting the technique specifically in the context of dance and movement practice.

We will research and develop our new work by employing a variety of live-composition methodologies; we will use the Soundpainting language and bring this into a creative conversation with other improvisational and live-composition techniques which have strongly influenced our work as choreographers and performers – for example, David Zambrano’s Passing Through, Francesco Scavetta’s Surprised Body Project and Joao Fieadeiro’s Real Time Composition.

We have spent the summer compiling our thoughts for this new phase in our work and applying for residency opportunities. We are thrilled with the offers we now have to develop it in Edinburgh, Leeds and Genova- and we'll have more residencies coming over the North and South East of England! Throughout these residencies, we will open up our research to the local dance communities in the form of open classes, workshops and events. This part of our research is particularly important to us as the methodologies we are working with directly promote group work as a way to challenge technique and push the boundaries of the method.

Being afforded this time and space in the form of research residencies allows us to build our new movement practice and to communicate these discoveries to our colleagues in dance as well as to establish new relationships with different artistic groups across Europe.

Your support is crucial to our developing this work and we are so grateful for your time and generosity.

Thank you!

 

Typhaine and Virginia

 

www.dancebase.co.uk

www.yorkshiredance.com

http://www.carlofelicegenova.it/teatro/deos/

https://virginiascudeletti.com

 

What we need and what you get:

We calculated that on top of the funding received by Edinburgh National Dance House, we need £1500.

The money we raise will go towards travel, accommodation, the chance of offering free workshops and a fee for collaborators who will join us during certain stages of the residencies. Any amount, small or large is appreciated. We will keep a daily online diary during our residencies, where you can follow our progress into our research. Certain contributions will be rewarded!

 

£10 or more. Thank you picture on social media

£20 or more. Thank you video with improvised dance from Typhaine or Virginia dedicated specially to you

£50 or more. Thank you picture + an improvised duet on video dedicated specially to you. You will also have access to one of our workshops in the future.

£100 or more. Thank you picture + an improvised duet on video dedicated specially to you + a video of the latest sharing of our work. You will also have access to one of our workshops in the future.

£250 or more. All of the above + an invitation to develop a long term artistic relationship with us. You will be welcome to access the studio and witness our research, discuss with us and be involved in our creative process.

 

Other ways you can help:

If you feel you can't donate right now, no stress. Remember that you can support us by sharing the campaign and telling people about us. And please get in touch and keep updated about our progress.

 

Risk and Challenges:

If we don’t achieve our goal the priority will be to cover fees and travel with whatever amount we make. We might have to reduce the time we dedicate to the project, therefore the progress will be a bit slower but we are determined to keep the project going forward.

story:
Shen Jun Movement Effect presents ORBITS

 

And each of us is not only our own lives unwinding forward
but also a part of (and in service to)
the larger life of the tribe
which in turn is in service to the larger life of the species
which in turn is in service to a larger life source
lost in a bath of stars that is a galaxy
scattered in the hugeness of the universe.
     --Dennis Downey, “We Never Go Away”

 

April 21, 22, and 23, we will gather on the South Lamar Pedestrian Bridge
to explore our connection to our nine planets and their passage through the Universe.

Each performance happens from twilight to nightfall.

Each of our nine dancers represents a being in our solar system, a planet; each planet has a path and style its own.

Viewers and passersby become part of the motion, and participate by using their phones as
lighting and to live-stream the event.

Austin composers will present an original score along with improvisations created in concert with the dancers.

 

We Need Money For Equipment & Dancers

  • Equipment
  • Artists 

Props and Lighting.  $200

Rehearsal Space: $300

Stipends for Dancers and Musicians. $2,000

The ORBITS Cast

Shen Jun, Genevieve Addie, Ally Morales, Kassie Kelly, Katie Gunderson, Katie McCarn, Rachel Clark, Audrey Halm, Erin Fulton

Introducing Shen Jun Movement Effect

Our MISSION is to bring dance out of the concert halls and into the streets, into the countryside, into people’s lives. Dance began as a communal event and we are here to keep it that way. 

SJME is the brainchild of our artistic director, Shen Jun, born in China, began dancing in high school. He received his Bachelor’s degree in dance at Beijing Capital Normal University. He attended Beijing Dance LDTX as a dancer and choreographer after his graduation. In the past several years, he has performed and choreographed many dance works in numerous worldwide dance festivals. He collaborated with different artists from various fields as well. Additionally, he has had rich teaching experiences in dance training. He was invited to join the graduate dance program at UT Austin in 2013, and eventually earned his Masters degree of Fine arts in the May of 2016. Now, he is the Artistic Director of Shen Jun Movement Effect. Meanwhile, he is working at Blue Lapis Light Aerial Dance Company as a dancer and instructor, as well as an assistant professor in Austin Community College.

Along with Jun, we are led by Genevieve Addie. Genevieve began dancing at age 3 and dance became a permanent fixture throughout her entire life. She received her Bachelor of Fine Arts from The University of Arkansas Little Rock in 2012. Prior to graduation, she had many opportunities to learn and expand through performance and training under world renowned artist. Since moving to Austin, Genevieve has trained and performed with a number of local companies and artists, continuing her movement education and creating strong relationships within the Austin Dance Community. Genevieve is now collaborating with Jun Shen as the Co-Director for Shen Jun Movement Effect. She is excited to share her passion and knowledge with those who are open to exploring with her.

SJME is an international company based in Austin, with ties to China and Europe. We combine dance, theater, martial arts, interpretive movement, and music. 

In our brief HISTORY, we have produced two shows in Austin. “Slowness” was presented as part of Jennifer Sherburn’s 11:11 in November 2016. Then in December we mounted a full-length show, Grit of Soul, in which we celebrated the hardships of life. For our artistic director, Shen Jun, “grit” is the sandpaper that make us shine, so we welcome the friction.

 

Orbits is the first event in our new season. We will be presenting other site-specific events and a full-length show is coming in Fall 2017.

Rehearsal Space: $300
Stipends for Dancers and Musicians. $2,000
The ORBITS Cast
Shen Jun, Genevieve Addie, Ally Morales, Kassie Kelly, Katie Gunderson, Katie McCarn, Rachel Clark, Audrey Halm, Erin Fulton
Introducing Shen Jun Movement Effect
Our MISSION is to bring dance out of the concert halls and into the streets, into the countryside, into people’s lives. Dance began as a communal event and we are here to keep it that way. 
SJME is the brainchild of our artistic director, Shen Jun, born in China, began dancing in high school. He received his Bachelor’s degree in dance at Beijing Capital Normal University. He attended Beijing Dance LDTX as a dancer and choreographer after his graduation. In the past several years, he has performed and choreographed many dance works in numerous worldwide dance festivals. He collaborated with different artists from various fields as well. Additionally, he has had rich teaching experiences in dance training. He was invited to join the graduate dance program at UT Austin in 2013, and eventually earned his Masters degree of Fine arts in the May of 2016. Now, he is the Artistic Director of Shen Jun Movement Effect. Meanwhile, he is working at Blue Lapis Light Aerial Dance Company as a dancer and instructor, as well as an assistant professor in Austin Community College.
Along with Jun, we are led by Genevieve Addie. Genevieve began dancing at age 3 and dance became a permanent fixture throughout her entire life. She received her Bachelor of Fine Arts from The University of Arkansas Little Rock in 2012. Prior to graduation, she had many opportunities to learn and expand through performance and training under world renowned artist. Since moving to Austin, Genevieve has trained and performed with a number of local companies and artists, continuing her movement education and creating strong relationships within the Austin Dance Community. Genevieve is now collaborating with Jun Shen as the Co-Director for Shen Jun Movement Effect. She is excited to share her passion and knowledge with those who are open to exploring with her.
SJME is an international company based in Austin, with ties to China and Europe. We combine dance, theater, martial arts, interpretive movement, and music. 
In our brief HISTORY, we have produced two shows in Austin. “Slowness” was presented as part of Jennifer Sherburn’s 11:11 in November 2016. Then in December we mounted a full-length show, Grit of Soul, in which we celebrated the hardships of life. For our artistic director, Shen Jun, “grit” is the sandpaper that make us shine, so we welcome the friction.
 
Orbits is the first event in our new season. We will be presenting other site-specific events and a full-length show is coming in Fall 2017.

story:
Who are you?

We are The Jacobins.

We tell stories of personal revolutions. 

The Book of Sebastián is our inaugural production! 

Read more about our team at thejacobins.org

Where is my money going?

 

What's this show all about?

Spain, 1937 

A volatile period of Civil War.

As the front descends upon his hometown, Sebastián, a mischievous young Jesuit with a thirst for adventure, sets off to discover life on his own terms.  His search is challenged by an eccentric ferryman, a rebel band of socialists, and a nation grappling with its uncertain future.

Based on the classic novel Siddhartha by Herman Hesse, The Book of Sebastián is a sweeping exploration of passion, consequence, and how we define God in a modern world.

Risks & Challenges

As a brand new company, there are going to be challenges in getting our ball rolling. For many of us, this our first time producing a piece in this way. We want to create the highest quality piece possible on a realistic budget. This will mean trying to find cheap ways to create magic on stage and assembling a team that is ready to go all in on the piece. We believe we are off to a good start but won't be afraid to ask for help if we need it.

Other Ways You Can Help

We get that you can't alway contribute to a cause monetarily. We really do! And that's ok. We hope you'll still be able to make it out to the show in August. And please help us get the word out. Share this page on your preferred social media platforms, send it to people you think might have a particular interest, and don't forget that you can use IndieGoGo's built in sharing buttons too!

story:
About the show

If you're here, you either know me personally, or take an interest in Indigenous theatre in Canada. In my final project as a student at Rosebud School of the Arts, Ancient Indigenous folklore, North American cultural staples gone extinct, and a young man's life as the son of a preacher come to Calgary in Kohkum & me, an Indigenous theatre experience unlike anything before seen on Turtle Island. I act as playwright, composer, lyricist, actor and producer in The Rest of Us Theatre Co.'s world premier at the Motel Theatre in Calgary AB's Arts Commons, June 4-8 2019, and our remount at the 2019 Calgary Fringe Festival!  I'm joined by an incredible team of artists including director Heidi MacDonald, actor Justin Lanouette, and designer Anna Dalgleish in bringing this story to life!

What We Need To Make it Happen

Theatre needs two things outside of the team creating it; an audience, and funds. This is where you come in! We need to raise $1,500 to cover costs such as:

  • Venue rental and insurance
  • Artist fees/honorariums
  • Marketing costs/materials, etc.
  • Fuel, accommodations and per diems for artists involved 
  • Sound effects
  • Fringe Festival Fee

Your support helps cover these costs and allows box office revenue to carry the show into further productions. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to contribute but still want to...contribute? Some very important things you can do to help us get this show on the road include:

  • Tell your friends
  • Bring your friends
  • Share our promo stuff on social media
  • COME SEE THE SHOW!

Any support is appreciated, your presence and interest s an audience is what makes theatre. Otherwise it's just rehearsal!

story:
About the Play

South Devon, 2001. Jeff is a dairy vet with a problem. Michael is a cattle farmer – he is a problem. The two men have a begrudging respect for one another, usually expressed through a shared fag, a nip of whisky and some boisterous banter.

But when Foot and Mouth sweeps the UK countryside their friendship – and indeed their whole way of life – is thrown into question. Michael watches in disbelief as his cows are rounded up and, to his horror, it is Jeff brandishing the gun.

Tender, funny and full of love, And Then Come the Nightjars is a story of male friendship against the odds, and a tribute to rural English life. It was selected from 1500 scripts as winner of the Theatre503 Playwriting Award and received six Off West End nominations, including Best New Play.

“A savagely funny and sad play directed with real delicacy”★★★★ The Guardian

What We Need & What You Get

We have already received some financial support from Arts Council England but we need your help to raise an additional £1,000 towards the budget of And Then Come The Nightjars.

Check out the perks on the right hand side, but any size donation is very welcome. If you wish to make a larger donation, please get in touch with the team directly via tara@tarafinney.com

Other Ways You Can Help

Please do help us to get the word out about And Then Come The Nightjars by sharing/tweeting our campaign - reminder that Indiegogo has its own share tools!

@tara_finney @theatre503 @bristololdvic #NightjarsPlay
